PETITION.TITLE: Local Television, Illawarra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That a Government decision to force, at the expense of viewers, the transfer of WIN TV (and any future local broadcast) from VHF to UHF transmission, while excluding Sydney metropolitan T.V. stations from this requirement, will place in jeopardy the future of the Illawarra and South Coast region's only local commercial T.V. operator.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call on questions without notice I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Gallery of former Senator Lajovic, and on behalf of all honourable senators I extend to him a warm and friendly welcome upon his return to Canberra.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Grimes will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Grimes in relation to his portfolio or to those he represents in the chamber should be directed to Senator Ryan.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: Is it a fact that seven Ministers, including those with big budget portfolios such as Social Security and Health, have told the Prime Minister that it is not possible to set spending priorities in their departments? What implications does this refusal to consider expenditure reductions have for the Government's ability to deliver tax cuts and cheaper petrol?

—The Government will meet its commitments on fiscal policy and will introduce the tax cuts as promised-a matter which I confirmed in the Senate last week. In respect of the oil pricing issue the Government, as is common knowledge, is considering that matter at the moment. When a decision has been reached it will be made known generally as quickly as possible.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that reply. Does that mean that the Ministers concerned will in fact have to set the spending priorities which have been requested of them?

—The reply means that the Government will meet its commitments. The Cabinet process is a collective one. As I said, the Government will meet its commitments and that will include its commitments to social welfare.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of an analysis of the Tasmanian economy which showed a sharp rise in bankruptcies and greater than average unemployment levels in that State in 1985. Will the Minister comment on claims that the analysis showed a monumental failure of the Gray Government in managing the State's economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the generally abysmal record of the Tasmanian economy in recent years-a record which equals or arguably even surpasses the abysmal record of the Government of Queensland. I think Senator Devlin referred to bankruptcies. In 1985 in Tasmania non-corporate bankruptcies were above 300, an increase of 21 per cent of the figure for the previous year. More significantly, Tasmania has the worst record of any State on unemployment. In the most recent figures, that is, for January 1986, Tasmania had the highest unemployment rate of any State on the raw figures at 10 1/2 per cent-a full 2 per cent above the national average. It is the only State to have recorded a rise in unemployment over the year from January to January when the Tasmanian unemployment rate went up from 10.2 per cent to 10.5 per cent and the Australian average fell from 9.3 per cent to 8.5 per cent. A year ago there was less than a one per cent difference between the Tasmanian unemployment rate and the national unemployment rate. That differential has more than doubled from 8 1/2 per cent to 10 1/2 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Not surprisingly, the increase in the number of people employed in the year to January in Tasmania was minimal. While there were 185,000 extra jobs in Australia as a whole over the 12 months ending January, in Tasmania there was an increase of only 1,700 or, in percentage terms, 3.4 and 1.2 per cent respectively. If I may say so, that abysmal record is in spite of the very generous financial treatment which the Tasmanian Government and the Tasmanian State get from the Federal Government with per capita payments which are very much higher than the national average and very much higher than for any other State. That is in addition to the very generous employment creation arrangements and so on which are being provided by this Government. In spite of all that, not only is the Tasmanian economy the worst performer in all Australia but also the gap between Tasmania and the rest of Australia has widened.

Tasmania, with Queensland, is dragging the rest of Australia down, although the quantitative importance of Queensland, because that State is very much larger and its economy very much larger, is much more serious compared with the relatively small economy of Tasmania, Finally, I suggest that it is no coincidence at all that the two States with the worst economic record by far in Australia are the only two States which do not have Labor governments.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS' AFFAIRS: EXPENDITURE CUTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Veterans' Affairs believe that it is possible to set priorities for spending cuts in his Department and, if not, why not?

—There are always possibilities in all government departments to make savings in some areas for the purpose of establishing priorities in others, initiating new programs or improving existing programs, particularly as they relate to treatment services, which is probably an important area in the Department of Veterans' Affairs, as it is important to improve the facilities in the repatriation hospitals. Those matters are receiving consideration in respect of the Budget and I have nothing further to add.

—Will the Minister for Resources and Energy outline what forms of assistance will be given to the tin mining industry following a recent report on the severe problems being experienced in that sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has received a submission from the North Queensland Tin Producers Association, which represents small tin producers in that region. The submission seeks financial assistance in the face of the sharp and unexpected decline in world tin prices and the expectations of continuing low tin prices in the future as a result of the suspension of buffer stock operations on the London Metal Exchange on 24 October last.

ANSWER.PARA: My Department, in consultation with other relevant departments, is at present actively examining that submission. Officers of my Department and the Bureau of Mineral Resources recently visited the Cairns-Mareeba tin mining district to assess the situation at first hand and also to try to get some more details in addition to those that have been provided so far as to the financial plight of the tin producers. As a result of all that, I expect the Government will be considering the NQTPA request for assistance soon. I will certainly be seeing a delegation from those producers later in the week.

I should just mention finally that the world tin market has been in disarray since the cessation of the International Tin Council buffer stock operations and the suspension of LME tin trading on 24 October. The Australian Government, through its delegation to the International Tin Council, is keeping in close touch with those Council discussions related to negotiations currently under way in London on a rescue package put forward by the banks and brokers. The objective of these negotiations is to achieve an orderly disposal of the ITC buffer stock and the re-opening of tin trading on the London Metal Exchange. It is still premature, however, to anticipate what the final result of these negotiations may be.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO BRITISH NUCLEAR TESTS IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The report of the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australian has been tabled in Parliament and has been before the Government for some time now. Can the Minister say when the Government will announce its response to that report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not really been a very long time. It was only at the end of last year that we received the report. What is happening is this: I announced in London on 23 January that following my discussions with United Kingdom Ministers-which discussions, I should add, proceeded on a rather more amicable and constructive basis than some earlier exchanges involving other persons-a technical assessment group has been established to advise on options for the decontamination of the atomic test sites so that informed decisions can be made by the Government on the most appropriate and cost effective means of rehabilitating the sites and, in particular, of course, the Maralinga site, where we have a major clean-up problem involving approximately 1 1/2 kilograms of plutonium dispersed in the form of 100,000-odd contaminated fragments of unacceptable concentrations, with approximately 20 kilos of plutonium buried in a mass of debris in 20 burial pits, and, in addition, large quantities of uranium and the toxic chemical beryllium scattered around other minor trial sites.

ANSWER.PARA: Agreement has now been reached with the United Kingdom Government on detailed terms of reference for the committee and its membership. I hope to be in a position to table in the Parliament before this week is out the relevant exchange of letters and to give some indication of the likely timetable for the deliberations of this technical assessment group. I also announced in London the establishment of a consultative group consisting of representatives from the Australian, United Kingdom, South Australian and Western Australian governments, together with Aboriginal interests, to discuss and monitor progress on the rehabilitation of the sites. I am keen to ensure that that consultative group is established and that its discussions proceed at the same time as the technical assessment group, which will comprise expert scientists, will be doing its job.

As to those recommendations of the Royal Commission report concerning compensation for claims of personal illness, the Government is currently considering those recommendations and I would expect decisions to be announced during the current autumn session of parliament. We are also giving consideration to the remaining recommendation of the Commission which concerns compensation to Aboriginals for the loss of use and enjoyment of Maralinga lands. I would not care to put a precise time at this stage as to when it might be possible to reach a concluded decision on that, but again it will be as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Finance believe there is room for any further reduction in Commonwealth Government welfare spending, or would such cuts only aggravate the worsening poverty and homelessness which have been a feature of the Hawke Government, this fact being recognised as recently as yesterday by Mr Gerry Hand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since this Government came to office social welfare recipients have received $1,500m over and above indexation. Certainly, some measures have been taken to withdraw social welfare benefits from people who did not need them, at very considerable savings on outlays. So far as the means test, for example, is concerned, by next year the likely total savings will be more than $200m. It is interesting to note that the Opposition, of course, opposed that measure and continues to oppose it. The Opposition behaves as irresponsibly in opposition as it did in government. As a measure of its irresponsibility in government I refer to the record of the five years during which the present Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer of Australia. In any one of those years actual expenditures were in excess of the budget estimate. The figures range from $175m in the first year, a very small figure in the second, $244m, $463m and, in his final year as Treasurer, $2 billion--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Having listened carefully to the answer being given by the Minister, I submit that there is absolutely no relevance in the point he is making to the question he was asked. He was asked a question relating to welfare expenditure and the ability to cut costs. He is now responding by making allegations about over-spending in a total Budget. That seems to me to be totally irrelevant to the question that was asked. I ask you to insist that the Minister addresses remarks which are relevant to the question which has been raised.
—Order! I assume that the Minister in answering the question is referring to the matter in generality, but I would ask him to come to the point as soon as he possibly can.

—Certainly, Mr President. I can understand the sensitivity of the Opposition in not wishing to be reminded of the fact that in the last year that the discredited former Treasurer was in office outlays exceeded Budget estimates by almost $2 billion and the deficit exceeded the Budget estimate by almost $3 billion. That is an example of the sort of fiscal irresponsibility which Mr Howard practised when in Government. So far as this Government is concerned, fiscal irresponsibility has been outlawed and because of that and because of the discipline that that imposes on a government in the social welfare area, this Government has adopted the approach of targeting social welfare expenditure; that is targeting it on the needy groups and a necessary corollary of that was that welfare expenditures which were not needed by other groups in the country have been withdrawn.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting to note that the Opposition has opposed that policy of directing welfare expenditure to the needy groups and targeting it in the most cost-efficient way. That is the policy which this Government has followed. It is the policy which this Government will continue to follow in marked distinction to that of the previous Government, of course, which was one of fiscal irresponsibility-let the deficit blow out, let the outlays blow out and leave the problem for some other government to sort out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to an article in today's Australian Financial Review entitled: `Minister doubts $100m figure put on education revenue'. Does the Minister believe that the Government's new policy of exporting education services to our geographical region will result in significant Budget savings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I certainly do believe that there is great potential for earning export dollars by making available for purchase in the region certain high quality and specialist services. I was rather disappointed to read that article in the Australian Financial Review because it put a very negative complexion on what is a very positive policy. Last year our Government, when reviewing the overseas students policy, had available to it certain recommendations from the report of the Jackson Committee on the Australian Overseas Aid Program concerning the potential market there is in our region for our very high standard education services.

ANSWER.PARA: We announced a number of steps which will enable Australians to have the benefit of those services. The first and perhaps a minor part of the new policy is that institutions which are interested in and able to provide extra places in sought after courses at full cost to overseas students will be able to do so. I am pleased to report to the Senate that at the most recent count eight institutions, mainly institutes of technology, have made known their capacity to take in extra overseas students at full cost. Other institutions are expressing an interest in doing this and are having discussions with the overseas student's office in my Department and the Trade Commissioner Service to see how they can pursue these opportunities. But even more than the export dollars that will be earned in this way, I believe is the possibility for countries in the region, particularly some Association of South East Asian Nations to purchase quite large consultancy services from Australia.

I visited a number of these countries recently. In Indonesia, Malaysia and Brunei there was great interest expressed in the possibility of purchasing services which will enable, in the case of Brunei, the development of a university there. Great interest was expressed in Indonesia in purchasing services related to the teaching of English as a second language and vocational education at the tertiary and further education level, both areas in which, of course, we have considerable expertise in Australia. In Malaysia an interest was expressed in the purchase of part places in faculties such as medicine and engineering in our institutions. When I say `part places' I mean arrangements are now being negotiated whereby students can do parts of their courses in Malaysian universities and complete the senior levels of their courses in Australian institutions. Those are just some examples of the way in which we will be able to utilise the fact that we have developed very high standards of education, particularly in fields which are of relevance to the economic development of our region, and that in a forward looking and entrepreneurial fashion our Government has sought to make those services available.

The reason that I refused yesterday to confirm a precise question about $100m was that we are in the experimental stage of this program. It is too early to put precise figures on export earnings expected for this year. It may well be that this year as the first year will not produce export earnings in the vicinity of $100m, but if we proceed to establish this new strategy in a careful and thorough fashion, in consultation with institutions, the private sector, Government agencies and educational authorities in the region, I believe that in years to come there will be significant export earnings and therefore a great contribution to improving our balance of payments situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations explain how his Government can justify the following five community employment program expenditures: Firstly, the allocation of over $47,000 to the unilateralist Campaign for International Co-operation and Disarmament; secondly, $96,000 to the pro-Moscow People for Nuclear Disarmament; thirdly, $249,000 to the Victorian Trades Hall Council to set up a trade union `Art in Working Life' program; over $110,000 to the Victorian Teachers Union to fund a women's affirmative action handbook; and fifthly, over $37,000 to the Italian Community Welfare Information Service, which is a front for the Italian Communist Party? Will the Minister also inform the Senate of how many other leftist and subversive groups and activities are being funded by this Government, using the CEP scheme to launder the money?

—I do not know where Senator Sheil got that list. I understand that News Weekly is a likely source, because apparently it publishes this sort of thing. I will seek a detailed and considered response from Mr Willis. The only thing I can say at this stage is that all projects which are submitted for CEP funding must come within the guidelines and in the main they are administered jointly by officials of State and Commonwealth governments. If Senator Sheil is interested in what he believes to be the misuse of public money, I would not mind, if I may, Mr President, asking him how he justifies the misuse of $5m by the Premier of Queensland to build a dam on the Mackenzie River, principally for the benefit of his son who owns 20,000 acres of land downstream from it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the Minister to a recent report by Amnesty International, related to Central America, which refers to the thousands of political killings and widespread torture that has occurred in Guatemala over the past 15 years against such people as church workers, trade unionists, human rights activists, students and journalists. I ask whether the Australian Government has expressed its objection to this continued abuse of human rights in that country.

—The Amnesty International report referred to by Senator Bolkus is one of a number which have documented Guatemala's poor human rights record. The Australian Government has consistently condemned the repeated instances of massive human rights violations in that country. We have voted in favour of resolutions in the United Nations General Assembly and in the Commission on Human Rights in Geneva which were strongly critical of Guatemala's lack or respect for basic human rights. In addition, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, issued a statement on 23 April 1985 expressing concern at the recent wave of politically motivated violence and his personal alarm that human rights activists had been singled out for attack. This was quickly brought to the attention of the Guatemalan Government of the day. Elections in December 1985 returned Guatemala to civilian government after 31 years of almost uninterrupted military rule. Australia welcomed this development in a message to the President-elect, at the same time joining the United Nations General Assembly in expressing the hope that this election would mark at least the first step towards an improvement in the human rights situation there.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Minister aware of a statement made today by Mr Noakes, the Director-General of the Confederation of Australian Industry, with regard to the productivity case in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to the effect that past productivity growth has already been fully distributed and, furthermore, that part of that productivity growth has been distributed to wage and salary earners in the form of higher real wages, higher levels of employment and increased government services? Mr Noakes stated that this argument has the endorsement of the Prime Minister, the working party on the measurement of labour productivity and all authorities on productivity estimation. Does the Minister agree with Mr Noakes's assertion that the Australian Council of Trade Unions' productivity claim would have no chance of success were it not for the support it is receiving from the Federal Government and the four State Labor governments? In view of the signs that the economy is in an exceedingly difficult situation, will the Government withdraw its support for the claim before the Arbitration Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw a report of what Mr Noakes had to say in the Australian Financial Review. Other organisations such as the Business Council of Australia have also expressed views about this. What he said has a certain deja vu quality about it in the light of the ongoing adversary roles in which these organisations cast themselves from force of habit. That is not to deny any validity in the claims made by Mr Noakes.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the suggestion made by Mr Noakes that the productivity gains have already been distributed, that is a matter which I would have thought would be appropriately assessed by the Arbitration Commission. The Confederation of Australian Industry and other organisations will have ample opportunity to advance those arguments before the Commission when it hears that case. Whether the Arbitration Commission is the appropriate forum to deal with that is another question. However, under the structural and organisational arrangements we have, it is the appropriate forum in the current context. I would have thought that the share of profits in the last 12 months had been such that this is a statement of doubtful quantifiable substantiation. Nonetheless, I interpret that as being a statement by one of a number of organisations in relation to the forthcoming case.

It is of course true that the Government has indicated its broad support for the productivity claim at a reduced percentage from what was originally suggested. That claim will go before the Commission with Government support. So the answer to the last part of the question is no, Government support for the claim will not be withdrawn. I might say that this is part of a wider question of looking at relative shares as a result of improved economic performance. One of the advantages which may very well flow from the productivity increase being taken in superannuation benefits is that it will avoid a severe addition to on-costs and will, I believe, help to stabilise the wage fixing scene in the next couple of years. That is something to which the Government attaches a great deal of importance. So the answer to the final part of the question is no. I broadly disagree with the arguments advanced by Mr Noakes. However, I am not saying that he is wrong in every respect. That is a matter which requires further analysis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Resources and Energy indicate whether Australian exports of petroleum and petroleum products to South Africa have in fact been prohibited as was announced by Cabinet on 19 August 1985?

—The agreement on South Africa reached at the Nassau Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting called for the adoption of a number of economic measures against South Africa. These measures, which were, of course, subsequently endorsed by the Australian Cabinet, included a ban on the sale and export to South Africa of Australian oil. All exports of crude oil and petroleum products from Australia are subject to export controls administered by my colleague the Minister for Trade. Export approvals are given only after the exporter has given an undertaking that no exports will be made to South Africa.

—I refer the Minister for Finance to two answers he gave yesterday concerning real unit labour costs and growth in average weekly earnings in which he claimed that this Government has halved wage increases and inflation. Is the Minister aware of, and alarmed by, the release of inflation figures for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries in 1985 which show that Australia's inflation rate is more than double that of the United States, which was 3.8 per cent for 1985, and more than four times that of West Germany and Japan at 1.8 per cent? Does the Minister agree that six-monthly wage indexation increases under the accord are contributing to a deteriorating inflationary situation compared with that of countries which do not have full wage indexation? Would the Minister mind confining his replies to the current state of Australia?

—I was asked whether I am alarmed by those figures. As accurately as I can recall, those figures are correct. I am not alarmed, but I am concerned about them. I think any sensible person ought to be concerned about them. It is a very broad jump and an illogical jump from that point of being concerned about having a higher inflation rate than most of our trading partners to the assumption which Senator Parer seems to have made that Australia's rate of wage increase and rate of inflation would be lower if it were not for the centralised wage fixing and the prices and incomes accord. One of the countries he mentioned was the United States-I do not remember the exact figures-where the percentage of the work force which is unionised is much less than half of the figure in Australia. Therefore it is not at all reasonable to assume that what has happened in the United States would happen in Australia in a completely different labour market situation. In the case of West Germany, the percentage of the labour force which is unionised is, I think, comparable, but West Germany has a very long tradition, going right back to the 1950s, of having, although it is not formally called an accord, a wages policy under successive governments which has been very similar to the accord in Australia. West Germany over that same period has reaped the benefits of having that sort of policy in place-low inflation rates, high rates of economic growth and low rates of unemployment-although in the last couple of years the record of West Germany, compared with that which it had in the 1960s and 1970s, has been comparatively poor but still vastly better than the record which Australia had over those same decades, as indeed is the record of almost all of the west European democracies, the Netherlands, the Scandinavian countries Austria and Germany, which have also had for that same period broad agreements between organised labour and government about wages policy. Far from drawing comparisons between unlikes-that is, the unlike situations of the labour force and the labour market in the United States and Australia-Senator Parer would be better advised to draw comparisons between what happened in Australia in the early 1980s, when there was a brief period of fairly high economic growth and there was a wages explosion, with what has happened in the last 2 1/2 years when there has been a sustained period of high economic growth accompanied by a very large fall in the rate of wage increases and a very large fall in the rate of inflation.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs inform the Senate of the Australian Government's reaction to the resignation of Dr Van Zyl Slabbert, the Leader of the Progressive Federal Party, from the South African Parliament? What is the Government's assessment of the likely political implications for South Africa of Dr Slabbert's decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has noted with concern the resignation from the South African Parliament of Dr Frederick van Zyl Slabbert as Leader of the Opposition Progressive Federal Party. Dr Slabbert has undoubtedly been one of the most effective critics of the South African Government during his seven years as Leader of the Opposition. Under his leadership that Party has done an outstanding job of exposing the harsh injustices of the apartheid system. Both Mr Hayden and I had the pleasure of meeting him, as I understand Senator Sibraa did also, when he visited Australia last year. He is certainly a very impressive figure.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Slabbert's resignation points up the inadequacy of reforms offered by President Botha in his speeches over the past year, most recently on 31 January. Dr Slabbert's resignation speech was a searching indictment of the established political processes in South Africa including the tri-cameral Parliament and the total inadequacy of the Government's conception of reform. Media reports that his resignation will cause a complete realignment of white politics in South Africa appear at this stage to be somewhat overstated. While some more liberal members of the ruling National Party probably feel some sympathy with Dr Slabbert's resignation, it seems unlikely at this stage that there will be any defections from the National Party to the Progressive Federal Party. The Government will, of course, be closely monitoring the situation and will be following the future course of Dr Slabbert's contribution to the apartheid debate in South Africa with some very considerable interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce: When may the Senate expect to see the legislation to give formal authorisation to the Government's decision to allow the 150 per cent tax deduction for private sector investment in research and development, or is no such legislation necessary or proposed? Will the Senate have any capacity to seek variation of the announced guidelines for the scheme, in particular the exclusion of expenditure on patenting and copyrighting which are often necessary for turning excellent research into commercial viability? Why has this important area of expenditure been excluded from the operations of the scheme to date?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the answer to the first part of the question is 8 May. As to the second two parts of the question as to whether the Senate will have the capacity to make changes in respect of this matter, I suppose the correct answer to that question depends a lot on Senator Puplick-whether he can persuade the Senate that changes ought to be made. Those guidelines which go with the legislation will, I believe, be capable of comment and appropriate change if necessary as I believe they are part of the legislation. I say `I believe'. If I am wrong about that I will come back and tell honourable senators tomorrow.

ANSWER.PARA: As to why patenting and copyright were excluded, I do not know the exact answer to that question, except that I anticipate that there were probably two things; Firstly, a capacity for very large expenses to be involved with that and, secondly, I think that the scheme would probably have run into a wide range of regulatory considerations which unhappily occupy that area and these may have caused some trouble. I am not sure about that, but I will try to get a detailed answer. The scheme has been subject to a number of qualifications in various areas. Any particular interest group might like to blow it out in a particular direction which suits that group. I think that the scheme as a whole as illustrated in the guidelines is fairly correct in the terms of what it purports to cover.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware of a statement made by Senator Peter Baume, the Opposition spokesperson for community services, asking that all potential immigrants be vetted against nazi involvement between 1933 and 1945? Can the Minister assure the Senate that this is, in fact, unnecessary in the light of established immigration procedures?

—I am pleased to report to the Senate that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hurford, has totally discounted the suggestion made by Senator Baume that nazis or former nazis are being allowed to migrate to Australia under our Government. Mr Hurford has pointed out that even the youngest Nazi Party member-someone who was a member of the Hitler Youth Movement in 1945-would be over 50 now and that is not an age group from which migrant intakes come substantially. Mr Hurford has also pointed out that no country has a tighter visa issue system than Australia and that all applicants for migration are carefully screened and their backgrounds fully checked. He emphasises that we will continue to go through these thorough procedures and that there is no point in taking up Senator Peter Baume's suggestion that there is something sloppy about our procedures and that nazis are getting in. I am very pleased that Mr Hurford has made such a clear denunciation of the suggestion of Senator Baume.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. The Government has made its position clear that it has no intention of regulating the flows of money in and out of Australia. If corporations borrow overseas to fund takeovers all our living standards will fall as we pay off the debt. How can the Government stand by and disregard its responsibilities to the community by refusing to regulate these borrowings? Is the Government not concerned that some foreign power could be buying up our productive resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a fundamental inconsistency in the question. Senator Siddons began by referring to overseas borrowings-that is, cash debts-and finished up by talking about buying up equity. There is that fundamental contradiction in the question. But leaving that aside, I suppose the Government could go back to the days when capital flows were regulated as they were in most of the 1950s-certainly soon after the war. However, this Government has chosen a different course and Senator Siddons is quite entitled to argue for some alternative policy if he wishes to do so. He is, however, quite mistaken in his assertion that funds borrowed overseas to facilitate takeovers in Australian industry necessarily cause a fall in our living standards. The critical test of whether funds borrowed overseas for any purpose cause either a fall or a rise in living standards is whether the earning rate of those funds is above or below the interest rate paid on them. That is a question which only time can answer and probably then not in any precise detail. It is logically inaccurate to say that the borrowing of funds overseas necessarily causes living standards to fall. It all depends on whether the earnings on those funds are greater or less than the interest paid on them.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also an error to assume-I know that Senator Siddons did not actually say this, but I think it was implicit in his question-that the borrowing of funds overseas for takeovers or any other purposes necessarily increases our overseas debt. The money does not disappear into a black hole; people who are persuaded to sell shares receive money for them and whether the whole process increases our overseas debt or has any effect on it ultimately depends on what the people who sold the shares did with the money that they received for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I would like the Minister to clarify his comment that there was a fundamental inconsistency in my question in the sense that if, for instance, Holmes a Court borrowed $2 billion overseas to buy equity in an Australian enterprise, would that not affect our balance of payments?

—Well, in the first round it affects the balance of payments to the extent that it means a plus sign of $2 billion, because that is an import of capital. Whether it has any long-term effect on the net indebtedness of the country or its net or continuing wealth is determined by the other factors that I mentioned previously.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in last week's media that the Queensland Government plans to re-write industrial law to force all trade unions, State and Federal, to hold secret ballots before any strike action can be taken by any of the one million workers involved? What legal or other powers does the Queensland Government enjoy that would allow it to force members of Federal unions into this course of action? Is the secret ballot proposal by the Queensland Government a workable one and, if implemented, what would be the likely effects on industrial relations in that State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen media reports along the lines outlined by Senator Jones. However, to the best of my knowledge, or the last time I got any advice on this from Mr Willis, no details were available, although Mr Willis had been trying to obtain details of precisely what it is that the Queensland Government proposes to do. Assuming the media reports are basically correct, we do not know among other things whether the Queensland Government is considering legislating so that a ballot must be held before a strike can be called off, for example, as well as a ballot for calling a strike in the first place. If we really believe in the principle that every member of every union should vote before industrial action of either a positive or a negative kind-if I can use those terms-is taken, it seems to me that it ought to apply in both directions. Of course, there would be very considerable problems with that sort of proposition if, for example, the post office went on strike because presumably we would not be able to call the strike off as we would not be able to conduct a postal ballot to decide whether it should be called off. That is a hypothetical situation, at least according to the advice I have. My advice is that any such law, if passed by the Queensland Government, would not apply to federally registered unions.

ANSWER.PARA: In a more general sense, I am informed that Queensland had legislation requiring compulsory ballots before strikes could be called for 14 years right up to 1975 when it was repealed, presumably because it was found to be ineffective. The Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act also has a provision where under certain circumstances the Commission or a commissioner-I am not sure which-may order a postal ballot of members if a strike is being contemplated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Education aware that the Human Rights Commission is offering, by advertisements in major daily newspapers, an amount of $500 and, in some cases, $1,000 to any individual teacher who will introduce into the curriculum at primary school level a course on human rights? I ask: Firstly, what is the budget for this program, either through the Minister's Department or through, presumably, the Attorney-General's Department? Secondly, what right has the Human Rights Commission to cut across the State education departments on curriculum content?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first comment I have to make in response to Senator Short's question is that the administration of the Human Rights Commission is, of course, the responsibility of the Attorney-General. However, since the question has been asked of me, presumably because it had something to do with possible curriculum developments, I will make some further comments. In response to the last part of the honourable senator's question, the Human Rights Commission has no right, nor would it seek to have any right, to interfere with the State governments' responsibility for the development of curriculum or the responsibility of non-government schools authorities for the curriculum used in their schools. Those rights do not exist in any Federal agency, nor are they being sought.

ANSWER.PARA: What Commonwealth agencies are able to do-this is something which the Commonwealth Curriculum Development Council does-is to assist by the provision of funds or expertise State government or non-government school authorities, where they seek assistance, in the development of new or improved curriculum materials. That sounds to me to be precisely what the Human Rights Commission is doing. If it wishes to make funds available to assist teachers or curriculum specialists to develop curriculum in these areas, that is a perfectly legitimate thing for it to do. Indeed, given, as I recall-Senator Gareth Evans might correct me if I am wrong-that the Human Rights Commission does have in its Act a requirement to engage in education in human rights matters, it probably has a responsibility to attempt to assist education authorities to introduce human rights material into the curriculum. I do not find that the shocking concept that Senator Short seems to find it; in fact, I think there would be a great demand in schools throughout Australia, government and non-government, for such material.

The important point, since there was an implication in Senator Short's question that there was something improper about this action by the Human Rights Commission, is that the determination of what does appear in a school curriculum is not something which is within the domain of Commonwealth responsibility. In respect of State schools it is in the domain of State governments and State education departments. Non-government school authorities make their own decisions, either at the individual school level or, in the case of systems such as the Catholic system, at the Catholic level. So any imputation in Senator Short's question that somehow unwelcome human rights curriculum material will be inflicted on schools is entirely wrong. On the other hand, it is a perfectly legitimate function of the Human Rights Commission to seek to assist in the development of curriculum material where that is sought by those with the proper responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to his non-answer to my question of 12 February in which I sought an Australian Government response to the new United States Ambassador's claim that New Zealand is the Hartley of ANZUS and thus liable to expulsion from the ANZUS alliance. I ask again: Is this not a completely false and misleading analogy, given that it is the United States which must withdraw from ANZUS if it disagrees with New Zealand's policy on nuclear ship visits? Is it not true that New Zealand cannot be expelled from ANZUS, given that under Article X of the Treaty a country can withdraw only by giving one year's notice to the other partners? Is it not also the case that nothing in the ANZUS Treaty necessitates that Australia or New Zealand accept United States nuclear warship visits and that between 1971 and 1976 both the McMahon and Whitlam governments refused entry into Australian ports of United States nuclear warships without any objections being raised by the United States? Why does the Australian Government continue to remain silent in this dispute if the United States is clearly issuing misleading and incorrect statements on the nature of the ANZUS relationship?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, has advised me that he agrees that to describe New Zealand as the Hartley of ANZUS is a somewhat misleading analogy in that it implies that New Zealand could be expelled from the Treaty. The honourable senator is correct in noting that the Treaty does not provide for expulsion but provides only, under Article X, for withdrawal from the Council by giving one year's notice to the Australian Government. To the extent that the United States has given any public indication of its position on this issue, it has, as I understand it, spoken so far of maintaining its security relationship under ANZUS with Australia fully intact but of possibly withdrawing or suspending its security obligations to New Zealand under ANZUS as a result of the New Zealand Government's actions. How that issue is finally resolved formally as between the United States and New Zealand is a matter which we would regard as one appropriate for resolution between those two countries.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the particular part of the question about what there is in the ANZUS Treaty which bears upon the question of nuclear ship visits, it is the case that, although the ANZUS Treaty does not refer to nuclear weapons, the nuclear dimension is important to the credibility and deterrent value of United States defence commitments. Certainly the Australian Government sees port access for United States nuclear-powered warships as essential to the continuing effectiveness of ANZUS.

As to the reference to the alleged behaviour of the Australian Government between 1971 and 1976 being inconsistent, as Senator Vallentine put it, with that sort of approach, let me say this on behalf of the Government: In 1971 the United Kingdom and United States governments were asked to refrain from proposing visits by nuclear-powered warships, pending a full study of the practical requirements in the differing circumstances of each Australian port. This was completed in 1976 with the promulgation of the conditions of entry for nuclear-powered warships which permitted visits to resume. There is simply no comparison between that course of events and these arrangements and the port ban which has been instituted by the New Zealand Government. I repeat that we regard the latter issue as one between New Zealand and the United States and we are simply not seeking to play a role in any sense as an intermediary in that dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In view of the necessity for a vibrant rural economy to improve our balance of payments position, is this Government prepared to initiate relief measures in any or all of the following areas, namely, interest rates, fuel prices, wage flexibility, government over-regulation and tariffs, in order to provide the kind of environment which is essential for our all-important rural industries to stage some sort of economic recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ironic that Senator Bjelke-Petersen of all people should have asked such a question. She asked: Is the Government willing to do anything about government over-regulation? The Government has been trying for almost 12 months to do something about the over-regulation of the Queensland sugar industry. It has run into a brick wall of opposition from her husband. The most regulated industry in Australia is the sugar industry. The Queensland Government decides not only who will grow sugar but also how much they will grow and where they will grow it. It then decides what mill they will deliver it to, and then decides who will market it. Because of that regimentation of the sugar industry which the Queensland Premier and the Queensland Government stubbornly refuse to change in any way, the Queensland sugar industry has been prevented from taking advantage of the potential economies of scale for which its technical efficiency provides the potential.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Kerin has been trying to get the message through to the troglodytes in the Queensland National Party that the world has changed-in particular, the world sugar industry has changed-and that only very low cost producers are likely to have a future in the world markets for sugar. But he has had no success in getting that message through. Although there is a belief that the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Turner, was somewhat more receptive to the sensible ideas which Mr Kerin put to him, he has had the rug pulled right out from underneath him by Senator Bjelke-Petersen's husband. So I find it particularly ironic that Senator Bjelke-Petersen should ask: What will this Government do about the over-regulation of primary industry?

She also mentioned tariffs. I can do no better than to refer her to the comments of the former Liberal member for Mount Marshall of the Western Australian Legislative Assembly, Mr Bill McNee, who was reported in the West Australian on Monday of last week as saying that the members of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's party should remember that it was Black Jack McEwen who imposed the tariff penalty on Australian agriculture; that it was Black Jack McEwen more than any other single politician who was responsible for the structural inefficiency of Australian industry across quite a wide spectrum, from which it still suffers and which this Government since it came to office has been trying in a gradual and orderly way to correct, a matter in which my colleague Senator Button, in particular, of course, has been very deeply involved.

She referred to fuel prices. Again I find it ironic that a member of a party which was part of the coalition Government which increased revenues from oil by 700 per cent, I think the figure was, from something like $400m to $3 1/2 billion in a period of five years, should be complaining about the alleged penalties imposed by the price of fuel. She mentioned wages. She is a member of a coalition party which, during its last two years in office, presided over a wage explosion of 13 per cent in 1981 and 14 per cent in 1982, a rate of wage growth which has been almost halved by this Government. For a member of such a political party to be castigating this Government for its record is, I think, quite unacceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister have up-to-date information on labour market conditions in South Australia? To what extent is the South Australian economy sharing in national economic recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most recent unemployment figures for South Australia show that South Australia has shared in the general recovery of the Australian economy at somewhere, I think, mid-point on a State basis. For example, for the most recent month the unemployment rate has fallen to 9.2 per cent from a figure of 11 per cent in the same month of 1983, a figure which, in 1983, went somewhat higher in the next month or two. South Australia is on line so far as the unemployment rate is concerned with the Australian economy in general; that is, unemployment rates have fallen by around 2 per cent as they have in the rest of the country, on average. The numbers of unemployed, the corollary of that figure, have fallen by almost 8,000 and an additional 42,000 people have found jobs in that period. Again, this is generally consistent with the national figures. The December-January economic newsletter of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia noted, of course, very considerable variation between States. The newsletter states:

ANSWER.PARA: While the national economy is well and truly into its third year of strong expansion, performance at the state and sectoral level has been somewhat uneven.
In contrast to most other states, the Queensland economy was relatively lacklustre over most of the 1984-85 financial year.
The South Australian economy performed reasonably strongly over 1984-85.
The Western Australian economy expanded strongly over the past year, with most sectors experiencing a significant upturn.

I think one or two States using the conventional economic indices of performance-that is, growth rates, increases in employment, decreases in unemployment and so on-are marginally ahead of South Australia. The important thing to note is that they are all Labor Government States and the two States which are spectacularly behind South Australia are the two non-Labor Government States.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FRENCH WARSHIPS: VISITS TO AUSTRALIAN PORTS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Vallentine asked me a rather excited question about two French warships visiting Australia. The answers I have received from the Ministers for Foreign Affairs and Defence are in the following terms: Two French ships, the Jeanne d'Arc and the Commandant Bourdais, are currently visiting Stirling Naval Base in Western Australia and will be calling at Sydney from 27 February to 3 March. The French Government sought permission for the ships to visit Australia en route from Mauritius to Noumea as part of a six-month round the world cruise. It should be appreciated that the Jeanne d'Arc is a naval officers' training ship and it is on a six-month training cruise from November last year to March this year with its escort the Commandant Bourdais.

ANSWER.PARA: A total of 137 cadets is on board the two vessels. During the cruise the ships' complements are engaged, among other things, in a variety of humanitarian assistance programs in Africa and Madagascar including, for example, utilising six helicopters from the ship to assist in a vaccination program for some 20,000 children and 20,000 women against diphtheria, tetanus, polio, whooping cough and so on.

It is usual to approve requests for visits by public vessels of states with which Australia has normal relations. We would expect the French Government, similarly, to agree to receive Australian naval vessels should there be some operational requirements to visit French ports. The Government has made clear, over and again, its opposition to nuclear testing in the South Pacific, its condemnation of the sinking of the Rainbow Warrior and its interest in the constructive resolution of the situation in New Caledonia. We simply do not believe that the course that has been adopted with respect to these two ships in any way cuts across or undermines that position.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond also to a question yesterday from Senator Jessop on the investigation of thefts at Maribyrnong. The answer I received from the Special Minister of State is in the following terms:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Federal Police investigations into the recent spate of thefts--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you incorporate it? He's not in the chamber.
—I do not mind. I am happy to incorporate it, Mr President, if you feel that that is consonant with the dignity of this chamber. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at Question Time Senator Missen asked me about the role of Professor Ovington in the context of a visit to Japan concerning the death of some koalas which had been exported. Professor Ovington visited Japan from 5 to 16 November 1985. During that visit he attended the third consultative meeting regarding the agreement between the Government of Japan and the Government of Australia for the protection of migratory birds and birds in danger of extinction in their environment; met with the Japanese Commission into the International Whaling Commission; and, with regard to koalas, visited six zoos that had received or hoped to receive koalas, checked on the health of surviving koalas, inspected eucalypt plantations and greenhouse facilities to ensure that there was a supply of eucalypt leaves in winter and had meetings with zoo officials and veterinarians to discuss possible causes of the death of the koalas and any measures necessary to give greater protection to the koalas should the current ban on exporting koalas be lifted. The Minister has arranged to make available to Senator Missen a copy of the reports to him by Professor Ovington and I understand that he would be pleased to supply copies of those reports to other interested senators.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard Mr Kerin's written response to the question asked earlier by Senator Sanders.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The Government and the public generally have been aware for some time that certain roading and forestry operations would be conducted in the Upper Picton region. The State Government's intentions were made quite clear in this respect with the publishing of a management plan in 1983. The values for which the Picton Valley has been registered by the Australian Heritage Commission can be summarised as old growth forest habitat, Mount Picton alpine area and the view field for the Hartz Mountain National Park. The Government is, however, aware that the general region has an importance to the wilderness values of the neighbouring south-west national park. Accordingly, in its 16 December announcement it indicated it would be acting to ensure that areas in the Upper Picton and Farmhouse Creek catchments would be excluded from the export licences with the aim of providing a substantial buffer zone to protect the wilderness values of the south west. The Government will be acting to honour this commitment. I am advised that operations planned and being undertaken in the normal management process by the State Forestry Commission do not compromise the proposed arrangements.

In respect of the Lemonthyme to which Senator Sanders has attributed wilderness value, I am advised this is not specifically a registered value for this area but it is a wilderness buffer or remoting zone. Senator Sanders will be aware that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission in 1983 published a management plan which took into account the then established values of the Lemonthyme, namely that it is the view field of the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park. The Forestry Commission plan provides for management of logging operations so as to minimise any compromise to the visual amenity of the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair area.
The Government does not propose to limit logging in the area beyond those limits already proposed in the Tasmanian Forestry Commission's 1983 management plan.

These areas are two parts of some 37 National Estate areas considered by the Government in its decision of 16 December. Consistent with the decision and the documents that were circulated publicly by the Minister for Primary Industry, there are a large number of areas where management planning for the period has not been completed. The Commonwealth will be ensuring that its views will be taken into account in respect of any operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In speaking to the Aboriginal Development Commission report 1984-85 I note the remarks of the Chairman, Mrs Shirley McPherson, and the Administrator, Mr Rob Winroe, regarding the Commission. They say that the Aboriginal Development Commission has reached a milestone in its evolution in that on 30 June 1985 it completed five years of operation. In looking back over that five years of operation, I believe that the Chairman and the Administrator are to be commended for having brought the Aboriginal Development Commission to where it is today. It has been a difficult five years and they have been troubled in various ways, but I believe that with the growth of the Commission, their experience has brought it to where it is today.

It was interesting to note that during the year the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure reviewed the Aboriginal Development Commission and put under very close scrutiny its financial control, administration and so on. Many criticisms were made of the organisation, but I believe that the work that the Chairman, the Board and the Administrator have carried out has overcome many of the criticisms. The Commission is now in a position to continue its work. The ADC annual report states:
Patterns have been shaped during this period which have enabled management to build on strengths and devise strategies to improve the overall efficiency of the Commission.

I would now like to refer to the transfer of functions from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to the Commission. I understand that the Expenditure Committee recommended that there should be a review. The main functional responsibilities of the ADC task force in respect of the transfer from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to the ADC were to assess the components of community management and services and social support functions which should be transferred from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to the ADC; to develop a plan to facilitate the transfer of functions and resources; to assess the numbers and levels of manpower resources and so on; and to examine the feasibility of the co-location of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the ADC. A report was given to the Chairman of the Commission in January 1985.

Also it was suggested that there should be a transfer of housing-related functions. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure recommended that the Commission should take over from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs responsibility for the very many services provided by the Department. The Department and the Commission agreed that the first stage in the transfer of housing-related functions to the Commission was to take effect from 1 July 1985. I would be very interested to hear from the Government what actually has happened in the intervening period. I believe that there has been too much overlapping between Commonwealth departments, State departments and various Aboriginal authorities in respect of Aboriginal administration which has resulted in money not being controlled very well and being ill spent. The document read as follows-
PRESS RELEASE FROM SENATOR BERN KILGARIFF
Aboriginal Assistance Programmes must be
Co-ordinated

Senator Bern Kilgariff said, in Canberra, today, that he is concerned that programmes designed to assist Aboriginals may not be achieving their full potential because of the duplication of some elements of assistance by various government departments and statutory authorities.

`We have, not only the Federal Department of Aboriginal Affairs, but several State departments of a similar nature, in addition to Aboriginal organisations such as the Aboriginal Development Commission implementing projects for Aboriginal people.
`Until a few months ago we also had the NAC to contend with. But that organisation has since been disbanded, as a result of its financial mismanagement.
`My concerns in this matter are twofold.

`Firstly, I am well aware of a desperate need within Aboriginal communities for improvements in standards of health, housing and education, but I am not convinced that with this multiplicity of departments and organisations, many of them top heavy with administrators and bureaucrats, the funds set aside for Aboriginal programmes are finding their way to those most in need.

This annual report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is for 1984-85 and as things have moved rather quickly in this area there have been a number of developments since then. The report sets out the record of the Authority's substantial achievements. Last year I had the opportunity of visiting the Great Barrier Reef for a couple of days in connection with the crown of thorns starfish problem and I must say that the co-operation and obvious enthusiasm of the leaders and staff of the Authority were very impressive. There are two or three matters in the report to which I wish to refer. They are dealt with briefly in the report and I regret this because they are important matters. To some extent I think that the difficulties have been put aside and I regret that. Under the heading of `Research and Monitoring' there are three matters with which I wish to deal: The crown of thorns starfish, the Hydrographer's Passage survey and the stranding of the TNT vessel Alltrans and also the Cape Tribulation monitoring program. These are all important matters which have increased in importance in many direct ways since the report was prepared. In relation to the crown of thorns starfish, this problem goes much further than the report shows. At that stage the Crown of Thorns Starfish Advisory Committee had reported that:
the destruction of hard coral by aggregations of A. planci--
that is, the crown of thorns starfish--
poses a serious threat to the organisation and functional relationships within some reef communities within the Great Barrier Reef, at least in the short term.

However, the Committee noted that scientific evidence was inadequate to assess the nature and significance of the phenomenon. Since that time we have passed a resolution in the Senate calling for an inquiry and moreover in the House of Representatives a report was tabled in November on the protection of the Great Barrier Reef. This report was prepared by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. It called for urgent action by the Government to deal with its various recommendations which were supportive of the Authority but which showed that the position was quite serious and that there was an evident need for money and further research.

The second matter relates to the Hydro- grapher's Passage survey. Since this report was written dangers have been caused by shipping in this area. These ships were unpiloted. I have raised this matter on several occasions in the Senate, but neither the Press nor the people of this country seem to show any concern about the enormous damage that may be done if a ship loses its cargo in this area. In fact, the report's reference to the standing of the TNT Alltrans-and the report only covers the period to June 1985-shows that a considerable amount of the coral in the area and surrounding colonies was destroyed. It appears to have been killed by siltation. Since that time there have been other accidents and unfortunately the Government has shown itself very little concerned with this problem. I regret that very much.

The third matter to which I wish to refer is the Cape Tribulation monitoring program. The problem here is siltation from the road at Daintree and this is a matter which has also been considered by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. It is a problem which concerns the people of Australia because it has caused the destruction of some parts of the reef near the shore. I believe that these matters will be dealt with in more detail in the next report of the Committee but I hope that in the meantime the Government and the Authority will act with great expedition in seeing that the monitoring is done so that permanent damage will not be done to the reef.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a beautiful report; it is very well done and it has beautiful pictures in it. However, 60 reefs lie in the region between the northern boundary of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and the Torres Strait Treaty area. SPEECH.PARA: There is another problem which is affecting the entire reef and which has not received much public attention. That is the Ok Tedi mine in Papua New Guinea. Once the Ok Tedi mine begins operating it is probable that heavy metals such as copper, zinc, lead and cadmium will be carried into the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Sediments from the mine have already been detected in the park. As the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation noted in November 1985, there is no monitoring program in place and there is an urgent need for the Australian Government, in consultation with the Papua New Guinea Government, to carry out an assessment of the impact of the Ok Tedi mine.

One of the most horrific threats is a seven-storey floating hotel called the Reef Link Resort which will be moored above John Brewer Reef, some 76 kilometres off Townsville. Procedures for the assessment of such proposals have now been developed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be dead before then.

In this case that means closing the road and restoring the vegetation, not regular monitoring of the reef's destruction through sedimentary run-off.
