DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION BILL 1985HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1985HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985AUSTRALIAN BILL OF RIGHTS BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was speaking in general on the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985. Of course, since that time there has been both a Cabinet and a Caucus meeting to discuss this Bill. However, it is still somewhat difficult to find out precisely what the situation will be. Today I had intended to refer to that part of the Bill dealing with the two-stage process. I will certainly continue with that intention. It seems to me to be relevant because, from what I understand of the decision of the Government, it refers to making use of that part of the process.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically the Government's two-step approach in this Bill runs as follows: A State law which breaches the Bill of Rights may be investigated by the proposed Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, provided it obtains the Attorney-General's permission. The Commission then makes its recommendations. If those recommendations are adverse, the Attorney- General may bring to the Parliament legislation which then, of course, may or may not be passed. There are so many ifs and buts in this particular exercise as to make the likelihood of any Federal government's overriding any State law extremely small.

Given the facts of Federation in Australia, we have a State election almost every year, sometimes two or three times a year. Fairly regularly in the last 10 years we have had a Federal election almost every two years. The circumstances surrounding elections have, as we have seen, influenced Federal government policy decisions mightily. If there were to be an inquiry this year with regard, for example, to the Queensland electoral laws, undoubtedly the Human Rights Commission would require more than six months to complete its report. In fact, the current Commission indicated to the Australian Democrats Queensland division that it would take longer than six months to complete an inquiry because of the nature of the matter to be inquired into. Therefore, we would be facing some legislation around October, possibly November, this year. Of course, a Queensland State election will be held in December this year. Therefore, such an inquiry would not be on. We would then have to look at next year. However, next year would not be on because next year is a Federal election year. Everyone knows that if any legislation were introduced it would be challenged in the courts of this land. I am quite sure that the case would still be running, with the help of the skilled barristers employed, in December 1987, when, of course a Federal election will be held. We all know that there will be no exercise of Federal powers arising out of these reports. That is a settled view which, if overturned, would amaze everybody in the country.

One could add that if a head of power exists under which the Commonwealth Government can act, it can act regardless of whether the Bill of Rights is passed. The Bill of itself cannot give to the Government any additional head of power that it does not currently have. There is no point in saying that we have to have the Bill of Rights and we have to go through this elaborate mechanism if the power already resides in the Federal Parliament to do anything that is proposed and such actions could be taken now.

There are other types of problems with the two-stage approach. First of all, a State government could persuade an Attorney-General, probably from the same political party, not to allow a Commission inquiry. That is possible. There could be some discussion and the Attorney-General could decide not to go ahead with giving a reference to the Commission. Secondly, the Commission could simply not exercise its right to inquire into a State law. Thirdly, the State government could persuade the Federal government not to undertake any overriding legislation. Fourthly, the Attorney-General of the government of the day might decide that the political risks were just too great to go down that track and, hence, would not bother. Looking at the current situation one can see how some of those could easily apply.

Another very serious point is this: A piece of legislation seeking to implement selectively the Bill of Rights could become a political device that could be used in a number of ways. I certainly wonder about the type of legal advice that may be given to the Government on this matter, because the type of legal advice that has been given to me is that, if the Government sought a selective implementation of the Bill of Rights, it would make more difficult the constitutional task of having it upheld in the High Court. The reasons are fairly obvious, even to the lay person.

Firstly, if there is selective implementation there could be a very strong argument for suggesting that it is selective in the sense of its applying to one State only which, of course, runs against the whole tenor of our Constitution. Secondly, in those circumstances the selective implementation of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights raises questions as to why other parts of the Covenant were not implemented. It raises the possible question of a political operation rather than the constitutional fulfilment of the requirements involved in signing an international covenant. One would never find out whether those types of arguments were valid until they were taken to the High Court but they certainly worry me a great deal. I believe that in any implementation of our international obligations the spirit of the Constitution requires that those international obligations be fulfilled in a general way affecting all States by implementing all parts of the international covenant.

Another problem is that governments change. If we merely leave it to governments to decide whether certain Articles apply, we will have a selective implementation of the Covenant over time, depending on the political composition of the government of the day. That seems to me to be hardly the type of thing we talked about when we first went into this debate so many years ago. In fact, we were talking about a general principle and a general right of citizens whereby, if they were offended or if their human rights were offended by governments or government instrumentalities, they could have some recourse, instead of being abused, instead of having their pensions denied and having nowhere to go. I remember discussing these matters in various meetings a long time ago-it seems many many years ago now. At that stage we were talking about the need to allow citizens to assert their basic human rights, no matter what the bureaucrats or governments say. We have come a long way since then. Unfortunately, the Bill we have before us is very weak in that regard. It will certainly apply to Federal laws. As I said yesterday, it seems to me to be a farce to say to a person: `We are going to protect you from being enslaved by any Federal law; however, if you are enslaved by a State law, that is your problem not ours'. The absurdity of that position is demonstrated by that example. A person can be enslaved only once. Indeed, once so many of these rights are taken away by a State government, they are effectively taken away forever; they cannot be taken away a second time. For example, if a person is denied the right to a free trial under State law, that right need be taken away only once and that person could suffer imprisonment as a result. I believe that if this Bill is not amended to apply to all jurisdictions in Australia, it is best that it be defeated because to have it on the books would be a sham and hypocrisy. It would be better to go on fighting for a genuine Bill of Rights in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it four Bills which it is debating cognately. The centrepiece is the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985, clause 8 of which contains 32 articles relating to human rights. A co-partner in this legislative package is the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill 1985, a Bill seeking to widen very greatly the powers of the existing Human Rights Commission. The proposed Bill of Rights has aroused enormous controversy throughout the community. That controversy was spread across the community to all types of people and all ranges of professions. It has been very heavily criticised by the legal profession. Indeed, the Law Council of Australia, representing more than 20,000 lawyers, has expressed very strong criticism and the gravest doubts about the Bill's constitutionality. Others have expressed similar strong criticisms and reservations about the Bill, including church groups and individuals. Honourable senators will have received many hundreds, even thousands, of letters from people who are gravely concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Against this background there are at least five key questions to be asked. The first question is: Is there a need in Australia for a written Bill of Rights? The second question is: If so, is that need satisfied by a piece of legislation which can be changed at any time or must such a change be entrenched in a referendum? The third question is: Is this Bill adequate and effective or is it defective in its compartments? The fourth question is: Is the head of power from which the Bill is derived-that is, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights-the appropriate head of power from which to draft a Bill? Finally, the fifth question is: How does it affect the States?

To answer these questions, the first thing one needs to understand is the nature of Australian society. Since 1901, Australia has had a fixed or written Constitution that the five subscribing States gave to the Commonwealth with all residual power residing in the States. It was understood then by the founding fathers that there would be a fixed ceiling upon the powers of the Commonwealth so that they could be contained. The founding fathers never realised that the probing of lawyers and courts of law would be such as to find breaches in the ceilings of those powers and that powers would be used by the Commonwealth that were never agreed to in 1901.

The second point is that one must take into consideration the International Covenant under which the head of power in the Bill is derived. To understand that we must look at the Commonwealth Constitution. Section 51 states, in part:
The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth, with respect to . . .

I turn to placitum (xxix) of section 51, which contains two words, `External affairs'. So the Commonwealth Parliament may make laws in relation to external affairs. I put it to the Senate that the founding fathers never envisaged that the external affairs power would extend to the making of treaties internationally or bilaterally with other nations, or that the terms of those treaties would be regarded as entrenching constitutional powers on which the Commonwealth could act. In other words, it is possible, of course, to make a wide range of treaties which would allow the Commonwealth to infiltrate through to State and local government to an extent which is well beyond its powers. That is precisely what has happened. Several years ago, in a bare majority decision of four to three, the High Court upheld the treaty-making power and as a result a new frontier of power has been achieved.

In Australia this fixed ceiling is now being breached. In the United Kingdom it was not deemed to be necessary to have a written constitution. The effect is that, although the sky is the limit, the lawmakers there are very careful to probe only in a very low stratum, whereas in Australia the socialists try to breach the ceiling and go as high as possible. That, of course, puts an enormous strain on the system of federalism, as does this Bill. One must look at the whole nature of the Bill to find out the profound effect that it has. If future Commonwealth parliaments are to use treaty powers it is not an exaggeration to say that federation as we know it today will have been destroyed. If one had wanted to create a Bill of Rights within the federation the logical thing would have been to look at the precious rights and get Federal-State agreement, not necessarily by referendum, but by ordinary agreement around the conference table. We could have had an understanding and a consensus on this matter. But that has not happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be much more flexible that way.
—Indeed, a flexible approach. That has not happened and now we are facing a very serious situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the head of power-the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It is a covenant which a series of Liberal governments in the past, particularly the Menzies Government, fought to have established on the international scene. It is a covenant that was signed in our time and it is one that we upheld. But it is not good enough to say simply that we will use it to define an instrument for Australia. One must understand that that covenant was formulated by 106 members of the United Nations, the great majority of those nations being ones that were not democracies but which were socialist or communist in their nature. The great majority of those nations had none or few of the freedoms that we share today. The aim of that covenant was to write down some basic elemental freedoms so that those non-democratic countries could be encouraged towards implementing a greater degree of freedom. Of course, such matters as freedom against slavery were written in. But it is fundamental to the understanding of the covenant that it was a hard fought compromise. Socialist and communist countries resisted the inclusion in the covenant of many vital rights and freedoms. The covenant would not have been agreed to if one of the most fundamental rights in democracy, the right to private property, had been included. The Russians and other socialists indicated that they would have no part of a covenant that included that right. So this covenant was very defective in terms of the rights of democracies. We conceded it in order that the freedoms of others might be advanced to a minor frontier. But it is one which we never dreamed would be used in seeking to draw our rights.

The first and great error of this Government is that it has used that head of power, which in itself is an extraordinarily narrow head, and has introduced a Bill which, by its very narrowness in listing rights, has excluded many of the precious rights and, in so doing, has caused great hardship and has made a great error. What is more, the Bill is gravely defective because the Government has sought that head of power but has not included the same sort of qualifications that are included in the covenant. The Law Council of Australia, in particular, has said that it believes that the Bill is gravely unconstitutional. It is even more critical when it says:
The Bill is expressed in terms which are declamatory and imprecise.

Fancy a government bringing in a measure that the Law Council of Australia, representing all the lawyers of Australia, condemns in those words! So we come to the basic defect of the Bill. It could never purport to be a Bill that would enshrine the rights and freedoms that Australia understands. At its best it could only try to encompass narrowly those freedoms that socialist and communist governments would allow to be included in a corral. So, of course, it leaves out basic, fundamental ones.

Many honourable senators have drawn attention to the fact that this Bill makes no mention of the right to hold private property. That, of course, as I say, was completely refused. It does not make any mention of the freedom to engage in lawful trade, professions or occupations. What kind of a Bill does not even entrench the basic principles? Mention has been made that it does not include the freedom of parents to send their children to non-government schools. Mention has been made, again, that it does not give an essential freedom-that is, the right not to join an association. Of course, many people in this community are gravely concerned because there is no mention of the protection of the unborn child. So, at the very most, what we have is a narrow and imprisoned Bill, built upon socialist and communist compromises of the past. It would be good for those countries but not for us.

If we look at the Bill we must ask ourselves this first question: Do we need such a Bill? In Australia it has been said by many that if our parliamentary institutions, our judicial institutions and our social institutions are active and vigorous they will enshrine human rights and there is no need for such a Bill. But one must understand this fundamental point: There are many countries around the world that have human rights Bills and those Bills have no effect on conferring rights on human beings. After all, the Soviet Union and its satellites have such Bills. The inclusion of something in legislation does nothing to create freedom. Freedom is a state of the human mind and spirit; it is the state of the willingness of a parliamentary chamber to preserve rights; it is the state of the judicial mind to preserve and entrench rights; it is the state of the value judgments of society at any time. Obviously we do not need this Bill because it simply identifies and fossilises a few rights and ignores others. By ignoring others it does a very dangerous thing because it can convey the illusion that the others do not matter. If they mattered, why would they not be put in this Bill? There should have been consultation between the Commonwealth and the States on this matter. So certainly the answer is that there is no need for such a Bill. It is not just that it is not necessary but by the very elements that I have mentioned, it is an extremely dangerous piece of legislation as it delimits. It delimits because it fossilises and excludes.

Let us have a look at the second point I raised. Is legislation an effective thing? How can it be? It can be changed at will. All that has to happen is that a new majority government can alter it. We do not have anything entrenched at all. We have something that is changeable and that can be altered at the whim of future governments. Clearly, if there were to be a written instrument it would have to be by way of referendum. But strangely enough the Government has run away from any such thing at all and has looked to a narrow and imperfect instrument to enshrine it. The next question is: Is the head of power effective? Quite clearly, whether it is or not, the fact that the Government has drawn a Bill that is wider than the head of power leads to the clear assumption that the Bill itself will be unconstitutional. It will be a lawyers' feast because it will raise point after point of unconstitutionality. What use is such a Bill?

How does it affect the States? The Australian Democrats have suggested that it does not affect the States at all. That is not so. It is possible for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to investigate a piece of legislation or an instrumentality of a State or local government body if the Minister agrees. Clause 27 (2) of the Bill of Rights states:
The Commission shall not commence to-
(a) inquire into an act done or practice engaged in by or on behalf of a state or an authority of a State; or
(b) examine a State enactment,

unless the Minister has, after taking into account such matters as the Minister in his or her discretion considers appropriate, consented to the holding of the inquiry or the making of the examination.
If it is felt that that, in itself, is a delimiting thing one should look to what the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said in a speech last year in Melbourne. He stated:

The fact that the Bill of Rights will not override of its own force inconsistent State laws does not mean that the Commonwealth will fail to act where the Commission recommends legislative change by the States and they fail to do so.

I have just quoted clause 27 of the Bill and the statement made by the Attorney-General. This Bill will reach right into the heart of State and local government Acts and regulations and to the actions of authorities of the State and local government. It will bring the force of this Bill to bear on them. That is, indeed, a treat in itself to federalism. The Bill is, in fact, a selective package of 32 articles; it excludes many and it can give no guarantees at all because it is subject to a future majority in Parliament. Fundamentally, what must be understood is that it overrides laws that have been passed before and will be passed after the enactment of the Bill. It is complicated in this regard. This Bill is not just prospective, it is totally retrospective in both Commonwealth and State laws. It has the capacity to look at all of the legislation that is being passed by the Commonwealth and States; it has the capacity to get a ruling that, in fact, there is an infringement and then, after a delay, for the legislation to be repealed. It gives-this is perhaps its gravest defect-to the courts decision-making powers which are political powers and not judicial powers. Perhaps of all the criticisms that can be made that is the biggest criticism. The Law Council of Australia has been highly critical in this regard. It stated:
S 14, is an ill-considered provision which will thrust the judges into the field of political and policy debate.

That is a very serious situation because we do not want the judiciary to make laws. The Supreme Court of America has a history of defective actions in this regard where courts can make and unmake laws by attitudinal arrangements. That in itself is very bad indeed. This Bill politicises the judiciary and it is extraordinarily full of conflicts. If honourable senators pick up any one of the Articles they can ask: `How long will it be before the lawyers simply go to town on this situation?' What do they mean? For example, Article 1 states:
Every person is entitled to equality before the law and to human rights . . .

But everybody knows that there are qualifications right throughout the community and powers given to governments and others which make people's rights quite different, one from the other. The problem is seen very clearly in Article 3, which states:
The rights and freedoms set out in this Bill of Rights are subject only to such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society.

I ask honourable senators: What can that possibly mean in a court of law? Here we are again asking the judges to decide. I turn now to Article 6, which is headed `Right of participation in public life'. It provides that every Australian citizen has the right and shall have the opportunity to vote. There is no qualification as to age. There is no qualification at all. The Law Council of Australia has queried this matter amongst many others.

Many misstatements have been made in the Senate about the powers under this Bill and there has been talk of the need to write one vote one value into a Bill of Rights. Those who use that phrase fail to understand that simply entrenching one vote one value will not stop a gerrymander. The Commonwealth Electoral Commissioner is on record as pointing out that malapportionment in itself is not simply restrained by one vote one value. He or she who holds the geographic pen that draws the boundaries can decide malapportionment and gerrymander even if there is one vote one value.

I draw attention to the vivid imaginations of the Cahill Labor Government of the past in New South Wales, architects of supreme gerrymander, architects of drawing boundaries of electorates. A member of the electorate had to go outside his electorate into another to come back into his own because it suited the arrangement of the vote. I draw attention to the former State seat of Goulburn not far from Canberra. There were not sufficient Labor votes; so a seat was run down to Captain's Flat to take in the mining area of Captain's Flat to entrench a malapportionment and a gerrymander. There could have been one vote one value. I draw attention to the vivid imaginations of the Labor governments of Western Australia and Queensland of the past, the real architects of gerrymander. This of course is the height of nonsense.
I am very glad to read that Article 8 states:
Every person has the right to freedom of thought . . .

Is that not a wonderful piece of dogma to entrench-the right to freedom of thought and conscience? What kind of doubletalk is this? This is KGB nonsense-that one cannot even feel free to think or to have a conscience because big brother will know. So it goes on. It is a document which is imperfect in every way. I wonder what Article 17 means and what Mr Trimbole would think of it, because it states:
Every person has the right to leave Australia.
What kind of qualifications, what kind of a lawyers fight is going on here?

I turn to the document of the Law Council of Australia and look at it page by page. It is a complete condemnation of this Bill. It does not decide whether or not there ought to be a Bill of Rights, but in 35 critical paragraphs on 16 pages it refers to this Bill of Rights. When it comes to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Law Council is scathing. It says: `Here is a Bill which entrenches a complete onslaught against freedoms'. I quote:
. . . the Law Council cannot support legislation which permits, as this legislation does, one body to act as both prosecutor and judge in the same cause.
The Council is concerned rather that the granting of such powers to an unrepresentative and non-judicial body creates the potential for abuse.
The Council believes that the ability of a person to know and to properly answer the complaint against him is very severely circumscribed by the Bill in its present form.
The privilege against self-incrimination has been removed, a step which would appear to be at odds with the whole notion of a Bill of Rights.
A further concern relates to compulsory conferences. Clause 34 provides that they should be held in private and that those who are required to attend have no right to legal representation.

Natural justice requires that any person called before the Commission ought to be entitled to be legally represented if he so desires. Nor should the Commission be capable of conducting its investigations into a complaint in secret.

That is a series of criticisms of this measure. This measure creates an impossibility in that it looks back to every Act that has been passed in Australia and allows a Commission with ministerial approval to walk into the State and local governments and to bring down reports upon what is happening there. The Minister has indicated quite clearly that if defects were found there, the Commonwealth would act. This is a fundamental threat to the system of Federation. This Bill says `If you bring in new laws, you can escape this by making a statement in ``express words of plain intendment'' ' which virtually excludes the effect of the Bill. If a Bill should come up by way of suggested repeal through a judicial decision, one can then rewrite it in the three months one has so that there are express words of plain intendment. Fundamentally we are putting into the hands of the judiciary powers which the judiciary itself would not want. That is absolutely wrong. We are also putting into the hands of the Minister powers that we have never considered. The Law Council says:

Clause 27 (2) is objectionable precisely because it confers an arbitrary power upon the Minister. The Minister may at his or her discretion grant or withhold consent to the Commission for the holding of an inquiry into State laws, acts or practices. There is no obvious limitation to the exercise of that discretion and the potential exists, therefore, for that discretion to be exercised according to political motives. Any capacity for arbitrary or discretionary power of governments to act in this way should be removed.

I cannot recall a more damning or critical document than the one from which I have quoted. The document says that this Bill is almost certainly unconstitutional and that this Bill is wrong because it is arbitrary and is likely to be subject to endless litigation. I would not support such a piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and associated Bills. It is not the first time that I have opposed such legislation; I recall doing so when it was introduced originally by the previous Government. I believe that this legislation establishes some problems for our democratic system in this country and this Bill certainly goes further than the original intention of the previous Government. It seems to me to have excited incredible interest in the Senate, because 35 or 36 senators have already taken part in the debate. One would almost think that it is designed to generate a vendetta against the Queensland electoral system. Senator Sir John Carrick pointed to the gerrymanders that have occurred in Australia under Australian Labor Party administrations. I thought that it was fitting to do some research on this matter in relation to Queensland, because one of the purposes of this Bill is to intrude into the electoral systems of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: In considering the merits or demerits of electoral boundaries it is necessary to distinguish between the representation of individual electors and the representation of political parties. Thus it is possible to have a situation in which electoral districts vary widely in enrolments, yet the major political parties win seats proportionately to the share of the votes that are cast for them. It is possible to have a situation in which, although the electoral districts are roughly equal in enrolments, one party has a considerable advantage over its competitors in converting votes into seats in this Parliament. I notice that the Australian Democrats have joined in the attack, particularly on Queensland--

TALK.START.PARA: —With reason and justice.

—I would imagine that the Australian Democrats ought to be thankful for the two-party preferential system because in 1984 throughout Australia they got 7.6 per cent of the vote. They have seven senators here and I suggest that they are over-represented by two, because if we are to be fair about electoral representation for this splinter group-which is more aligned with the tomato red left section of the Labor Party, in my opinion-it should attract 9.2 per cent of the vote. I think that they are phoneys and it is absolutely incredible that they cannot demonstrate any knowledge of electoral matters in this place. Senator Haines stood up here like a schoolteacher lecturing us on electoral matters. She does not realise that if the present system were abolished the Australian Democrats would have far fewer people representing them in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the criticism with respect to the Queensland redistribution has been based on the first preference voting figures. However, the preferential voting in single representative electorates is the accepted method of voting in most of Australia. If we look at the two-party preferred figures, there is no doubt that the coalition won government fairly in Queensland from 1960 to 1977, and in the elections since that date.

The charge of gerrymander had been levelled long before the coalition split. The only real cases of gerrymander in Queensland were those exercised by the Labor Party in the 1947 and 1950 elections. In 1947, for example, the coalition won 45.2 per cent of the vote but gained only 23 seats whereas Labor won 43.6 per cent of the vote to gain 35 seats. In 1950-I think Senator Sir John Carrick alluded to this but did not spell it out; it might be interesting to do so-the coalition won 49.2 per cent of the vote while Labor gained 46.9 per cent. In that election Labor won 42 seats to the coalition's 31 seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —So much for a gerrymander.

—That is the sort of gerrymander that applied in those days. Dr Colin Hughes of the Australian National University, who could not by any stretch of the imagination be regarded as a raving right wing conservative, wrote in 1980 a book entitled The Government of Queensland. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Once again it is obvious that each redistribution favoured the government of the day, and that the Hanlon and Nicklin distributions were about on a par for the degree of bias induced, although the last election on the Nicklin boundaries were conspicuously fairer-that is, less biased-than the rest. But the Bjelke-Petersen boundaries, which had appeared so suspect--
so Dr Colin Hughes says--
now appear to have given the Government significantly less of an advantage than earlier redistributions.

Of course, Dr Colin Hughes has not had the opportunity to comment on the new Queensland redistribution, nor will he until after another election takes place. It is suggested that Senator Haines and other critics are talking through their hats when they criticise the Premier, whose redistributions, according to Dr Hughes, have to date been the fairest in Queensland's history. We could argue about that matter indefinitely.

My former colleague and a very eminent politician in South Australia, the Honourable Ren de Garis, who has done copious analysis of electoral systems and performances and certainly knows a lot more about this subject than does Senator Haines, has demonstrated that currently the Liberal Party in South Australia cannot gain government unless it gets over 52 per cent of the vote. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I have been a member of this Parliament since about 1966. I believe that the legislation before the House has caused more concern and has led to more correspondence coming into my office than has any other Bill for a considerable number of years.
—It is because of the hate campaign that has been stirred up.

—It is interesting that people seem to be writing to Liberal and National Party senators. We suggest that there is no need to write to us at all, because members of the seventh part of the Australian Labor Party-the Australian Democrats-are the ones who have the answer to this problem. They are trying to codify matters relating to human rights which are already enshrined in our common law and which give us adequate protection. I believe that the common law--
—What about Tasmania? We are not adequately protected there.

—Tasmania is adequately protected while the honourable senator is here and not in Tasmania! That is the best thing we can say about the representation of Senator Sanders. I am appalled at the things he says on occasions. However, I will just put that aside. The people of Australia are trying to arouse the attention of the Australian Democrats to the problems that they perceive in this inflexible piece of tripe that the Government is obviously going to pass with the support of the Australian Democrats. I think Senator Macklin said that he had had thousands of representations. The other day Senator Bjelke-Petersen said that she had had 1,700. I do not know how many I have had but it must be hundreds. Certainly I have had collective representations from many organisations which do not come from one political group. Those organisations include the Presbyterian Church of Eastern Australia, the Christian Pro-Family Forum, the Riverland Churches of Christ, the Country Women's Association of Western Australia, the Festival of Light and the Right to Life Association. All of these bodies have a very strong view.
—The Democrats abuse them.

—Yes, of course. I should not repeat what Senator Haines said in this respect because I note that she has just taken the chair. However, I think she used the phrase `Chicken Littles in the community'. I am just wondering what that means. To me it sounds a disparaging comment. I think in retrospect she might be sorry that she said that.
—Even the DOGS are opposed to it.

—Even the DOGS are opposed to it. I think the cats and probably the sheep are too! The organisations from which we have received representations also include the Council for Defence of Government Schools-DOGS-and the Victorian Protestant Federation. Hundreds and hundreds-I guess even thousands-of ordinary citizens of very widely differing backgrounds have demonstrated their serious concern about matters relating to the Bill we are debating at present.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this massive concern has arisen despite what seems to me to be almost a conspiracy of silence between the Government and the media. I think I saw two very good articles in the Australian newspaper which provided some sort of public exposure. However, the Press reporting has been less than adequate. I contacted the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in South Australia and provided it with some background information hoping that people would be given the opportunity to participate and give their views on the Bill that we are discussing. Philip Satchell is a very astute journalist who generally tends to provide the opportunity for public debate on matters such as the one we are discussing. However, his producer told me that although he has had many inquiries about this matter space has not been given to encourage the important public debate that should be attributed a Bill of this character. As Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned, it would be a different matter if some sort of consensus or flexibility had been written into the Constitution when it was being drafted. This legislation has been introduced to change government regulations by way of government decree. The other way in which we can introduce such a measure is by putting such constitutional change to a referendum. I am quite sure that a referendum held on this Bill would be soundly rejected. However, I think the Government and its supporters-its cohorts, the surrogate Australian Democrats-are guilty of surreptitiously, subversively and in great haste foisting upon the Australian people a set of Bills that would be opposed by the majority-there is no question about this-of the Australian people. I will refer to the attitude of the Democrats to this Bill and other matters later.
The people of Australia have every right to fear this Bill, which is aimed at destroying the federal system that is established in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good idea.

—That is exactly why the people of Australia ought to condemn the Australian Democrats. `That would be a great idea', says this light of knowledge from Tasmania. He says that it would be a great idea to destroy our federal system. I bet that the people of Tasmania, being as independently minded as they are, would tear the honourable senator to shreds if he was recorded in the Press as saying that.
—But the media will not write that up.

—I hope the media will because it is the purpose of this Government; it wants to destroy the federal system. It wants to put in its place a republican system. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would love to be the first President of Australia and I am sure that our friend the expatriate American would like to be one of the Vice-Presidents. That might be a good position to give him. I am sure that the introduction of this legislation has been done in a very sneaky, snide way. The question of having any real public debate has never entered the mind of the Government because it knows that that would cause tremendous antagonism in the electorate, but it is doing that anyway. Probably, the best thing it could have done would have been to refer the matter to one of our Senate committees. That may have given the opportunity to encourage a far greater exposure of this legislation to the electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill grants no rights, certainly none that cannot be withdrawn by the government of the day. Only in the past fortnight have I seen some of the rights that can be denied to Australians under the Labor socialist Government. In Australia, we find ourselves in a position in which the present Government has allowed officers of some self-professed terrorist organisations to become established in this country. I have alluded to that before. These organisations have no diplomatic status, but their rights are okay.

I was disturbed to see the other day that Rotary International was denied the opportunity to bring some exchange students to Australia. Because these students came from South Africa the Government of New South Wales said: `No, you cannot have those people here. We do not want to hear any thing about the truth as these students see it in South Africa'. They may have been able to tell the Rotary people how they think that the South African Government can overcome its problems. It is a learning system, and having Australian students going to other countries and other students coming here is one way in which the Rotary Club quite properly provides a community service. It is one of its four cardinal objectives. Rotary's four-way test asks: Is it the truth? Is it fair to all concerned? Will it build goodwill and better friendships? Will it be beneficial to all concerned? This Bill states something about the freedom of association, the freedom of Australians to associate in the way that I have described, but that is certainly not permitted unless the Government agrees with the people with whom the Australians want to associate. I think that is a dictatorial and absolutely unpardonable attitude for any government to take. I would like to extend that debate on another occasion.

The Bill clearly demonstrates to me, to this side of the Senate, and to the majority of the people of Australia that the Government and its collaborators, the Australian Democrats, have no commitment either to democracy or to people's rights. The people of Australia have been denied a say, denied even the information on which to make judgments on these nefarious Bills. Nonetheless, many of them know that this Bill is dangerous, divisive and undemocratic. It is my belief that we do not need the Bill of Rights. We have rights firmly established in our Constitution and in our system of common law. If laws are shown to be discriminating against any particular sector or individual, they can be quite easily corrected.

I thought Senator Missen made a very thoughtful speech earlier in the debate. He properly questioned whether this measure was in fact constitutional. Senator Sir John Carrick also drew attention to the concern expressed by the Law Council of Australia, which made the same comment. I believe that it is quite correct, although I do not have a legal background. Article 11, which I have mentioned, states:
Every person has the right to freedom of association with others, including the right to join trade unions for the protection of that person's interests.

We know that some people have been denied that freedom of association, and I have referred to the Rotarians in that context. I would also like to refer to the fact that some people may wish, through conscientious objection or for other reasons, not to join a trade union. I am not opposed to trade unions; I was a trade unionist myself because I thought that it was very important for me to exert some influence over the left wing leadership of the particular union to which I belonged. Some people prefer for one reason or another, including conscientious objection, not to join. There is no question of that in this Bill. That is a serious omission.

Another serious omission, as previous speakers have referred to during this debate, is the right to own property or to use property to earn a living. The Government, which fully understands the powers which this Bill confers on the central government, tends to allay the people's fears by deprecating these powers in public statements about the Bill. Recently, in the House of Representatives, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) stated in a speech:

. . . the enactment of a Bill of Rights has a vital educative function. It has the capacity to inspire respect for fundamental freedoms and liberties by setting out rights in positive, declaratory form . . . Alternatives, whether reliance on the common law, particular legislation or administrative mechanisms and programs . . . do not spell out and proclaim key rights and concepts in the same way as does the Bill of Rights.

We on this side of the chamber believe that the right to own property and to use that property to make a living is one of the most fundamental of the rights which distinguish Western democracies from the totalitarian, oppressive societies of socialist and communist states. I thought that Senator Sir John Carrick made that point quite well when he said the Russians and their satellite allies objected to this particular matter being included in such a Bill, and for very good reasons, because in those sorts of states one does not have the right to own property. They have co-operative farming enterprises which are run by government, and certainly such a government would not want the people living under its socialist administrations to have any rights at all with respect to property. Many of the rights set out in this Bill become meaningless unless the right to own property and to use that property to earn a living is included.

If the Bill is educative in nature, as the Attorney-General indicated, it is essential that these rights to property be included in the Bill so that the interconnection between the right to own property and real, as opposed to paper, rights is firmly established within that educative process. This is critically important at this stage of the development of Australia because a minority group of teachers, nonetheless vocal in their advocacy, have been given funds by this Government to teach so-called peace and resolution of conflict in schools in Australia. These courses claim that peace can come about only if capitalism and, therefore, Western democracy are eliminated. Those sorts of things are going on in Australia and we lie back and say that everything in the country is fine. I get quite alarmed. I believe that the Senate has to examine in greater detail the perversion of our school children under the Labor Administration in the past few years. I will pose a few questions to illustrate my point. I might tell honourable senators that the Parents Council and the Primary School Principals Association in South Australia have objected to politicising classrooms in that State. I think that is a very serious matter. The pacemaker in the process of indoctrination of our classrooms has been the New South Wales Teachers Federation whose resource folder proudly proclaims:

Peace studies is not about the formal academic study of peace and war . . . (its object is to) create student peace activists by a carefully planned program of psychopolitics and student involvement in peace and disarmament activities and protests.

The folder makes it quite clear that the function of the school must change from one of the liberal educational principles to the creation of `committed, caring peace students'. New South Wales peace activist, Cathy Bloch, who is one of the architects of these teaching guides and folders, sees peace studies and socialist perspectives being combined to bring about `the distribution of wealth and power'. Thus peace studies as taught are not about peace but about waging war against our capitalist society which dares to produce more wheat and primary produce than any of the totalitarian states. I was interested to note the other day that in Russia, for example, food production in that country per capita is at the same level today as it was in 1917. These people are trying to disparage our way of life, our capitalist society.

This Bill is another very aggressive step towards undermining the society that has brought us freedom and the rights that we have come to cherish over so many years. It is on this score and many others that I believe-someone called it a Clayton's Bill of Rights; I think that was quite an adequate expression-the Bill should include provisions such as a person's right to own property and to use that property to earn a living.

I alluded to that earlier. The way to do this is either through the way that Senator Sir John Carrick described earlier-by recognising these things in a flexible way at the outset or by a measure which is before us, which codifies the whole question of human rights, making human rights inflexible-or through a referendum. Many comments have been made against this measure. One particularly pertinent comment, I think, was made by Professor Lauchlan Chipman, the distinguished Professor of Philosophy at the University of Wollongong-I guess Senator Sir John Carrick would know him-in the television program Pressure Point on 30 May 1985. Regarding the commissions at which we are looking now he had this to say:

I think that the very fact that you have in the constitution of the commission that mixture of functions which allows the same body to be both an advocate and an investigator, and then that same commission, though not the same people, ultimately makes a determination as to whether someone has indeed broken the law, I think that's a monument to injustice.
He came to the conclusion:

There are views of eminent people such as Professor Chipman and members of the law councils of Australia. Senator Sir John Carrick drew attention to other quite prominent objections to the Bill. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is significant. It is modelled on, but not identical to, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which was adopted in 1966 and ratified by Australia in 1980. This ratification, subject to 13 reservations entered by the Fraser Government, signified Australia's willingness and ability to apply the provisions of the Convention. All but three of the 13 reservations have recently, in 1984, been lifted. One reservation remaining relates specifically to `propaganda for war'. Article 20 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights states:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Any propaganda for war shall be prohibited by law.
2. Any advocacy of national, racial or religious hatred that contributes incitement to discrimination, hostility or violence shall be prohibited by law.
The reasons for the continuing reservation, given in Australia's November 1981 report to the Human Rights Commission, are unconvincing. I quote from the report which states:

The Commonwealth and State Governments intend to adhere firmly to their established tradition of freedom of expression. They believe that this right would be too severely restricted if propaganda for war and incitement to discrimination, violence and hostility were to be made unlawful, particularly in times of peace. They further believe that the repugnant nature of such arguments becomes more readily apparent if free and open debate on this issue is allowed.

Does the Government accept that freedom of expression should include propaganda for war and incitement to discrimination, violence and hostility? Is the implication that we need to wait for a nuclear war before such freedom of expression be removed? Is this present Government arguing that the boundaries of free and open debate should allow propaganda for war and incitement to hostility? The consequences for our society in the event of a nuclear war are such that explicit legislation should be enacted within an Australian Bill of Rights to make propaganda for war illegal. Many would argue further that the Australian Government itself is guilty of promoting propaganda for war through the continued presence of, and implied approval for, the United States military and communications installations on Australian soil, by permitting B52 bombers flying across and landing on Australian soil; and by continuing to allow visiting nuclear warships to major seaports.

Other articles which are of concern follow. Article 3 (1) creates a test for permissible limitations which is very difficult to prove. A limitation will be permitted only if it `can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society'. This criterion is uncertain. By what criterion does one judge whether a society is free and democratic? The burden of proving that the particular law is demonstrably justified means that it must be patently clear. Article 32 raises the questions concerning customary law and punishment of Aboriginals. The Australian Law Reform Commission has documented concerns as to the interpretation of what is cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. That Aboriginal views may well differ very strongly from non-Aboriginals' views on this question must be kept in mind when persons seeking their rights use this Article in support of their case.
Regarding the operation of the Australian Bill of Rights, sub-clause (3) of clause 9 states:
The rights and freedoms set out in the Bill of Rights apply only for the benefit of natural persons.

It is considered essential that the rights and protections contained in the Australian Bill of Rights should be extended to corporations and groups. Representative actions are available under the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 where `a person aggrieved by the Act on behalf of the persons included in that class of persons' may lodge a complaint with the Commission and may thus have a resolution in favour of a class of people. The same right for representative actions must be included in the Australian Bill of Rights and persons should be able to seek declarations as to their rights in court. Such a right is permitted in the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. In a recent case there, in May 1985 the Operation Dismantle case, it was agreed that a Canadian Cabinet decision to permit US cruise missile testing in Canada infringed the charter-protected right to life, liberty and security of the persons by increasing the risk of nuclear war. Peace groups within Australia would welcome the opportunity to present such a case in Australia. According to Article 19 (1) of the Australian Bill of Rights:
Every person has the right to liberty and security of person.

The security of all Australian people is severely compromised by the continuing presence of US military installations, B52s and visiting nuclear warships. Australian people have a right to live without such threats to their security. The emphasis of the Australian Bill of Rights on individualism and individual human rights is to deny the natural law concept of the common good. The `common good' is of positive value and an Australian Bill of Rights has the responsibility to promote and protect it. The Murphy Bill of 1973, the Haines Bill of 1982 and the Evans Bill of 1984 did respect the rights of the body politic or corporate as well as those of the individual. The Evans Bill also included the right of a person or persons to apply for declarations about rights if those persons believed that a right or freedom had been infringed or was likely to be infringed in the immediate future. Such a right should be included in this Australian Bill of Rights.

Further, as the Australian Bill of Rights reads now, it does not override State laws, either statutory or common law, nor does it operate as a rule of construction for State laws. However, the Bill of Rights does empower the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to inquire into the State government laws or proposed laws provided that the Attorney-General, as the Minister responsible for the administration of the Act, has approved that inquiry after taking into account such matters as the Minister, in his or her discretion, considers appropriate. This provision is clearly open to abuse for political motives but would it be possible for the Federal Government to recommend that the Queensland and Western Australian Governments redraw their electoral boundaries for equal suffrage? Would the Queensland Government be urged to enforce the right of `peaceful assembly'? Would the same State government and others be urged to ensure the equal and inalienable rights of its Aboriginal people?

The Australian Democrats and certain members of the Australian Labor Party are to be congratulated on their initiatives to strengthen the Australian Bill of Rights so as to apply Federal law to State responsibilities. However, the concession that the States should be able to displace provisions, save the electoral rights provision, of the Bill of Rights by passing overriding legislation should be withdrawn. The main legislative areas where human rights are denied occurs at the State, not Federal, level. An Australian Bill of Rights that does not address the questions of State abuse of basic human rights immediately and directly will deny the fundamental principles of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. As Australia ratified the ICCPR in 1980 after consultation with all the States, this Government is therefore morally and politically responsible for ensuring that that covenant is enforced in full, save for the three reservations.

While the Australian Bill of Rights is designed to work in conjunction with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, which includes the ICCPR schedule, it is preferable that the schedule be incorporated directly into the Bill of Rights and that the Bill of Rights be adopted as a constitutional amendment. As it stands at present, an ordinary Act of parliament, it may be easily amended and even repealed or specifically overridden by succeeding legislation. Additional powers conferred on courts are wider than presently exist, and this is to be commended. Federal legislation in existence before the passage of the Act cannot be struck down for a five-year period, and that is far too long.

The Australian Bill of Rights Bill, as it stands, can be considered primarily as an educative and symbolic statement and secondarily as a yardstick against which current and future Federal and State laws, Acts and practices can be measured. Given that the Australian Constitution is currently under review, it is recommended that by 1988 an Australian Bill of Rights be enshrined within the Australian Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I wish to speak on this document just briefly because it is self-explanatory. The subject of the document is the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and Mr Buffett says that this matter has now been discussed in the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly, and adds:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . My Government's position was endorsed on 4 December 1985 by a unanimous resolution of the Assembly, the text of which is as follows:
Then follows the motion that has now been incorporated. I wish to highlight one or two matters relating to the motion that was passed. Part of it says:
the Legislative Assembly opposes the extension of the proposed Australian Bill of Rights legislation to Norfolk Island;

The extension of the Australian Bill of Rights to Norfolk Island has, in the opinion of the Legislative Assembly, been proposed without adequate consultation between the Commonwealth and Norfolk Island Governments;

There is no doubt that in this debate, as in many other debates, it always comes back to the fact that the people-organisations and individuals around Australia-say that they have never been adequately consulted on so many moves that the present Government has taken. In closing his letter to the Senate, Mr Buffett urges that the Bill be opposed-and there will be an amendment seeking to do this-and he adds:
We are anxious to see the Bill referred to a Standing or Select Committee for detailed consideration of the points we have raised. We would greatly appreciate your assistance in achieving this.

This was contained in a letter to the Senate. Of course, the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly is against the Bill but, in the event of the Bill being passed, it wishes the matter to go to a committee. As I was saying, Norfolk Island and other Australian Territories, including the Australian Capital Territory, feel concern at being included in the Bill. However, the Northern Territory has been excluded in this respect and in the interpretation section of the Bill has been defined as a State. Sometimes the Northern Territory is defined as a State and at other times it is considered a Territory. In this case it is defined as a State. Surely the Federal Government, if it is genuinely interested in the rights of Australians, should start with their right to be informed and consulted about such a significant piece of legislation. Is the Federal Government really interested in the rights of Australians? I think not. I certainly think, judging by this piece of legislation, that the Federal Government has a minimal interest in enhancing the rights of Australians and a maximum interest in enhancing its own power vis-a-vis the States, Territories and local government.

Even though the legislation will not allow the Federal Government to override State legislation directly, it will force State, Territory or local governments to submit their laws to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to determine whether those laws comply with the requirements of the Acts. The Commission will have the power to determine whether State or local laws infringe the rights set out in the Bill. With the exception of the Northern Territory, the Bill will impose an obligation on Norfolk Island, the Australian Capital Territory and all external Territories to ensure that any future Territory legislation or ordinances are in compliance with the Bill.

The Commission, a body of people who are not elected, will be empowered to compel people to appear before it and to attend compulsory conferences without any legal representation-a rather incredible situation. Also the Commission is empowered to inflict fines or impose imprisonment on persons who fail to appear or who fail to provide information when requested to do so by the Commission. The very fact that under this legislation people will be denied the right to legal representation in circumstances in which they may be faced with a fine or imprisonment is evidence of the lack of credibility of the Government's arguments that the Bills are all about protecting rights.

The amazing thing about this situation is that if one read about it, perhaps in a newspaper, one would think that perhaps one was reading about a law or an order from a dictatorship. We believe in democracy here. However, where is democracy in relation to the Bills which we see before us today? When one adds to that consideration of the sorts of decisions which have been reached by the Human Rights Commission in the past, the potential for the perpetration of gross injustices by the Commission in the name of human rights becomes even more clear.

If I may, I will just outline a few examples of the Commission's past efforts. It banned the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), from its offices after he criticised its performance and policy. The Commission declared Mr Brown to be `a non person'. Once again, what an incredible situation! Clearly, the Commission has not heard of the rights of free speech. The Commission has suppressed a research paper on affirmative action which it commissioned from Dr Gabriel Moens, describing his views as `tendentious'. In reality it was objecting to his conclusions that affirmative action was philosophically unjustified and inconsistent with equality of opportunity. There goes free speech again, I suggest.

The Commission has supported the right of Women Against Rape to disrupt Anzac Day marches. It seems that free speech is all right if it is exercised by a group with which members of the Commission perhaps have sympathy. For example, the Pine Gap feminist protesters' claims that they had been tortured by the police were supported by the Commission-I do not know on what basis-in spite of the fact that no charges were ever laid and notwithstanding the assurances of the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, that there was no evidence of police brutality. The Commission has attacked the Queensland Government over its industrial relations law, claiming that the legislation governing employment by the Queensland Electricity Commission amounted to an enforcement of `slave labour'. That is a ridiculous claim. I wonder what will happen to the rights of Queenslanders to an uninterrupted power supply if this legislation is passed.

The Commission has advocated laws banning any comments which could be described as racially intolerant, claiming that such a law is needed to protect people from Irish jokes and the views of academics such as Geoffrey Blainey. Free speech goes out the window, I say, once again. The Commission also has refused to intervene to protect the rights of Frank Marrett, who was sacked by his employer after he refused to contribute to an illegal levy by the Amalgamated Metal Foundry and Shipwrights Union. The Commission, in contrast to its willingness to interfere in Queensland industrial law and other State laws, said that his case was outside its jurisdiction. Perhaps that was so, but what a strange thing. I believe those are but a few examples in the long list of cases in which the Human Rights Commission has shown its true colours. The Commission amply demonstrates that my colleague Senator Parer was spot on when he referred to the Human Rights Commission earlier in this debate as the new Australian thought police. Those who have read George Orwell's 1984 would remember that between Big Brother and the thought police there was very limited scope for individual free expression. The prospect of handing the Commission the additional powers proposed by this legislation has dire implications for existing rights which already are protected under the system of common law.

I have already alluded to the amount of correspondence which this legislation has generated. I believe that it is worth making the point that a significant number of letters and phone calls which have come into my office and, for that matter, the offices of many other senators have been from Australian citizens who have come here from countries with totalitarian regimes. I would have thought that these people are those who would be most well aware of the need for the rights of the individual to be protected. Yet, to a man and a woman, they have vigorously urged that the Bill of Rights and the associated Bills be defeated. From their many and bitter experiences in Europe and other places they have recognised the dangers of enunciating a limited number of rights and of placing the authority for the enforcement of those rights in the hands of a Commission with its own political barrows which it has quite clearly pushed in the past and a centralist government which is determined to gain for itself as much power from the States as possible.

I have already said that I believe the Bill to be a power-grabbing exercise and nothing to do with a genuine attempt to protect rights. An examination of the Bill will quickly show that this simply is not false rhetoric. On the facts, rights just are not protected by this Bill. Where does this Bill mention the right to the freedom to choose one's own religion, the right to own property or the right of parents to choose to send their children to non-state schools? These are mentioned nowhere. This has been debated in another place. The Bill does not mention these rights anywhere. As I have said, it does not protect them anywhere. Indeed, when the coalition in another place moved amendments which would have had the effect of protecting these rights within the framework of this legislation, the Labor Government voted against those amendments, as undoubtedly it will vote against them in this chamber. The Labor Government is not interested in the rights of people to freedom of religion or freedom to choose non-government education for their children or the right to their own property, and so many other things.

What the Federal Government is interested in is what it clearly sees as its right to interfere in the State, Territory and local government legislation of this country under the guise of protecting human rights. That is big brother in the extreme. In drafting this legislation the Government is, as my colleague Senator Durack quite rightly pointed out, very long on the rights of persons to join unions but says nothing about the rights of a person to refuse to join a union and to remain employed without penalty. For instance, I certainly did not see or hear the Human Rights Commission defending Jay Pendarvis and his wife Joy and his meatworkers at Mudginberri when they exercised their right to work and to negotiate a legal agreement in accordance with established industrial guidelines. But that is hardly surprising, given the performance that I have outlined.

The coalition will seek again in this chamber to have included in the rights which this Bill covers the right of an individual to choose not to join a union. After all, it is supposedly a free country although, the way we are going, quite obviously it is not because Big Brother is breathing down everyone's neck. The Government voted against the Opposition's amendment when it was moved in another place. That is an indication of its hollow claims about its being concerned with the protection of the rights of the individual. If the Government votes against it again in the Senate, by so doing honourable senators opposite will have removed any last shred of doubt that they are interested in anything other than increasing the Federal Government's power to interfere with the legislation of the States. At least the Democrats make no bones about the fact that they want this legislation to go further and to be applied directly to the States instead of indirectly, as the Government proposes.

I understand that the Democrats plan to move amendments which will seek to apply the Bills directly to the States, and the coalition will be voting against those amendments. Clearly, the Democrats are taking the same centralist approach to States rights as the Federal Government. Unfortunately, the numbers will dictate the fate of these Bills and, indeed, the fate of the people of Australia. I am sorry that the pleas in the mass of correspondence from genuinely concerned people who have urged the Federal Government to desist from passing this legislation have fallen on deaf ears on the Government and Democrats side. On looking at the submissions that honourable senators on both sides of the chamber have received from learned professional people and from people in very many other walks of life, I can only assure those people who made those very detailed and competent submissions that the coalition is determined not only to fight this legislation here and now but also to repeal it when it is returned to government. It seems as though this Bill will be passed with the support of the Democrats. I have no doubt that when this Bill is passed many people in Australia will wish to see it repealed. I am sure that in the future, as people experience more and more the effects of having Big Brother breathing over their shoulders, there will be increasing momentum for this piece of legislation to be removed from the statute book of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is quite a strong view in the community as to the constitutional validity of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill should that legislation be passed by the Senate. Therefore, it will not be surprising to many to see an early testing of this view in the High Court of Australia. Those who believe in the principles of federalism must reject this Bill of Rights. This Bill has created a tremendous amount of interest, concern and public discussion since it was hurried through the House of Representatives. I am sure that I am not alone when I say that I have been inundated with hundreds of letters expressing opposition to the Bill. Some of the arguments that have been put forward are seemingly well founded and raise doubts about the Bill's ability to protect rights, particularly if a wide range of powers is vested in a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission with power virtually to conduct its investigations in secret. I share with the Law Council of Australia a belief that secret investigations are objectionable, especially where there is no right of legal or other representation before the tribunal itself.

SPEECH.PARA: Some groups have expressed a justifiable concern at what we might term deliberate omissions or changes made to the list of human rights that has been enunciated in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights on which the Australian Bill of Rights is based. For example, Article 23.1 of the International Covenant to which we as a nation are a signatory states:
The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society and the State.

That has been omitted from the Australian Bill of Rights. I ask: Has Australian society disintegrated so much that it no longer believes in the importance of the family or have the architects of the Bill determined that the security offered by the family support network is no longer important and therefore should no longer be supported by legislation or even by society itself? I believe that the family must receive due recognition as the natural and fundamental group unit of society and as such it is entitled to protection by society and the state.

Probably in response to the desire to remove the right of the family to recognition and protection from the Australian Bill of Rights, the architects of this Bill have decided to deny the rights of parents to determine the type of education received by their children. The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights states:

Parties to the Covenant undertake to have respect for the liberty of parents and, when applicable, legal guardians to ensure the religious and moral education of their children in conformity with their own convictions.

If we as a nation and as a parliament have agreed to become a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, why are we seeking to make such vitally important omissions? Are we saying that it is quite okay for the 80 or so other countries that are signatories to the Covenant to protect the family and the rights of parents but that we as a so-called Christian community do not consider the family unit worth being granted any rights under the proposed Bill of Rights? Are we saying by these very omissions that we have signed the International Covenant but that it is not binding on our country? I do not find any great problem in the declaration of civil and political rights, but this Bill falls a long way short of being adequate for the job.

While I recognise that many remarks made in opposition to this Bill are justified, I have to acknowledge that I am conscious of the many ill-founded, ill-informed and disturbingly inaccurate statements that are being made in an effort to stir up public opposition and fear. It is unfortunate that it has been necessary for some people to go to those sorts of lengths. Letters that have been received over the last few weeks reveal quite clearly many people's distrust of the Government and their fears for the future of our society, particularly with the omission of the family unit from the Bill of Rights. The Labor Government therefore must accept a great deal of the blame for this increasing fear and confusion because of the secrecy in which this Bill was conceived and the haste with which it was pressed and passed through the House of Representatives. There has not been enough time to examine the implications and ramifications of this Bill. There has not been enough time for interested and knowledgeable persons and organisations to come to terms adequately with this Bill. There has not been enough time for the people of this country to discuss and debate the various areas of concern; in fact, the people of this country were not even canvassed to see whether they really wanted a Bill of Rights. This legislation is of considerable constitutional and public importance. The draft of the Bill should have been distributed as widely as possible and time, preferably 12 months, should have been made available to allow for informed discussion, comment and debate.

The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs presented an exposure report on a Bill of Rights. This report was presented in the Senate in November 1985. The Committee, I believe, made a valuable contribution to the debate and its views should not be ignored. Since the actual Bill has now seen the light of day, the Committee is in a very good position to undertake a detailed review of the legislation. Thus, instead of proceeding to deal with the legislation in its present form, I believe it would be considered desirable to refer the Bill back to the Senate Standing Committee for further scrutiny and report. We are in no position, I believe, to act on this Bill now.

Within the Parliament we all acknowledge that there is bipartisan support for the Inter- national Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I think there is general agreement that basic human rights should be preserved as such. As a signatory to the Covenant we have an obligation to ensure that the rights and freedoms guaranteed by the International Covenant on Civil and Political rights are valued, and if they are denied, there is an effective remedy. Unfortunately, there is considerable disagreement about the content and extent of the Australian Bill of Rights. There is confusion as to whether a Bill of Rights should be a basic declaration, to be supplemented by other more explicit legislation, or whether the Bill should be all-inclusive. There is, I believe, total confusion in the minds of the public and considerable disagreement with regard to the role and powers of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. With such disagreement and confusion rife in the Parliament and the community, I believe that the only sensible course would be to defer the debate in this House for at least 12 months and in the meantime refer the Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.
