—Yes, Senator. Of course, the Bill of Rights in the United States is the cornerstone of American democracy. During our education in the United States it is drummed into our heads. Frankly, I did not take it very seriously as a high school student, as a youngster. I did not take it seriously until I became involved in the protest against the Vietnam war, when the government of the day was starting to take excessive steps against the people of the United States. The Bill of Rights was brought out to protect them, and it did so. Ultimately, because of those legal protests, guaranteed under the Bill of Rights, the Vietnam war ended. That was certainly a tremendous advantage to the United States. I think a Bill of Rights would be a tremendous advantage here. The Bill of Rights that has been introduced in this Parliament has a number of similarities to the United States Bill of Rights. I am surprised that, with the love and affection that members of the Liberal-National Party Opposition hold for all things American, they do not embrace this Bill of Rights. But apparently they draw the line at that point. They will accept American nuclear ships, American war planes and American nuclear holocausts, but they will not accept an American-style Bill of Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: This country is not really a country; it is a collection of petulant States. They are so petulant that they cannot even agree on railway gauges. Each State preserves its own right to go its own way. I think in this late part of the twentieth century we cannot afford the luxury of a horse and buggy system in which we have small States like Tasmania which have massive powers. Tasmania, with a population of 435,000, has 12 senators. It is absolutely ridiculous. What we need is recognition that we have jet aircraft and electronic communication. These States were set up in the horse and buggy days. We really need regional government and a strong Federal government. We certainly need protection from the excesses of the States. It has been noted earlier in this place that it is the State governments that are the oppressive governments. It is the State governments that cause grief in the community.
Honourable senators will recall, I am sure, that in Tasmania we had a controversy over the damming of the Franklin River. During that controversy--

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall that that was when we first met.

—That is indeed when we first met. I was welcoming the honourable senator to Strahan when he flew in to see first hand the damage that the Gray Government and the Hydro-Electric Commission were doing in South West Tasmania. I remember that I was sitting on a fence, which I do not often do, when the honourable senator's aircraft landed and I welcomed him to Strahan. I thank the honourable senator and his Party for what they did in saving that beautiful river. But during that time there was politicisation of the police and courts in Tasmania. The courts and police were subverted by the Government for political ends. During the blockade we set up a communications system of citizen band radios. The police jammed those radios. They devised a system by which they could tune in a receiver to our frequencies. They could then start a transmitter which would jam those frequencies. That was in violation of Federal law. Yet the police, in Tasmania, under State government orders, were jamming our radio signals. The police cut the Commonwealth telephone lines in Tasmania. They not only cut the lines to the Wilderness Society headquarters, but also cut the lines to every public phone box in the town of Strahan, including the one at the airport, so that I could not ring up the Department of Transport to file a flight plan. That is a Federal offence. That happened in Tasmania. That is a certain deprivation of our rights.
—And it was supported by the Liberal Party of the day.
—It was supported by the Liberal Party of the day.
—Those were the days, when we were down in Strahan.

—They were good days in Strahan because they brought out not only the worst of the political system but also the best of the political system. It was a victory for grassroots democracy. But we do need defence from the excesses of demagogues and totalitarian politicians such as Robin Gray and Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. The demagogues of this world will scare people; they will use them, but in the end they will take their rights from them.

SPEECH.PARA: In Tasmania at this very moment there is a vigil. It started today in the wilderness forests of south-western Tasmania because yesterday the Gray Government told the bulldozers to move into the National Estate areas. Because of the draconian legislation that was passed in the Tasmanian Parliament late last year anybody setting foot in a state forest in Tasmania can now be arrested. It is a $500 offence or two months in gaol for merely standing in a state forest in Tasmania. That is why we need this Bill of Rights. It is not something that happens in Russia, Guatemala, Nicaragua or some place else. We are being deprived of our rights in many areas right now-not just the environmental protesters-and it must be stopped. We must have a strong Bill of Rights which will protect these rights.

The Australian Democrats are moving a number of amendments to strengthen the Bill of Rights. A Bill of Rights is a good thing but, first and foremost, it has to have enough teeth to make the State governments come to heel. That is of prime importance. I urge honourable senators to forget their usual mud-slinging, slanging matches and personal vilification and to think about the needs of this country. We need to be guaranteed our freedom, we cannot take it for granted. The only way to guarantee our freedom is with a strong Bill of Rights. I recommend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to hear Senator Sanders suggest that those people who had written letters and taken the trouble to contact so many of us-I, too, have received a number of letters-have been stirred up by demagogues, to use his words. A number of the letters that I have received are form letters. I think it would be reasonable to assume that many people may well have very significant views and feelings about the Australian Bill of Rights Bill but are not confident in expressing them. They feel that sending a letter that has been described as a form letter is one way of knowing that they have at least done that much. The numerous people who have contacted me have not been stirred up by demagogues in the Australian Capital Territory. The churchmen in the Australian Capital Territory whom I know are very concerned about this Bill are not demagogues. They have a genuine concern for their community.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a wide-ranging debate. Many issues have been canvassed, some of them very relevant to the Bill and some of them ranging quite widely from it. But there are a couple of aspects of the Bill to which I want to refer specifically-the articles in the Bill of Rights and the quite different, but very significant, powers conferred upon the Human Rights Commission. They really are two quite separate propositions. Under the articles, the Government is seeking to confer a few rights on the people of this country. I would have preferred an approach whereby the people conferred powers on the Parliament, but that is not to be the case and we are getting a few crumbs. It is, by no means, exhaustive. What troubles me is that it may well be seen that the rights that have been conferred have a great deal of importance. Those that some of us think still exist perhaps do not exist any more or perhaps they are under threat.

Senator Sanders also attacked us for saying that there was no need for a Bill and went on to say, in a loud voice, that we should talk to the unemployed. I had a quick look through the articles and I still cannot find any mention of the right to work. It is obvious why there cannot be a right to work. If there were a right to work a person would have to be able to do so without being forced to join a trade union and that, of course, presumably cannot be put in this Bill. But a person would be discriminated against if he were not able to work because he refused to join a trade union. That is one of the significant omissions from this Bill.

The second aspect that I said I would refer to is the powers of the Commission and the significant change in direction of the system of justice that comes about under those provisions. The Bill is especially important to the Australian Capital Territory because we really are the social laboratory where it will all happen. Certainly there are powers to interfere with the States and the Northern Territory which is included as a State and specifically excluded as a Territory. But the Australian Capital Territory is right in line for what comes up under this Bill. I note that there is no exclusion for the ACT council when it comes into effect. No provision is made for it to be excluded once it is operating. It is clearly intended that the Commonwealth will retain its power to interfere in the ACT in the way one can assume it would like to interfere in the States and in the way that the Democrats would want it to interfere in the States.

Because the Bill specifically refers to the ACT and to acts of the Commonwealth, I feel the people of the Australian Capital Territory have a particular interest in it. Clause 4 (1) only applies to acts done by or on behalf of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory-I am referring particularly, to the Commonwealth-or by or on behalf of an authority of the Commonwealth, of a State, or of a Territory. In a sense the Commonwealth does not really do anything. We are now talking about public servants. Presumably public servants who get involved will be protected for any costs which are incurred and they will be borne by the Commonwealth. I do not think we should forget that the face of the Commonwealth in these proceedings is that of the public servant. Many public servants live in this electorate and will be directly affected by the legislation that is being brought in. Let me now turn to the Articles of the Bill which seek to protect minority groups. That is clearly set out in Article 5, which states:

Persons who belong to an ethnic, religious or linguistic minority have the right, in community with other members of their own group, to enjoy their own culture, to profess and practise their own religion, or to use their own language.

Parents of a religious minority group who may wish to educate their children in a certain way cannot do so. That is restricted. It can be no accident that the right of choice in education is restricted because it is effectively repeated again in Article 14, which deals with the rights of the child. Paragraph (d) states:
the liberty of parents and legal guardians to ensure the religious and moral education of their children in conformity with their own convictions is to be respected.

There is no suggestion that they have a right of choice of schooling. It is interesting that a minority of this community, only about 25 per cent, wish and choose to send their children to non-government schools, but that seems to be a minority that this Government is not prepared to respect and recognise. It is a most serious and significant omission. It cannot be an accident that that is the case and that it has been omitted. I have referred to the fact that there is no right not to join a trade union and I mentioned that in response to Senator Sanders's speech about the unemployed. There is no right not to join a trade union. The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, on which this Bill is based, was drawn up 20 years or so ago. At that time to suggest that there should be a right to join a trade union was a very reasonable thing, and I guess that none of us would have objected to that being put in. But the changes which have taken place over the past 20 years are such that the reasons for putting that in 20 years ago are the same reasons which should demand that the right not to join a trade union be included now. It is clearly discriminatory against people who want to work, who would have thought that they have a right to work, but because of this they are no longer entitled to that right.

One would have thought that one would be entitled to enjoy the fruits of one's labour-subject of course to tax obligations. With the fruits of one's labour one should be entitled to acquire property and to enjoy it, but no such right is preserved in this Bill. It refers to the protection of privacy, the family, the home and correspondence, but not to the actual home. It has been the policy of this Party for a very long time that owning one's home is something that should be encouraged. This Government has been promoting that policy over the past three years with its first home ownership scheme and all sorts of things, but there is no right to own property. One could lose it at any time. There is no definition in the Bill which enables that right to be preserved.

However, even if one really thought that the Bill of Rights was necessary-even though it is enforceable only against the Commonwealth and not against individuals or unions-and appropriate and one did not mind not having the right not to join a union, not to own property and not having a choice of education, and one felt that the Bill was complete as it is and that what is left out is unimportant, and one was enthusiastic about it up to this point, one could only be alarmed if one read Part III, entitled `Operation of Bill of Rights'. The actions which flow from all this may turn out to be costly for the Government, but that is not the issue. The real worry I have is for the individuals, the public servants, who are likely to bear the brunt of being the real respondents to this legislation. There can be no doubt that they are the real respondents.

Firstly, the Commission will inquire into any act reported to it and will seek a solution if possible by way of conciliation. That is commendable. Clause 26 deals with the complaints that would be inquired into. There is provision for help for the complainant and appropriate assistance from the Commission. One would not object to that, but we note also in clause 26 that for the first time the respondent is identified and the words refer to an act of a person. Suddenly we find that the Commonwealth is a person. I am glad to find that that is the case, because that is exactly what it is and that is where we find the focus on those who bear the brunt of this legislation. Throughout this Bill it is clear, and it persists, that a complainant who comes to the Human Rights Commission has a halo and wings, but any respondent or public servant involved on the other side has horns. It is quite contrary to what one would expect to be the thrust of the Bill of Rights.

There is no provision for a public servant, who is the real respondent, to be adequately represented. The proceedings on behalf of the Commonwealth undoubtedly will be taken over by a branch head or somebody else within a department. The person concerned-who may have done nothing wrong, who may have been only doing his job as he saw it, and may feel very aggrieved about the way his branch head or a senior person is handling the matter-has no position in this at all. There is no recognition of public servants as human beings, whose jobs depends on being in the Public Service, and I find that thoroughly offensive.

Clause 27 of the Bill recognises that there can be such things as frivolous, vexatious or misconceived complaints, or complaints lacking in substance. It may well be that there will be complaints of that nature from time to time. The Commission may decide not to inquire into complaints that it decides are of this nature, but we are not given any indication of the basis upon which the Commission would make such a decision. It may do it strictly; it may take the view that it is difficult and that it will not rule out many complaints in that category, but will let them go through to see what happens. One wonders whether we will ever know what the actual guidelines will be, as to whether or not a complaint may be frivolous, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance.

There are a lot of things in this legislation that are secret, and that may be one of the things. There are no rules to guide decisions of this nature. What remedy does a respondent have where an inquiry of this type proceeds and is subsequently found to be frivolous, vexatious, misconceived, or lacking in substance? A diligent public servant who has gone through the anguish and worry of being on the receiving end of one of these complaints, who has probably had sleepless nights, has no provision in this Bill whatever to get any recompense for having suffered that. I should not expect that he would be out of pocket but there is more to life than that; there certainly is in this legislation. There is no suggestion either that the Commonwealth can recover any costs under a provision of this kind. Again, the respondent has horns and I think this legislation lacks in comprehension of the people involved.

The Commission is not bound by the rules of evidence. That sounds pretty good and makes it sound very relaxed, informal and easy-going. The rules of evidence may not be perfect and they are criticised from time to time, but at least they give a structure and give some idea of what is going on. We have some idea of where we stand in proceedings where rules of evidence apply. Here we have no idea, and probably the proceedings will be in secret anyway. It could be a secret complaint, an anonymous complainant and a secret inquiry. I think it is a disgrace that we should contemplate setting up anything of that nature. People would be able to incriminate themselves and would have no idea of what they were dealing with. The rules guiding the Commission could come under the heading of intuition, innuendo, hunch or prejudice. I have not the slightest doubt that those appointed to the Commission will be conscientious and will want to carry out their duty, but we would not know what things guide them and there is no way of knowing exactly how it will all turn out.

The complainant may have his or her identity kept secret. Certainly I approve of the provision that publishing should be a matter for the Commission to determine-whether or not a matter should be disclosed to the Press and published-but there are other secrecy aspects which I think are grossly unfair to the respondents who, as I will point out again, are in fact public servants. The Commonwealth has no face of its own, other than through them. There is no way for them to properly defend themselves. If they do not have the full story of the complaint, as they may not, they cannot possibly bring the best or all evidence to the proceedings. There is no right to legal representation.

It is interesting to go back to the articles and to note the sorts of things which should occur when somebody is before the courts and the sorts of rights that apply in that situation. Those rights are quite specifically left out in proceedings before the Commission-the right to be informed, the right to obtain legal assistance and the right to communicate with a lawyer. A whole range of things in Article 27 do not flow on to the Bill. There is provision for the Commission to subpoena documents. They are handed over to the Commission or to a prescribed person. There does not seem to be any means of debating, arguing or challenging what is in a subpoena, as to whether or not the documents ought to be produced. If one is told to produce them, one must do so. I suggest that the penalties in the legislation are pretty severe. If one is subpoenaed to produce documents to a court, certain rules apply and the way in which a case is proceeded with can be debated. However, this legislation provides that one just hands over documents. Clause 31 provides that the Commission can take possession of documents which are in its hands. It can make copies of and take extracts from them. It can retain the documents for as long as it thinks necessary. There is no mention in the legislation of the way in which one can challenge that sort of action by the Commission. Of course, it is not only the Commonwealth that may be required to produce documents under this provision. Another party could be involved and presumably it, too, will not be allowed to have legal representation before the Commission.
There is incredible power in the Human Rights Commission which I think should be resisted. Henry Brooks Adams said:
The effect of power and publicity on all men is the aggravation of the self, a sort of tumour that ends by killing the victims' sympathy.

I do not know what will happen to the Human Rights Commissioners, but it is the sort of power that I would find quite frightening. A member of the Commission, of course, can administer an oath and examine witnesses. However, I do not find any suggestion of cross-examination of witnesses or the right to challenge and examine a complaint that has been made. I am not suggesting that such a complaint would not be valid. However, if it is a valid complaint, it would stand up to cross-examination; if it is a vexatious complaint it may not, and surely that should be exposed. This provision is inquisitorial; I think it is unjust and quite contrary to the best interests of our system. The Bill provides a significant change of direction. It seeks to give significant increases in power to a body which is not a court. There is secrecy, it is unstructured and it is potentially dangerous.

The financial impact statement set out in the second reading speech of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) does not really tell us very much. It concedes that the legislation will, of course, have a direct cost to the Government. We are told that there may be some additional cost to departments. The statement refers to a sum of money that in no way is accounted for. There is no basis for the calculations of the amount of $350,000 suggested as the cost for the financial year 1985-86 and the $1.4m thereafter. I suggest that the amount may in fact turn out to be considerably more. It is not anticipated that there will be any significant financial impact from the legislation on industry or other financial sections of the community. I am not at all certain that that will be actually the case because I think that they may well yet be caught up in some of the proceedings which have been referred to. Clause 49 (1) provides:

A person who has invoked the provisions of the Bill of Rights in any legal proceeding may apply to the Attorney-General for the provision of assistance under this section in respect of the proceeding.

The legislation does not seem to give a public servant, who in fact may be a respondent, the right to seek representation or legal advice. I wonder, then, from where that sort of money will come? It does not seem to be provided for in the statement of financial impact. Will it in fact come from what may well be regarded as the limited legal aid sources that exist at present? I think we may well find just about every complainant under this Bill will be seeking financial assistance. Therefore, I think we are entitled to have some idea of what the costs are likely to be and what impact this legislation will have on other sources of legal aid. This is a significant aspect of the operation of this Bill and the effect that it will have on other litigation.

I have said that I do not think we need a Bill of Rights. I have pointed out what I regard as the deficiencies in the legislation. Also, I have pointed out what I regard as the serious deficiencies as far as many of my constituents are concerned. I believe that they are entitled to be concerned about the impact that this legislation may well have on them and on their careers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Predictably, I oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985. I do so essentially for four basic reasons. Those reasons are what I might broadly call the Bill's foundations; the principle of a Bill of Rights; the characteristics of this Bill of Rights; and, finally, the way in which the Government intends to administer the Bill of Rights should this legislation ever be enacted. This Bill has as its foundations, of course, the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Australia became a signatory to that covenant in 1972. It is alleged that this legislation is an attempt to bring Australian law into conformity with the standards laid down in that document and that that is what caused the Government to introduce this Bill. I strongly dispute from the outset the notion that Australia needs to enact a Bill of Rights to bring its laws into conformity with the covenant. The covenant, by any standards, is very shallow protection for human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not the slightest contention of opposition to certain parts of the covenant. For example, Article 8 (1) of the covenant provides unequivocally that no one shall be held in slavery, and Article 16 provides that everyone shall have the right everywhere to be treated as a person before the law. Where, however, there may be any contention about a right, the covenant contains broad exceptions and abounds with words such as `except as provided by law, are necessary to protect public security or public order'. Any argument which might attempt to portray Australia as not living up to its international obligations if it does not enact this Bill is false. A simple perusal of the terms of the United Nations agreement will reveal this. The fact that our civil rights record is already more than adequate to meet our obligations is evidenced by the fact that the Soviet Union was able to be party to the very same agreement virtually without reservations. If the human rights record of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is such that it can be party to this covenant and meet all its obligations, I do not think that contemporary Australia is ever likely to be called to account.

The second great falsehood of this covenant is one which was repeated by Senator Button, who is presently leaving the chamber, in his speech. Senator Button said that the covenant specifically commits Australia to adopt legislative measures to give effect to the rights it contains. Senator Button then cited Article 2 (2) of the covenant to support this contention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't believe I said any of that.

—Does not Senator Button believe anything about the Bill of Rights? I am glad to hear him commit himself in Hansard on that. Article 2 (2) of the covenant states a party to the covenant is required `to adopt such legislative or other measures as may be necessary to give effect to the rights recognised in the present covenant'. This does not require legislation at all. Our present legislation, and more particularly the common law, already provide the Australian people with all the rights and freedoms that this covenant will ever demand. Thus, there is no reason to believe that this Bill of Rights is necessary for Australia to meet any of its international obligations or agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: The potential constitutional ramifications of this Bill of Rights are another ground on which to oppose the legislation. Though the present Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has chosen not to extend the legal operation of this Bill to the States, fair warning of the possibility was given by Senator Button in his speech. In reality, it is as if the Commonwealth has already legislated for the States. When Senator Button says that the Government is not going to extend the operation of this Bill to the States but the Commonwealth expects the States to enact legislation to conform with the Bill, and that should they not do so the Commonwealth reserves the right to enact overriding legislation, what choice does that leave the States? It leaves them absolutely and unequivocally none.

If Australia is to have a Bill of Rights, if it is to become an historic document and if the Government wants support for such a document, I believe that an intrinsic part of that commitment ought to be public support for such a proposal. When we have legislation of a constitutional nature such as this and it does not have that support, it is not worth the paper it is written on. What the Government ought to be doing is seeking a referendum. The Australian Labor Party does not seem to understand or chooses not to understand that, particularly with this kind of document, there is no magic in just a piece of paper. Both the United States and the Soviet Union have written constitutions, both are written on a piece of paper. In one country the government is legally and practically bound by the Constitution; in the other, in reality, it is not. The reason a mere piece of paper can work in one country and not in another is that in the former there is a genuine commitment to the principles which it embodies. It is this and nothing else which gives the piece of paper such strength. By contrast, the Australian Bill of Rights Bill has no such public support. It would be most unlikely that the Government could muster support from half the community. For this type of legislation, a simple majority is just not enough. Such an Act needs broad-based community support if it is to be the historical document that the Australian Labor Party would wish it to be. From the correspondence I have received, far from having the support of half the community, there appears to be violent and vehement opposition from the vast majority of the Australian community. As I said earlier, if the Government is serious about this Bill it ought to be holding a referendum and getting the imprimatur of the community as a whole to the introduction of such controversial legislation.

The second broad reason for my opposition to this Bill is that I object, in a society such as ours, to the very principle of a Bill of Rights. If one is really concerned about protecting the liberties of the citizen, there are two ways by which something might be done about it. The first way is to remove the power of the state to make the transgression. It is this method which was adopted with respect to interstate trade under section 92 of the Constitution. If one wants to understand the Labor Party's liking for constitutional provisions which take away the power to interfere in the life of a citizen, one ought to consult Mr Whitlam's book On Australia's Constitution. In regard to section 92 of the Constitution, which takes away the power of the Government to meddle, Mr Whitlam rages for pages about it. He is vehement in this opposition to section 92 because it denies constitutional power to the Federal Government and the Executive. The protection of rights to which I refer in this fashion might be described as protection by exclusion because it excludes the offending power from the field of legislative competence.

One of the many reasons I am opposed to this Bill of Rights in principle is that it pays no heed, as Senator Gareth Evans knows, to the institutions which we have already to protect our liberties. The greatest of these is, of course, the common law and since the times of Coke the judges have stood between the Executive and the subject in defence of liberty. The great attribute of the common law is its ability to adapt to fit the times in which it is being employed in service of the people. No Bill of Rights can hope to do this unless it is cast in very broad language, which in itself has many problems. The Bill of Rights is based on a priori reasoning. It assumes that those rights which are presently appropriate are also appropriate for the future. Of course, that is just not the case.

Sir Harry Gibbs demonstrated the difficulties which this has caused in the United States when he delivered the eleventh Wilfred Fullagar Memorial Lecture. The Chief Justice drew attention to the second amendment of the United States Constitution, which allows people to bear arms. While this may have been appropriate when the Constitution was drawn up in the aftermath of a revolution, it is very doubtful that it is necessary or beneficial today. However, it is something that cannot be changed. Much of the vitality of the law will be lost if we attempt to set up a Bill of Rights which enshrines the value of one time for all time.

I do not believe our society needs a Bill of Rights because of checks and balances which are already in our system of government. The division of the arms of government into three is one of these checks and balances. Each arm of government can and does form a restraining influence on the others. The Parliament may, by legislation, control the Executive and override the judiciary. The judiciary has the power to interpret the statutes of the Parliament and may impress the requirement of natural justice on the operations of the Executive. Finally, the Executive may pardon or remit the sentences of the judiciary and may mellow the statutes of the Parliament by the way it administers them. To this one adds the right of trial by a jury of one's peers and the right to vote. It is these institutions which will ensure the liberties of the people, not a Bill of Rights.

By contrast, set up a Bill of Rights as the standard by which all things are to be judged and there is the risk that the balance will tip too far in favour of one document and the judiciary which is required to interpret it. As the Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, said:
If we live in a caring, humane society, we do not need a Bill or Rights to protect us. If we do not live in such a society, then a Bill of Rights will not protect us even if it is enacted.

Sir Harry Gibbs went on to make the point that Albania, Chad, El Salvador, Haiti and the Khmer Republic all have Bills of Rights. I will leave it to honourable senators to decide for themselves what difference those Bills of Rights have made to the civil liberties and the protection of the individuals in those countries.

The third main reason I oppose the Bill is the features which are peculiar to it. The first aspect of the Bill which is offensive is the rights which it leaves out. As has been said in the debates here and in another place, there is no right to own property. To me, this would seem to defeat the very purpose of the Bill, even on the Government's criteria. Despite what the Labor Party would have us believe, it is not possible to have political freedom if we do not have a measure of economic freedom as well. If we control a man's property or his income, we control the man. If we are able to threaten the economic welfare of a man's family, we will shake him to the very core. One of the great guarantees of the independence of the judiciary in this country has always been that the Government cannot reduce the salary of any member of the judiciary during his period of office. If there is no such economic guarantee for the individual, he will have no real political independence either.

Though this Bill gives the right to associate, there is no converse right not to associate. The Government will not include this measure because it would threaten the closed shop. It seems that the Government would try to save us from all manner of potential but unlikely tyrannies, but when it comes to saving us from a very real tyranny-from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the militant trade union movement-it does not have the courage to do so. Another fault with this Bill is that there is no ability to enforce one's rights when they are transgressed. At least with the common law when a right was transgressed it was the basis for an action.

Article 14 of the Bill requires judges to determine what rights are compatible with the age of a child. This is not, in my view, a question which can be answered by any legal reasoning. The community will come to realise this and there will be a grave danger that the judiciary will fall into disrepute. As decisions are seen to vary from judge to judge, depending on personal opinions, there will be a great temptation to appoint judges for political reasons. Sadly, in the life of the last Liberal Government and in the life of this Government there has been a temptation to make appointments to the High Court of Australia based on the views of the Government as to the preconceived views of judges of the High Court, particularly vis-a-vis centralism and federalism, and the rights of the States compared with the rights of the central Government.

Another fault of the Bill is that it does not really guarantee rights at all. As I said earlier, I do not like attempts to enshrine rights for all time and I do not resile from that position. If, however, the Government is going to tell the people of Australia that this Bill is a guarantee of their rights it is deceiving them knowingly and willingly. There are two ways in which the rights that are given in the Bill can be undone. The first is by the simple legislative enactment of this Parliament. Part III of the Bill even contemplates repealing the rights which are already given in the Bill.

The second way in which the Government has not guaranteed the rights which it would lead people to believe they have is that the judiciary may waive a right given in the Bill of Rights if its effect on another law would be to cause `great public hardship or inconvenience'. So the courts can suspend the rights given. Again, I ask: Is this the type of question which the courts should be asked to answer? Should they be made responsible for determining when there would be sufficient hardship that an Act of the Parliament should be given no effect? Is that really what the judiciary was ever intended to do? Was it ever intended that that onus of responsibility ought to be cast upon the judiciary in a subjective way, requiring it to make subjective judgments? Of course it was not.

The sentiments which are expressed in this Bill are way out of step with the opinions of the community. The way that it is interpreted could engender enormous hostility. Article 7, for example, gives the right of free speech and freedom of the Press in open terms. It makes no mention of the limitations which are rightly imposed by the laws of defamation.

It also makes no mention of the responsibility that people such as teachers have when they are imparting ideas and ideals to their pupils. If this is combined with Article 14 which gives the rights contained in the Bill to children, commensurate with their age, should a teacher want to impart a particular belief to a child and that child wants to receive it, the opinion of the parent as to the appropriateness of what the child is being taught could be totally irrelevant.

The very idea of Article 14, which would make the rights given to a child a decision for someone other than the child's parents is one which would be resented, in my view, by the vast majority of families in Australia. responsibility for children is with the parents of those children and is not to be usurped by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

Article 10 says that every person has the right of peaceful assembly, but makes no mention of any limitation which should be put on this right. Should a large crowd of people have the right of peaceful assembly anywhere they like? Should they be able to do so to the great inconvenience of the rest of the community? Should a trade union be able to blockade a factory allegedly in exercise of its right of peaceful assembly? Would the illegal picket outside the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd factory in Victoria recently have been able to be stopped if this law applied? Even if these provisions do not have the extreme effect which they can have, how many people will be put through the courts needlessly? It is because decisions will normally rest on the facts of the case at hand that will lead many cases to end up in the courts.

My final reason for opposing this Bill is because of the way it will be administered. As Mr Spender has said in another place, so many of the rights which we have come to know are actually taken away when a party is called before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Some of the most basic guarantees are missing. Proposed section 29 of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill will take away the right to be confronted by one's accuser. Should the Commission so decide, it may preserve the anonymity of a complainant or people who have provided information to it. The Commission has the power to compel people to attend compulsory conferences and to produce documents. The Commission has the power under clause 31 (4) to copy documents and to retain them. Interestingly enough, though clause 29 gives the Government the right to certify some of its documents confidential, there are no comparable guarantees for private documents. There is no protection of a private confidential document being revealed in the Commission's report to the Minister. There are many documents which the Government has no right to see. Documents which might contain the political affiliation of the individual involved are one example. No doubt there are other examples.

Under the proposed Bill there is no right to refuse to answer questions which are incriminating. Clause 34 takes away the right of legal representation unless leave of the presiding officer at the compulsory conference is given. What criteria will he use in determining whether or not legal representation ought to be provided? All the rights which the courts have developed over the centuries to ensure a fair and open trial of matters are denied people who have the misfortune to be summoned before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

In addition to the powers that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has been given, it has been given certain tasks which are highly inappropriate for a body with its functions. The Commission is required to promote an understanding of the freedoms set out in the Bill of Rights and to undertake research and educational programs, on behalf of the Commonwealth, promoting the Bill of Rights. How can a body which has these functions then turn around and attempt to impartially consider possible breaches of human rights? Surely the Government can see that to educate and promote a view about human rights is incompatible with the quasi-judicial functions of the Commission. There is no requirement for the Commission to follow the rules of natural justice in the Bill. It is hoped that the courts which have been given no part in the functioning of the Commission will impress the rules of natural justice upon it. It will be the ultimate irony if it is the courts which have to come to the rescue of the citizen who is suffering at the hands of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. As I said at the outset, I do not believe that we are obliged to enact this piece of legislation. Our civil rights record amply satisfies anything that the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights requires. Within our system of government, our freedoms are protected already.

The attempt by the Government to introduce this Bill will only undermine the institutions which we already have. It will do this to introduce a Bill which will not guarantee our freedom as effectively as these institutions do. The rights which the Bill attempts to introduce are not in step with the thinking in the community and for that reason, it will fail. The Government then wants this Bill, which will be damaging and unpopular, to be administered by a commission with extraordinarily draconian powers. Should the Bill be enacted it will be one of the most unpopular ever passed by this Parliament.

There are two other matters that concern me. One is the effect that the legislation will have on the judiciary. It will require our judges to make some very difficult and subjective judgments. One of the most potentially damaging effects of the Bill is the kinds of questions which it places before judges. Our judges, when they act judicially, do not make arbitrary decisions but decide cases according to law. One of the main reasons that respect for our judiciary is maintained, even by unsuccessful litigants, is because of the judges' actual and perceived detachment from the decisions which the courts make. The courts have been recognised so far as being thoroughly impartial. Judges have been deemed to be thoroughly impartial. There has been a preparedness to acknowledge that decisions have been made in that way. When a judge is seen to be not merely applying the rules but making them as well there is no such satisfaction with a decision and acceptance by the parties. This type of situation arises when the law gives no real guidance to the judge but leaves him with open-ended discretion. This is perhaps one of the reasons for the frequent dissatisfaction with the decisions of the Family Court of Australia. Litigants realise that, with the wide discretion given to a judge, a different judge with a different point of view may well have have provided a different result.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was debating the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 when the Senate rose for dinner and I had almost completed my remarks. By way of peroration let me say that in my view there is considerable possibility of a conflict among the Commonwealth, the Commission and the States. That seems even more likely if we remember that every right given to one person imposes a corresponding right on another person to respect it. The decision as to who should be given the right and who should carry the burden of respecting it in a particular case becomes very subjective. This kind of conflict has troubled the law of defamation for decades. How much should a person be allowed to speak his mind before he begins to make an unfair attack on somebody else's reputation could be something that a State could decide in one way and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission could decide in quite a different way.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one other aspect of the origin of this Bill which means that it should be opposed and that is the haste with which it has been enacted and the lack of public discussion which has surrounded it. We have even had the absurd situation in which Senator Gareth Evans produced his infamous Bill of Rights which allegedly was to provide a guarantee of greater freedoms. In fact it was granting a great deal fewer freedoms, and as I recall that Bill was, by any standards, a highly classified document.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you rabbiting on about?

—I am not rabbiting on, Senator Evans; I am simply quoting your classified document, a Bill of Rights which was intended to give rights to everybody. The only trouble was that nobody knew what their rights were. It reminds me of that magnificent emperor who had all the laws of the land written on a pillar which nobody could reach to read.
—My Bill was identical to the Bill before the House.
—It was not identical. With the greatest respect, Senator Evans, you either did not understand your Bill or you do not understand the contemporary Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: If Parliament passes the Australian Bill of Rights Bill it is very likely that it will retard the development of the common law. The eighteenth century and, more particularly perhaps, the nineteenth century was a time of evolution and great growth in the common law. The judges changed the application of the common law to suit the rapidly changing nature of society. By comparison, the twentieth century has been a time of legislation and in my view that is regrettable. Acts passed by the parliaments have represented the greatest changes in the law. This has had an effect on the judges because today they are far less likely to change the common law too frequently. The judges have attempted to follow old and totally inappropriate precedents, believing that it is not their role to change the common law and that if change is needed then parliament should make it. As we know, there are a number of absurd examples. There is Searle v. Wallbank and there is Myers v. The Director of Public Prosecutions. The judges rested their decision very much on common law which no longer had application, purely on the basis that there had been evolution towards the use of legislation as distinct from common law. This is a threat which is presented by the Bill of Rights. Whereas for the past quarter of a century judges have been keen to develop the law of natural justice, they will now see the Bill of Rights as the pre-eminent declaration of rights in Australia. The pressure will be off the judges and rather than working to develop the common law, the courts will more than likely make the Bill of Rights their first and last stopping place. The development of common law will fall very badly behind.

Having said that, I conclude by saying that in my view the architects of this legislation totally lack a sensitivity or understanding of what the Australian community wants and what is in its best interests. The Bill itself is riddled with prejudices and bias and an ideological commitment by one political party and, more particularly, one part of one political party. Should the Bill be enacted it will be one of the most unpopular pieces of legislation ever introduced into this Parliament. Perhaps I could conclude by citing the words of the US Judge Learned Hand who said:

This much I think I know-that a society so riven that the spirit of moderation is gone, no court can save; that a society where that spirit flourishes no court need save: That a society which evades its responsibilities by thrusting upon the courts the nurture of that spirit, that spirit in the end will perish.
In my view this diabolical piece of legislation should be ignominiously cast out of the Senate and never seen again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Walters.
—Out of the frying pan into the fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely I do not have to start by listening to Senator Gareth Evans's odd comments. Perhaps I could start with a higher comment from the Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Harry Gibbs, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: If a society is tolerant and rational it does not need a Bill of Rights; if it is not no Bill of Rights will preserve it.

That is the sort of statement that I believe this Parliament should be noting. The Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 is reminiscent of everything that Senator Gareth Evans has ever had anything to do with. It is reminiscent of the Sex Discrimination Bill which was brought before this Senate just 12 months earlier. Some 40-odd amendments were made before that Bill was finally passed; indeed the whole Bill had to be rewritten. Once again we find that a Bill which Senator Evans originally put up had to be rewritten after he was relieved of his position of Attorney-General. A subsequent Attorney- General has had to rewrite it. One of Senator Evans's interjections in the speech of Senator Crichton-Browne interested me because he claimed that this Bill was the same as his own Bill of Rights Bill. That is not accurate--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is blatantly dishonest.

—Well, certainly it is not accurate. Even so, this Bill bears a lot of his traits and that is the reason why the Australian people are rejecting it in their hundreds and thousands. We in the Opposition understand why Senator Evans was so secretive about his Bill before the 1984 election because he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the context in which passions would be expected to rage fairly high, here in parliament, let alone in the community at large, it would be impossible to have a calm and rational debate on this measure which its significance and importance justifies.

Certainly that is a sham for hiding behind. In effect what he was saying was `I am not going to tell you now, you might not like it and you might not vote for us if I told you. I will save it until after the election when we will bring it in, despite the will of the people'. The secrecy that was involved was only broken because the Premier of Queensland alerted the people, and that was the only reason why we heard anything at all about it. Because Senator Evans was so secretive and so dishonest, and he would not allow the Australian people to know what was in his Bill, that situation arose prior to the election. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) have rushed this Bill through the House of Representatives-
Honourable senators interjecting-

—We know that prior to Christmas this legislation was rushed through the House of Representatives. Honourable members were not given time to debate it; the public was not given time to see it. The Law Council of Australia at that time pleaded with the Government not to push the legislation through. The Government ignored it. During the recess many groups studied the legislation and many people presented documents to us. The Law Council of Australia-a very prestigious organisation-presented a document. The Labor lawyers were very silent on this subject. We have not heard a word from them. I wonder why. The Law Council of Australia did indeed make its presence felt. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard points A, B, C and D in a letter which the Law Council sent to us.
—Is leave granted?
—It is an appropriate courtesy to show those things beforehand.
—I am sorry; I intended to.
—Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Gareth Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

INTERJECT.PARA: (a) The Council's concern that the Australian Bill of Rights permits ``reverse discrimination'' in favour of disadvantaged races and groups. The Council points out that there is no support for this in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

(b) The Council's concern at the wide range of powers given to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and of the secret nature of its investigations. The Council believes that secret investigations are objectionable especially where, as here, there is no right of legal or other representation before the Tribunal.

(c) The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has the potential to be used as a lever to put pressure upon State Governments to change their laws. (d) That the right to refuse to answer questions or provide information on the grounds of self-incrimination has been removed from persons who are summoned before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from those sections A, B, C and D which I have had incorpor- ated I think that other comments made by the Law Council of Australia in that letter bear mentioning. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Although the powers of the Commission in areas other than under the Sex Discrimination Act stop just short of final determination, the powers are themselves so wide-ranging, and the Commission may, in the exercise of them, so seriously effect the position of individual citizens, that the Law Council believes that the legislation in its present form cannot be supported.
The Council continues:
The Law Council is also concerned by the powers given to the Commission to preserve the anonymity of the person who has made a complaint . . .
The Council further continues:
However, the Law Council cannot support legislation which permits, as this legislation does, one body to act as both prosecutor and judge in the same cause.
Other groups have also made statements. The Country Women's Association presented a document to us. I will quote briefly from that letter because I believe it is appropriate. The Association stated:
With a Bill of Rights they would immediately cease to be rights and become political concessions subject to alteration by Parliament.
I believe that is the crux of the reason why we should not have a Bill of Rights. The Institute of Public Affairs (New South Wales) saw fit to distribute a paper in which it stated:
In short, the Bill appears likely to offer nothing but harm to ordinary law-abiding, decent and hard-working citizens and clearly has the potential to undermine social cohesion in Australia.
The Chamber of Commerce and Industry South Australia Inc. is another group which has put forward what it sees as problems. It stated:

This document is a compromise document created with strong influence from Eastern Bloc nations hence the omission of at least two basic elements of human rights-the right to own property, and the freedom to disassociate.
It continued:

. . . the Bill of Rights Bill which allows freedom of association including `the right to form and join Trade Unions' needs a balancing provision within the Bill allowing individuals the `freedom to disassociate' and pursue freely chosen productive employment free from Trade Union coercion, strike action and restrictions.

It is the view of our Chamber that no Bill of Rights, is far preferable to an inadequate and selective Bill of Rights which quite blatantly omits some of the basic principles of our democratic society.

We had comments by the Right to Life Association. The Labor lawyers support them actually in relation to Article 18 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The Law Council states that Article 18 has the potential to come into conflict with laws authorising abortion and that applications may be made to the Human Rights Commission to seek to strike down State abortion laws and to re-open some rulings. Apart from those many groups we have had submissions from many church and education groups and local and State governments and from thousands and thousands of individuals.

The Bill was based on the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. This was ratified in 1966 when many countries were facing grave problems in regard to freedoms. To promote the right of people in those nations to freedoms Australia joined many other countries in signing the covenant. I will now cite figures from Freedom in the World: Political Rights and Civil Liberties by Gastil. It was published in 1984-85, so it is an up-to-date version. It points out that, of 167 independant nations, 19 have the same freedoms as Australia. These nations are measured on a scale of freedoms. These 19 nations have the highest rating for freedoms in political rights and civil liberties. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has the worst record. There are 17 countries, along with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which are rated as having no political rights, no civil liberties and no freedoms. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, along with those other 17 countries, has the worst rating. Libya, a country which I believe is looked on in Australia as having a pretty low freedom rating, actually has more freedoms than the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Yet it is Australia that seems to need the Bill of Rights.

It is quite beyond me why the present Government seems to believe that Australia needs a Bill of Rights while these other countries have not only ratified the covenant but have signed it. Lybia ratified and signed it. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics ratified and signed it. Afghanistan also ratified it-for what that is worth-as did Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, the Democratic Republic of East Germany, Iran, Iraq, Mongolia, Poland and Romania. Is it not ludicrous that these countries, which according to the Freedom in the World document, have no political rights and civil liberties, have signed the International Covenant but do not abide by the Covenant at all, yet we in Australia will be passing a Bill offering Australians supposed rights? This is how the Bill of Rights will work.

Let me now state the example of someone, let us call her Mrs Ann Citizen, who receives in the mail a letter from the Human Rights Commission saying that certain allegations have been made against her and directing her to come to the Commission's office to answer them. When she recovers from the shock, she rings the Commission to find out what it is all about. She asks who made the complaint. The Commission officer says that under section 29 (2) the Commission has decided that she is not entitled to know and that this is confidential. Ann Citizen says: `But that is not fair. I will arrange for my solicitor to accompany me to the office'. The Commission officer says: `Oh no, under section 34 (4) of the Bill of Rights legislation you are not entitled to have legal representation unless we decide that you can. Just come by yourself. By the way, bring documents A and B which we understand you have in your possession. We understand there may also be certain letters. We believe those will help decide the issue'. Citizen Ann says: `They are private documents and private letters'. `But under section 35 (2) (b)', says the Commission officer, `you will be fined or imprisoned if you don't provide the information that we demand even though it may be self-incriminatory'. Ann Citizen then says that she will appeal to the courts because she believes that she is not being shown true justice. Again, the Commission officer says: `No, you don't. That's not possible either, because there is no appeal from the Commission's decision to a court of law'.

People in Australia do not believe one when one tells them that that is what can happen, but it can happen. I have quoted each clause that may be applied in such a case to show the way in which the legislation can work. The result is that we will have enshrined in new legislation all those rights and beliefs which we have always had and which, if violated, can already be dealt with under the common law and the Constitution. To have enshrined in new legislation such rights as freedom of thought, expression and religion, the right to marry and freedom from slavery, if you please, and from torture-basic rights that are so ridiculous that we should not even bother to mention them in Australia-we will now have to give up the rights I mentioned in my example in the case of Ann Citizen.

We will lose the right to know who has made allegations against us. Fancy having to give up that right. A person could know that someone, for a very personal reason, was out to cause mischief to him, yet that person would not be entitled to know who was making the accusations. I have never heard anything like that. It has always been the right of every Australian not to give self-incriminating evidence, and that has been wiped. If the Commission believes that a person has evidence along those lines, it can demand it and that person could be imprisoned for three months if the material is not supplied. That is absolutely extraordinary, that an accused person will lose the right to have a lawyer of his own choice to defend and advise him is abhorrent to the people of Australia. The right to appeal to a higher court on a decision that could result in imprisonment if a person decided not to present certain documents that could be self-incriminating will be denied.

Why has the Government done this? Why has the Government refused to accept the Opposition's amendments, and we moved many amendments in the other place? Why has it refused to accept amendments that include the right to ownership of private land? Just a short time ago, Senator Bolkus laughed when I said that the Chamber of Commerce had--

—There is no point of order.

—I can assure you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that he was here. He laughed when I said that the International Covenant is a compromise document created following strong influence from the Eastern bloc countries. I say to Senator Bolkus: Do not deny you laughed at that suggestion.
—I did not laugh.
—You did. You were sitting there and you laughed when I said it.

Why it will not include the right of private ownership is quite beyond me, unless in its socialist frame of mind it decided that it will not eventually have--

—I am saying that because the Government is already rewriting the Covenant. It has already gone beyond the powers of the Covenant of 1966 in its rewriting of the Articles. Not only will the Government not accept the principle of the right of ownership of private land but also it will not pass the Opposition's proposed amendment to protect someone's right not to join a union. The Bill makes it very clear that associations can be formed and one can join a union. I wonder what is the philosophical problem with giving Australians the right not to join a union? SPEECH.PARA: Why will the Government also not include the right of Australian citizens to allow their children to be educated in a private school? What is the Government's philosophical objection to that? Honourable senators will remember my speech in the debate on the Franklin Dam issue.

—I am sure that Senator Evans will remember it very clearly because I believe that it was the issue that caused him to be thrown out of the Attorney-Generalship. I think he will remember it for the rest of his life. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will remember my speech in the debate on the Franklin Dam issue. You will remember my warnings when Mr Hawke took the Tasmanian Government to the High Court and won the case by a majority of one. You will remember that there were seven High Court judges on that case. The decision was not made on legal grounds at all; it was made on the opinion of the judges. SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General, in his speech to the Labor lawyers, said: `We will fix that'. At least he was honest when speaking before the Labor lawyers. He said: `If the commissioners report that they are concerned about State government legislation, we will bring the State government to heel and we will pass legislation'. May I, as one who tends to oppose increased government powers of most kinds, caution those Labor supporters who may approve of the extension of such powers in this case.
He was concerned. He was the only Labor member who was honest enough to point out to the people what strong powers they were.

I suppose the Bill is so horrific that whenever one gives an example of what can happen, as I have done tonight, most people say: `But why is the Government doing it?' That question may well be asked: Why is the Government doing it? The only answer I can come up with is that I believe that this is not just a centralist government wishing to do away with the rights of the people, as I have explained tonight, but it certainly tends to interfere with State election laws. The Government must state-and Senator Evans must state-the real reason why it is bringing forward this sort of Bill in the Senate. Then the people can assess an honest reason for the introduction of such draconian legislation. The Opposition as a whole will vote against this Bill. Indeed, we will repeal it when we return to government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no wonder that the honourable senator opposite is often referred to as `Senator Mogadon'. She has managed to put this place to sleep tonight. The problem that confronts me tonight is to try to rebut some of the arguments that she put forward. It is hard to do so because, on a very detailed examination of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985, all of those threats to Australian society that she says will emanate from the passing by this Parliament of this Bill do not seem to be there to effervesce and blow up in our faces. Claims about the destruction of family life, the destruction of the school lives of our children, the destruction of the whole constitutional system-all of these evils that Senator Walters, in her isolationism in Tasmania, seems to be concerned about-do not seem to have any basis in the Bill that is before the Senate. The contribution we have just heard is typical of the histrionics of the members of the Opposition. It is no wonder that they are are now sitting on the other side of the chamber with very little prospect of changing sides.

SPEECH.PARA: When one addresses oneself to the Bill of Rights it is worth while to look at the history of it. The whole idea in the Australian context arose in the early 1970s, if not beforehand. It has taken quite some time to come before the Parliament. There has been quite a degree of public debate-to which Senator Gareth Evans, of course, can attest-to get to this stage. Bills were introduced during the days of the Whitlam Government between 1972 and 1975. It took quite some time-five years later, in fact-before a Liberal government ratified the Inter- national Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. In doing so it presented Australia and the Australian Parliament with an obligation in international law not only to respect the Covenant but also to ensure that all persons living within this country have rights as they are set down in the Covenant.

What does it mean? Does it mean this massive destruction of life that Senator Walters referred to? The Covenant and this legislation embody the principle that people in this country will have rights without distinction such as to race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status. The rights would be equal. Since the date of committing ourselves to that Covenant we have committed ourselves to distilling a process through which these enforcement procedures could be applied. We have come a long way down what I believe to be a retrogressive track in respect of that.

Initially we were talking about amending our Constitution to embody civil rights, but not, as Senator Walters says, as every Warsaw Pact country has seen fit to do. Let us look at that great democracy-as those opposite would have us believe-the United States of America. It has embodied in its constitutional system the protection of civil liberties. I ask Senator Walters and Senator Durack: If it is good enough for that country why do we feel that we can do without it? Yet we are not even proposing to amend the Constitution in this instance. We are proposing a piece of legislation which has gone a further four steps down the track from constitutional entrenchment. We are not proposing application to the States. It does not take all that much intelligence to ascertain that point. We are not proposing that the Bill of Rights can be used as a sword in civil and other litigation. We are proposing that it be used as a shield, to use Senator Evans's term; as a defence for an individual, and for an individual against the power of the state, whether that be the Commonwealth Government or a State government, in theory, but in practice, by way of this Bill as it now stands, only in respect of Commonwealth legislation. We are looking at a five-year lead-in period-a period which even the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs found to be excessive-before this legislation can be used in most instances.

We are not proposing revolution. In fact, when one looks at the historical context of the Bill of Rights, we are proposing a marginal, if any, increase in the protection of rights and liberties of Australian citizens. But in doing so we are going at least some way towards meeting our international obligations. The Bill also goes some way towards stating the principles that we, as a parliament, believe our society should follow.

Members of the Opposition have argued very strenuously, both in this place and in the House of Representatives, against the Bill. Their opposition, I believe, has been born out of total ignorance and insensitivity to the plight of individual Australians. They do not understand the powerlessness that comes with poverty. They do not understand the powerlessness that comes with people's inability to have access to the facilities of the state. Of course, they do not. They have never been in the position to have to understand it. When one looks at the background of speakers opposite who have spoken against the Bill, they have always enjoyed the power that comes with privilege. They have never suffered the disadvantages that come with poverty, whether it is poverty in cash, financial assets or information. They have not experienced that and, as a consequence, we get the sort of ignorant contribution that we have had from honourable senators opposite.

They have stated six primary objections to the Bill of Rights and quite a number of ancillary ones. We have been told that we do not need a Bill of Rights because `the common law provides sufficient protection for individual freedoms'. The facts are that the common law does not sufficiently protect individual freedoms. In fact, civil and political rights in this country are those that are left after the exceptions, limitations and interpretations have been dealt to them by the common law. At the moment we do not have protection of freedom of expression. We do not have the right to demonstrate peacefully in all States. As we can see in Queensland in recent days, we do not have the principle of one vote one value. No matter what honourable senators opposite might say, this principle will be further eroded by the aggravated gerrymander in Queensland. If one looks at the gerrymander that has been introduced in recent weeks and compares that to the voting intention in regard to the respective parties in Queensland, one sees that according to the Morgan gallup poll published in the Bulletin of 21 January 1986, the National Party in that State, polling 35 per cent of the vote, will finish up with 56 per cent of the seats in that Parliament. It might interest Senator Walters to know that the Liberal Party will be disadvantaged as much as the Labor Party in this instance. The Liberal Party in that State, with a voting intention of 18 per cent, will finish up with 7.9 per cent of the seats and the Labor Party, with a voting intention of 42 per cent, will finish up with 34 per cent of the seats in that Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this what the Bill is all about?

—Senator Walters might babble on and say: `Is this what the Bill is all about?' The most basic right of any individual living is a democratic system is to be treated equally. One of the most basic rights in that respect is equal participation in the selection of his government. When there is that degree of malapportionment, gerrymander and distortion of the voting system in Queensland, as I have just presented to honourable senators, where one's own party goes down the gurgler because of the immorality and unprincipled actions of the Premier of that State and where representations will be diminished, then the principle of one vote one value does not apply in this country. Senator Walters would not realise that because in her position of privilege she never really needed to be protected by the laws of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the Opposition's first contention. The second objection is that the Bill is an attempt at a constitutional power grab. Senator Walters might laugh at that. She pretends that this is the basic intention of the Bill and that this is a nasty, centralist government that is indulging in a power grab. Let us get some of the facts straight. The Bill does not apply to the States. The Bill is passed constitutionally in a method which has been endorsed by the High Court of Australia as early as 1936, not in recent days, not only in 1983 in the Tasmanian wilderness case, but in 1936. In essence, we are not talking about a power grab by the Federal Government. We are really talking about a grab back by individuals and about giving the individuals rights vis-a-vis their state. In that respect I refer to both State and Federal governments and, once again, in this instance, only in respect of the Federal Government.

The interests of the individual have, for too long, been disregarded in order for governments to be able to operate more easily. Politicians often look for a quick fix that might involve a deprivation of civil liberties in one way or another. We had quite a number of instances of that in recent years both on a State and Federal level. Sadly, in many ways, we have failed as politicians. We have failed to guarantee civil freedoms. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has indicated from time to time where the excessiveness of bureaucrats and the compliance of politicians have led to a deprivation of civil liberties. It is those sorts of activities and protections that we are talking about when we talk about a Bill of Rights. It does not matter what the complexion of the Government is that introduces legislation and passes it.

If we look at our own history we find quite a number of infringements of individual civil rights in the history of our parliamentary system: The white Australia policy was a great deprivation; the corresponding treatment meted out to Aboriginals and ethnic minorities over 20 years to 30 years, if not 200 years in the case of Aboriginals; and the treatment of homosexuals under State laws. Once again, let us look at Queensland and the treatment of people there with homosexual tendencies. There has been a total diminution of civil rights for the unemployed, single parents and migrants, particularly when one looks at Queensland in recent days. There is, in fact, a need for a Bill of Rights. I believe that there is a need for a stronger Bill of Rights than the one proposed now. I also believe that for the minimal advances it makes, it needs to be supported. I am not on my own in this belief. Mr Justice Kirby, who is a noted and very respected justice in the Australian legal system, has recently discussed the shortfalls in the human rights protection area in this country. He stated:

We tend to assume that we in Australia have an impeccable system of legal protection for human rights which is second to none in the world. In short, we are apt to think of our legal protections for the human rights of Australians as a happy blend between British justice and the Australian `fair go'. This illusion is a dangerous one. There is no doubt that our legal protections fall short, in many respects, of internationally accepted standards. That is not to say that we are significantly worse than most countries in the protection of human rights. Far from it. But there is no room for complacency.

Not only is there no room for complacency, but also there is room for developing and increasing protection. As I mentioned earlier, we have international obligations. We choose as governments, and I believe on both sides of the Parliament, to criticise and object to the current system of voting in the Philippines. We have criticised the Marcos regime and quite rightly so. We criticise other countries, whether they be in Central America or other parts of the world. How can we rightfully criticise some of these countries when we tolerate a situation where, as I said, in Queensland Sir Joh can be elected with the same percentage of votes as that received by President Marcos in his recent election? In both respects we are protecting fraudulent governments if we defend either of them.

As I said earlier, this is not a radical step. To give some credence to that I would like to refer, very briefly, to a report forwarded to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs inquiry on a Bill of Rights. It is a submission from a radical organisation referred to as the Young Liberal Movement of Australia, Victorian division.
