Let me quote some parts of the report for the illumination of honourable senators opposite and expose the hypocrisy of some of the honourable senators opposite. Page 4 of the submission to the Senate inquiry-an inquiry which continued through much of last year and reported at the end of last year-states:

For a truly effective Bill it should be national (applying to states and Commonwealth) but this could create the objection of those who defend `states rights'. The reply to this is that a Bill of Rights at Commonwealth level does not increase central power at the expense of the states. Rather, it limits the powers of both levels of government. It was Thomas Jefferson who made the famous statement that `a Bill of Rights is what the people are entitled to against every government on earth.'

That is the guiding principle of the Young Liberals. It is a pity they change suits and philosophies as they walk into this Parliament. I continue to quote the submission which I think is rather interesting and should be quoted in some length. It states:
It is also important that Federal measures should not infringe upon constructive developments in some states . . .
The Young Liberals are addressing their submission in this part to what could have been a Bill of Rights applying to the States. The submission continues:

. . . it is not necessary nor possibly even desirable for the Commonwealth to cover the whole field. A provision could be contained in a Bill of Rights to allow state legislation or state Bills of Rights which are capable of operating concurrently with the national Bill if they further the desired objectives.

The Young Liberal movement is contemplating a stronger Bill of Rights than the one for which we are experiencing histrionics from those on the opposite side, and they do go on as to whether we are doing this legally and properly or whether we are abusing the power under the Constitution. The Young Liberals have got some very clear views on this matter. The submission states:

Any Bill of Rights as legislation of the Commonwealth Parliament would be based largely on the external affairs power-the validity of which has been placed beyond all doubt by the Tasmanian Dam Case (The Commonwealth v. Tasmania (1983) 57 ALJR 450).

It does not dispute the validity of that sort of power and approach. We do not have to look at the left wing organisations to get some support for this particular approach to protecting civil liberties in this country, nor do we have to look at extreme right wing ones solely in opposition to an approach to protect civil liberties. We can look at an organisation such as the Victorian branch of the Young Liberal Movement of Australia and get support from it. We are not looking at a radical, revolutionary measure to destroy the constitutional system as we now have it. I mentioned the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It should also be noted, in the context of making an assessment of what sort of legislation we have before us tonight, that the Committee unanimously decided that if we were to have a Bill of Rights in Australia it should have some application to the States. As I have said, and I have to repeat time and again to get the context accurate, the Bill before the Parliament does not do that. It was the unanimous attitude of senators that if we were to go along the path of a Bill of Rights, given the fact that most cases of infringement of civil liberties involve some sort of State laws or State administration, that particular aspect should not be excluded from the ambit of the Bill of Rights. State laws are those which normally infringe upon freedom of expression, freedom of assembly or the criminal pro- cess rights. State laws often are barriers, whether they are intended to be or not, to ethnic, religious or linguistic minorities enjoying their group rights under the International Covenant. I believe that it is unfortunate that we have not chosen to heed the advice of the Standing Committee to extend the ambit of the Bill of Rights to cover these provisions. However, be that as it may, as a marginal increase this Bill should be supported.

I emphasise once again that this Bill is not a revolutionary, radical measure. It presents at a national level a body which will have an educative role and it gives us legislation which will act as a touch-stone in the interpretation of legislation which seeks to protect civil liberties in this country. Most importantly, it will limit the power of the national Parliament to enact laws inconsistent with it and to that extent it will protect the rights of individuals vis-a-vis the national Parliament. I do not see what members of the Opposition are jumping up and down about and why they are not concerned to give individuals rights against the parliamentary system which, over the years, given the entrenchment and the bureaucracy which has built around it, given the self-protection involved in those bureaucracies, has often forgotten the individual. I commend the Bill to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In a front page article in the Age of 8 December 1984 Michelle Grattan quoted a leading citizen of this country in an interview in the Catholic Leader. He said that the Bill raised enormous issues. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: All this Bill is trying to do is to hang on to an international covenant. It cannot alter the Constitution. It cannot override acts of Parliament. It can't entrench anything.
He finished by saying:
With these enormous issues, these problems it's got, I reckon the sensible thing to say about the Bill of Rights is: `This is causing too much contention. Why go ahead with it? Scrap it.'

That leading Australian citizen is now the Attorney-General, the Hon. Lionel Bowen. I could not agree more. Yet the Attorney-General, who less than 18 months ago advised us to scrap it, has now introduced and rammed through the House of Representatives, using the numbers game, the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and associated Bills-the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill-which have become known as the Australian Bill of Rights. No other debate, since I have been in this chamber, has attracted so much attention or so many speakers. At last count over 30 have spoken. Every one of my colleagues in the National Party of Australia has taken part in this debate. It comes as no surprise to everybody that we are diametrically opposed to it and I am continuing that opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that the quality was not matched by the quantity.

—Considering the great number of speakers, the quality of the debate has been quite good up to this point. Quite often we find in a long debate that the quality starts to drag off towards the end. The quality of the debate from the Opposition has been of a pretty high standing all the way through. It has been indicated that this package of human rights Bills is based on the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which was adopted by the United Nations in 1966. Senator Peter Durack mentioned that fact in an article in the Australian. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the covenant was to advance throughout the world (a world largely composed of dictatorships of the Right or Left-many of a murderous disposition) the rights and freedoms which had been developed and enjoyed for many generations by democracies such as our own.

Senator Durack, in a few succinct words, was telling us about the International Covenant and why we were original signatories to it. At the same time he said that there was very little need for us to have a Bill of Rights in Australia. Quite significantly it has been mentioned by many Opposition speakers that the countries of the world who are signatories to a Bill of Rights, or which have their own Bill of Rights, are not known as being paragons of virtue as far as the civil rights of their own citizens are concerned. Senator Walters, the Opposition speaker who preceded me, mentioned quite a few of those countries, such as the Warsaw Pact countries. No-one in his right mind would say, even though the citizens of those countries have a Bill of Rights, that they have the rights and privileges that we take for granted in this great country of ours.

If the Government goes down the track of the Bill of Rights-we understand that it has been the Government's party policy since 1969 and that it has a philosophical bent towards these things-the immediate question is: What is the extra benefit? What will it add to the quality of life in this country? Government members who have spoken in this debate have not been able to answer that question adequately or at all. It will add nothing. Members of the Opposition, including myself, say that not only will it not add anything, but also it will subtract from the quality of life. There will be an added chance of mischief with the expanded Human Rights Commission when somebody makes a spurious complaint against another citizen.

All Australians currently enjoy the protection of an independent judiciary under a common law system and a Parliament which is freely elected and responsible to the electors. It is a system inherited from the British common law system which is adaptable, evolutionary and has stood the best test of all, the test of time. It has the dual role of protecting the citizens while at the same time provides a maximum amount of individual freedom. I have always said, and many people in the Opposition have said, that the minute one starts to define people's rights, one immediately limits them. The proponents of this Bill argue that under the common law system a government is bound only by tradition and it is under no legal obligation to continue the rights that we now have. If such a government were in power, it would be extremely doubtful that any Bill of Rights would restrain it from bad behaviour. The common law system does not define an exhaustive list of what can be done, but such a list is intimated under this legislation. The common law allows each case to be treated on its merits and case precedents established over many years. The determinant is what society really believes is reasonable. My colleague, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, mentioned the words of the late Sir Robert Menzies. I quote again:
To live in a common law country is in itself the very best guarantee of the rights of the individual.

We knew that a Bill of Rights was around the ridges. Senator Gareth Evans, when he was Attorney-General, was dropping hints about it. We can thank Premier Joh Bjelke-Petersen for warning the people, just prior to the 1984 election, of what was involved in that Bill of Rights. It was a great embarrassment to the Government at that time and was one of the many things which saw its election majority severely cut back.

However, we now have the Bill of Rights and associated Bills before us. As I said earlier, they have literally been rammed through the House of Representatives using the numbers game. They were guillotined through. There was insufficient debate on the legislation generally, the clauses of the legislation and the amendments that the Opposition sought to move. Because of a lack of interest by the media it was hard to get a point of view over as to what the legislation was all about. However, the people of Australia are now waking up. There probably has been no piece of legislation in the 10 years that I have been in this chamber that has attracted so many speakers as this legislation has. Also I do not think I have been subject to such a concentrated campaign through the mail as I have in the last few weeks, particularly the last few days, from the people of Australia, who are showing their concern about the Bill of Rights and its contents. In hundreds of letters and telegrams being received by individual senators day by day as a result of this mailing campaign people are indicating their opposition to the Bill of Rights. I think we were almost taken by surprise today when we got one out of literally thousands of letters which was in favour of a Bill of Rights.

Quite a number of senators quoted an article-I think Senator Bjelke-Petersen did this-that I think originally appeared in the Toowoomba Chronicle. Many papers in the provincial areas of Queensland have taken up this article. Obviously it appeared in the South Burnett Times, a great paper which represents a great area of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly the best.

—A responsible citizen and senator also resides in that area! Significantly, quite a deal of space was devoted to that article in papers right around Queensland. I think that article has been as responsible as anything else for waking up the people of Australia, the people of Queensland particularly, to what the Bill of Rights is all about and it started them on their writing campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the Opposition has opposed the creation of a Bill of Rights. It has put up tremendously good arguments over a long period and our opposition will continue when this legislation is dealt with at the Committee stage. It is significant that the Government has used this Bill as a vehicle to once again blast Queensland's electoral laws, demonstrations and all the rest of it. Not once did honourable senators opposite seek to mention the disparity in the New South Wales electoral system. Most countries have weightage systems which favour rural electorates. The demography of Australia is such-I think I once worked out that about 70 per cent of the population live within 30 kilometres of the coast-that it probably needs a weightage system more than any other nation. Yet members of the Government seem hell-bent on imposing a system of one vote one value. Queensland has quite significantly followed a weightage system that was introduced by a Labor government. New South Wales had a similar scheme-instead of four zones I think it had three-which operated for many years. Yet because we have fought and beaten the Labor Party in Queensland using its own rules, Labor now wants to change the rules. Incredibly, the weightage in New South Wales is towards the city electorates. I would like to give four examples to illustrate the number of electors in country areas as against city electorates in New South Wales as at September 1985. The country electorates of Coffs Harbour and Gosford had 42,148 and 43,285 respectively, whereas the city electorates of Coogee and North Shore had 29,183 and 30,084 respectively. So there are in excess of 10,000 more electors in country electorates than in city electorates in New South Wales. Yet we have the Labor Party lecturing us when we have done no more or no less than it did in New South Wales. Queensland is doing no more or no less than is being done in other democracies of the world by accepting the need for weightage in favour of country electorates.

Senator Bolkus also mentioned what has become known as the street march laws and argued that somehow or other this Bill would remedy that situation. I find it very hard to accept the proposition put forward by the Labor Party that the Bill of Rights would mean that the minority would have the right of way over the majority. All the Queensland Government has done has been to say that it does not believe that a minority should disrupt people who want to work and shop-people engaged in the natural process of commerce. We do not believe that these people should be interrupted by a minority. The Queensland Government said: `We will make available to you a place in which you can hold your demonstrations'. People in Brisbane can use the very fine Roma Street forum to protest against the government of the day or against anything else. Indeed, most responsible organisations which, it would be fair to say, protest against the Queensland Government or some action of the Queensland Government use that place. They see fit to use the places provided for them. However, there is always the minority who want to take to the streets, particularly at a time of peak hour traffic, and cause the greatest disruption. All that has happened is that the Queensland Government has said: `No, you cannot do that'. Yet I understand from what was said by Senator Bolkus that the minority could use the Bill of Rights and insist that they interrupt the majority as they go about their business.

Australia is a great country. I am no different from any other person. I do not feel the need for a Bill of Rights. I do not have any problem with the law except perhaps a bit of over- exuberance with the right foot in my motor vehicle. However, I will not go down the track of discussing the way in which I think policemen are being used by governments as tax collectors. Other than that, I am no different from the vast majority of the people of Australia. I am free to do what I like provided I do not harm another person. The statutes of this land revolve around defining what I cannot do if I am not to harm another person. Like countless other people in this great country of course, I do not see any need, I do not feel any need, and never at any time in my life have I felt the need, for the Bill of Rights to protect me from anything. I join all other members of the Opposition in saying once again that we are diametrically opposed to this Bill of Rights. We see no need for it; there is no need for it; and none of the Government speakers has proved that there is a need for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin my speech by seeking to refute some of the points made in the debate by honourable senators on the other side of the chamber and by some Australian Democrat speakers, particularly in respect of the need to refer this matter to a committee. The point made by many speakers on the other side is that the campaign of letter writing and obvious concern in the community is based on a series of misconceptions, that people have been misled, that falsehoods have been spread and so on. I think there has been no direct attempt to suggest that the Opposition has sought to mislead any one. Of course, I would deny it with great vigour. However, there has been a suggestion from the Government benches that the opposition to this legislation is based totally and overwhelmingly on misinformation, on deceit, on deception and on a campaign that is not based on truth. If those suggestions are made seriously, I suggest that, of all the arguments, to refer this matter to a committee is probably the most effective. If in fact there is massive misinformation, if there is a massive lack of understanding and confusion, clearly there is no merit in proceeding with this legislation at this moment, and it is most appropriate from the Government's own case that it be referred to a committee for appropriate and detailed examination. That being the case-in other words, the Government's position being totally undermined by its own approach to this discussion-let us see how inaccurate, how improper, the general level of these submissions by people really is. For example, I have here a letter from a constituent which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir,
I am given to understand that in the next session of Parliament the proposed Bill of Rights is to be presented before the Senate to be debated. I wish to voice my protest at this proposed Bill.
I assume that many other senators have received similar letters, but I think it is important that this protest, this kind of complaint, be recorded in Hansard. The letter continues:

(1) Because of the fact that it adversely affects areas of great importance to freedom and liberty and because of the haste with which this legislation was passed through the House of Representatives.

(2) In view of the fact that it is based upon the United Nations International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights which was accepted by the Warsaw pact countries, but which has been rejected by Great Britain and the United States of America.

(3) Our Australian Constitution limits the power and rights of government stating that ``whereas we the people'' give you the government these rights. However, the proposed Bill of Rights states that ``we the government, give you the people these rights.'' At present our rights are protected by Common Law, the present Constitution and current legislation. The Bill of Rights reverses the nature of government in this country.

(4) The proposed Bill transfers the power of interpretation of legislation to the Courts (an unelected body of people) taking said power of interpretation of legislation from the Parliament of Australia (the democratically elected institution.)

(5) This same Bill of Rights is to be administered by the Human Rights Commission which is an unelected body of people given powers not subject to the normal processes of law-no appeal, no legal representation, and with closed hearings.
I therefore write to request that you vote to reject this proposed Bill of Rights.

If that letter represents confusion and lack of understanding, why should not the Government welcome any suggestion of a greater course of public education and seek a greater consensus on the matter, instead of rushing this legislation through the House of Representatives as it did, certainly without adequate discussion, and now seeking to get it through here. I think that it is important to note the comment in paragraph 3 of this letter about where the original rights reside. I think it is a fair point to say that in our society it is assumed that the basis of our rights is in fact the individual rights that we have and that we transfer these to the community in order to seek offsetting benefits, that we give up certain individual rights in order to achieve others, but we are the possessors of those rights. The people are the fount from which these rights spring, not governments. For any government to have the arrogance to assert that it will give people rights, that it is the source of rights, is to me a total nonsense.

I think it is worth making another general point. In many instances the granting of rights and the imposition of laws aimed at protecting people have contrary consequences. I am reminded that under Roman law, for example, it was illegal to kill a virgin. That, I presume, was aimed at trying to prevent the murder of young girls. I think it was one of Agrippina's daughters who was to be killed. As a result, it was necessary, under the law, for her to be raped before she was killed so that her death would not infringe the Roman law. I make that as a general point. What is perceived to be in many instances the protection of a right simply induces people to find ways around that alleged protection. In other words, we do not protect rights by putting into law what appears to be legislation that protects them.

This raises the next inevitable point, that is, that prescribing rights by establishing what they are generally, in effect, limits them. This follows naturally from the example I used of Roman law. Certainly in the commercial area the threat of law, the threat of constraint, is often more effective than the ultimate constraint itself when at last imposed.

As every honourable senator here knows, once a regulatory law is introduced the people who are affected by it simply spend their time working out how to get around it. They look to the law and say: `if that is what the law says, anything the law does not say is therefore legal'. Instead of having the moral constraint of decent and proper behaviour, which in our society has in the past been far more effective than any black letter law, we now have a situation in which, because proper behaviour is legislated for, it is therefore assumed that any behaviour which can be seen not to be so legislated against is acceptable.

One of the unfortunate developments in Australian society at the moment is that there is a tendency for lawyers-I do not want to be unkind to my many legal friends-to be engaged in commercial enterprises in which they appear to be spending a great deal of their time involved in finding out how to establish that a course of action can be achieved legally. There is an old saying that lawyers should always be on tap but never on top. It seems to me that the greater the development of legislation controlling behaviour in these areas, the greater the diminution of proper moral behaviour, the greater the diminution of the thing which dominated commercial business life, and that was that people behaved, to use the old fashioned term, like gentlemen, that it was not done, that a man's word was his bond and all those propositions which are now clearly not acceptable in the modern world, largely, I suggest, as a result of this incredible mad rush to legislate when in many instances it would be a far more acceptable, far more preferable, conclusion if the moral laws, the moral suasion, was allowed to be the major instrument.

There are many instances where legislation is required. I am not suggesting that one should totally withdraw from legislating. I am simply making the point that it seems to me that in many of the areas covered in this legislation the need for black letter law does not exist, and black letter law will prescribe and therefore limit rights. This is the essential point to me. Just as many businessmen will seek to get around the constraints of commercial law once they are put down, so will a tyrannical centralist government. Let us face it, the Australian Labor Party is a centralist party and, judging from the sound that certain honourable senators opposite make, some of them have the potential to be tyrants. The reality is that a tyrant can quite simply and easily get around the black letter law allegedly preserving the rights of individuals just as a commercial adventurer gets around the laws relating to commercial misbehaviour. I suggest that the Roman law example I gave earlier is a clear indication of what would happen.

I refer briefly to some of the points that were made by Senator Sir John Carrick in what I thought was a very persuasive speech. He noted that the socialist states had not allowed the inclusion of many rights in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights when it was passed by the United Nations. As I understand it, this Convention excluded from the Bill of Rights such things as the right to private ownership. I can understand why the Labor Party would not favour the right to private ownership. One has only to go to New South Wales where the private rights acquired by many people, at great expense, to coal under their properties were expropriated by that Government only a few years ago. Not one cent of compensation has been paid, nor is it likely to be paid, despite promises, because we all know what a Labor Party promise is like. It is no wonder that members of the Labor Party, who are sitting temporarily on the Government benches, are certainly very happy to see a so-called Bill of Rights which affords no protection at all to the rights of private ownership.

As Sir John pointed out, the proposed legislation does not protect the right to lawful trade or occupation and the right not to join an association. In other words, the Labor Party would clearly not favour any Bill of Rights which gave an individual in Australia the right not to be a member of a union. It cannot do that because the Australian Council of Trade Unions would not allow it to do so. So we have here clear examples of where, deliberately by the Labor Party, these rights are being excluded from the legislation. As I suggested earlier, the exclusion of specific rights from such legislation may well be held to indicate that they do not exist and that they should not be an important part of our society when in fact they are being savagely attacked, as Mr Wran savagely attacked them in New South Wales by expropriating those coal rights. It is important to recognise that when certain clear rights are excluded from this kind of legislation there is an inference that they are not sufficiently significant to be in such legislation and, therefore, are not in need of protection. But that exists only if one accepts the proposition that there is any need for the legislation in the first place. That is one of the points I wish to discuss now. Is there a need for this legislation?

There are many societies in which the group right is regarded as more important than the individual right. We have seen that through history. We see it in current days. I suggest that in nations such as Indonesia, where there are 100 million people crowded on to one small island of Java which, I think, is smaller than Victoria, it is self-evident that their society considers that the group right, with so many people crowded there, is more important than the individual right. No matter how offensive we may find that, nonetheless it appears that the way they have established historically is the way to run their society successfully. Through history we have seen many examples of the group right being far more significant than the individual right. Where there are conflicts between these two-that is, the group right and the individual right-clearly we have difficulties when we look at human rights legislation.

I argue a further point that the whole concept of human rights as seen in this legislation which, of course, stems from the United Nations Convention, is basically a nonsense because it confuses the concept of natural or human rights-in other words, civil liberties-which, of course, are clearly the enemy of the state. The greatest risk to civil liberties comes from the intrusive state. It confuses these rights with the socio-economic rights which are, in fact, granted by the state. So, on the one hand, one has civil liberty rights, human natural rights, which the state generally impinges on and which involve people being in conflict with the state generally, as against the socio-economic rights which are granted by the state. This Bill fails to distinguish between these two rights.

The reality is that these two separate kinds of rights are often in conflict. The political situation in Australia suggests this. The ALP tends to consider, in its legislation at least if not in its rhetoric, that the socio-economic rights are paramount whenever there is a conflict between civil rights and socio-economic rights. In the ALP's terms, socio-economic rights would be paramount, whereas the Liberal Party tends to the view that civil rights, individual rights, are paramount in those conflicts. As far as this legislation is concerned, there is no difference when, of course, there is a monumental difference both in nature and in consequence between these two kinds of rights. I am indebted to a very interesting paper prepared recently by Professor Eugene Kamenka about human rights. He pointed out that a marxist legal philosopher, Herman Klenner, in a paper circulated at the World Congress on Philosophy of Law and Social Philosophy held in Sydney and Canberra in August 1977, said:

Human rights are neither eternal truths nor supreme values . . . They are not valid everywhere nor for an unlimited time. They are rooted neither in the conscience of the individual nor in a God's plan of creation. They are of earthly origin . . . a comparatively late product in the history of human society-and their implementation does not lie in everybody's interest. In their essentials, man's interests are not the same everywhere and they cannot even be the same in any particular country under the conditions of the system of private ownership of the means of production.

That in itself indicates quite clearly that the claim of universality over the human rights on which this Bill now rests is a nonsense claim because, in fact, these are conflicting rights. They are not the same for different people, even within the same society. Kamenka continued:

The UNESCO campaign to promote human rights, being an international campaign directed at all countries and people, has been accompanied by an understandable attempt to deny or to soft-pedal the suggestion that the belief in human rights as a great moral value is a specifically western or Judaeo-Christian contribution to the world. On the contrary, it is claimed, such a belief is to be found in all the great moral documents of mankind, and in all its aspirations since primitive times.
As Kamenka says, that is simply untrue. He continued:

If the concept of rights is to have any specific meaning, is to be not an empty abstraction but a concept that involves and promotes a view of man and society . . . The concept of human rights is a historical product which evolves in Europe, out of foundations in Christianity, Stoicism and Roman law . . . but which gains force and direction only with the contractual and pluralist nature of European feudalism, church struggles and the rise of Protestantism and cities. It sees society as an association of individuals, as founded-logically or historically-on a contract between them, and it elevates the individual human person and his freedom and happiness to be the goal and end of all human association.

That is a totally separate concept of rights from these socio-economic rights which the Government manages to confuse with human rights. Kamenka says that the Greeks, like the Chinese, saw man in a familial social and cosmic setting and their concern was not with rights but with duties, balance, harmony, Confucian rights and ceremonies with a balance that transcended the individual. They saw society as part of a great cosmic pattern resting on a network of obligations, not just to individuals but to forces and institutions, human and divine, that shaped and transcended such individuals. Even in Roman law, as the Romans and their immediate successors knew it, there was a concept of right and duties, but no concept of rights. The growing belief in natural or human rights, as those in the eighteenth century saw them, is the story of the rise of individualism and the theory and practice of society. The eighteenth and nineteenth century emphasis on human rights was, it is often said, on those human rights that are called civil liberties and the chief enemy of human rights was seen as the state. We can see that in the way that the Australian Labor Party tends to govern. It has an intrusive style of government; the state tends to intrude on civil liberties and rights of individuals in order to provide, in its view, the socio-economic rights that the Labor Party considers paramount.

By the end of the nineteenth century all those who were hoping for radical reform of Western society, or of other societies, through state-initiated action, began to recognise that the classical conception of human or natural rights stood in the way of such State action. There is absolutely no doubt about it-the granting of these socio-economic rights involved a clear conflict with traditional human rights and civil liberties. Movements developed, like Marxism and utilitarianism, which saw human rights as fundamentally subordinate to other values, or treated them with great suspicion. That is of major significance because it is in those societies which have developed from those kinds of attitudes that one finds acceptance of this Bill of Rights and the underwriting of and support for this Bill of Rights, and that support relates not to the human rights as we understand them-the civil liberties-but to the socio-economic rights. I would suggest that these are clearly in conflict; the history of the world shows them to have been in conflict and the Liberal Party, by its tradition, has been the defender of these individual civil liberty rights, not the socio-economic rights which the Labor Party holds paramount.

Since the Second World War there has been a great emphasis on human rights other than classical civil liberties, according to Kamenka. The emphasis has been on socio-economic rights and on the rights of groups or classes or nations. The recognition that the promotion of socio-economic rights, as rights to benefit from the State, stand in great tension with civil liberties may be often deliberately obscured, but it is nevertheless widespread and it is, of course, a correct recognition. The traditional civil liberties, many have correctly recognised, require institutional settings, historical traditions and a sense of community. Those do not exist in any of the authoritarian nations of the world which have embraced the covenant on which this legislation is based. The socio-economic rights can, in principle, be granted by the state, even by a state which suppresses all non-state organisations and institutions, says Kamenka. Of course, that is really what this Bill of Rights is all about. It has nothing to do with natural human civil liberty rights, it has to do with the socio-economic rights which are the dogma of the Labor Party and which are the acceptable tradition of those authoritarian and totalitarian nations which have no concern for individual rights.

According to Kamenka, some of the current demands are for an extension of the traditional eighteenth century conceptions of individual autonomy against previously exempted institutions, such as the family and the school and to people such as women and children, to whom these rights were not always applied. Other demands-that is, demands for group rights and for social and economic benefits claimed as rights-are demands in substance for far-reaching state control and intervention at the expense of other individual rights. Surely this is the crux of any discussion of human rights: To what extent are the rights of civil liberty, of individual natural rights, limited by the move which many of us may argue is important, the move towards some other rights, socio-economic rights and group rights. These are rights which become prominent only because of effective lobbying-the `squeaky hinge syndrome' of specific lobby groups represented in most instances by the Australian Democrats. The Democrats are not represented here in the chamber at the moment. They are so concerned for human rights they are not here. But it is interesting to note that in many instances there is a perception of the need to grant these socio-economic rights, not because of the merit of the case but because of the squeakiness of the hinge and the political clout of the people concerned, particularly when they may hold the balance of power in a parliament.

The reality is that where there is a conflict in those instances between what we understand as the natural rights, the human rights that have been developed in our style of society, members of the Labor Party and in many instances the Australian Democrats will prefer to do something that damages our inherent human rights and it seems to me that this legislation goes straight down that path. As Kamenka says, the current substitution of `human' for the word `natural' in the concept of natural rights is a recognition of the fact that belief in the law of nature is not strong today. But the doctrine of human rights still attempts to suggest without specifically stating it that rights are, in some essential sense, part of the concept of being human. Kamenka points out that when we say that X has a human right to Y, rather than a legal right under a specific code or set of laws in a specific society, we are making not an empirical but a moral assertion.

I have to say this: I would much rather that our rights depended on a moral recognition, a historic recognition of what we are as people, rather than a legal, limiting, prescribing black letter law which states what those rights are specifically and by exclusion indicates that many of the other things that we now hold to be rights are not such. It seems to me that the very concept of this legislation is in error; the very approach by the Labor Party in supporting it is authoritarian and puts at risk those human and natural rights, those civil liberties which I, frankly, hold far more dear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most important subjects that we could be debating is how basic human rights should be best protected. Therefore, it is not surprising that there has been such a long speaking list in this debate. The Senate's own Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs sought to contribute to this debate by an exposure draft put down late last year. In a dispassionate and objective way the Committee sought to address the debate, not in terms of any particular Bill and certainly not in terms of this Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985, but in terms of the issues involved. These issues of whether a statutory Bill of Rights is the best way to further preserve and enhance human rights are complex in themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: The constitutional entrenchment, the regulation of both past and future legislation, the involvement of the States-whether the States should be bound-whether such a Bill of Rights should bind private individuals as well as the States and whether it should also bind the Executive, what exemptions are legitimate, questions of enforcement and remedies are all complex and worthy of serious consideration. I remind the Senate that that is what the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs attempted to do late last year, and to which I contributed. I hope that we assisted the Senate to that end.

There are many precedents for Bills of Rights as the Senate heard earlier in this debate. The United States Bill of Rights is the one most often referred to, and some seem to think it is the only precedent. Clearly, that is not so. Many of Britain's former colonies now have Bills of Rights. Probably the one most relevant to our consideration in this debate, and to which we should pay particular attention, is the recent Canadian Bill of Rights. That is the most relevant because of the considerable similarity of the federal system in Canada to our system. Therefore, it is important to examine how that country has attempted to wrestle with the questions which our proposed legislation should deal with. I remind the Senate that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs addressed all of these questions and others in an effort to reduce the hysteria which seems to surround this subject.

I have concluded that a Bill of Rights is not the best way to go in this country, but it is clearly a legitimate option to be considered. It deserves serious debate and debate based on facts not on hysteria. A serious study of the subject brings home just how fragile is the base for the fundamental rights which we take for granted in this country. We certainly take them for granted. No doubt we take them for granted because of the very nature of the society in which we live. We put that point in the report to which I referred right at the beginning of my speech. Point 1.2 of the report stated:

As Australians we are fortunate to live in a democratic and pluralistic society which, by any standards, accords a high respect to the dignity of the individual and which recognises many rights and freedoms consequent on that dignity,

As soon as a society takes for granted something so precious, I suggest, it puts at risk that which it sees as so precious. In fact, what the Committee did was to address what our fundamental rights are and to examine critically, but constructively, the complex of laws, institutions and traditions which we have to protect them. The fact that we were criticised even for doing that causes me and some others to wonder about the security of such safeguards.

We looked at the constitutionally entrenched provisions. Earlier in this debate I heard honourable senators say that our Constitution protects fundamental human rights, but we found very few such protections in our Constitution. Of those that exist, electoral guarantees in section 41, just terms for compulsory acquisition of property in section 51, placitum (xxxi), jury trials in section 80, and freedom of religion in section 116 have been interpreted by the courts extremely narrowly. A study of the matter reveals that the security offered by the Constitution simply is not what some might expect. Our Constitution has not been structured to protect such basic human rights. Therefore, we do not find such protection in that document.

The Committee logically then looked at the role of the courts and the common law. Again, we hear and read so often in correspondence on this matter that all we need to rely on is the common law and that human rights are adequately protected by the common law. Again, in a quiet and logical study of the role which the common law has played in this area we find that that also is not so. We attempted in our report to give credit where credit was due to the common law. We made reference in the field of administrative law to the extensions of areas of natural justice and to the procedural safeguards developed in the criminal law. We again pointed out the shortfalls. To say that protection of fundamental rights is safeguarded in the common law is clearly invalid. I remind the Senate that in point 2.33 of the report we stated:

Many Australians think that the common law protects their fundamental rights. However, fundamental rights such as the right to vote, the right to practise religion freely, and the right to seek employment without being discriminated against on account of race or sex are not recognised at common law.

The report then looked at the relevant court decisions which tended to substantiate what had just been said in the report. We looked at the role of the Parliament and of legislation. I guess the Parliament has been modestly active in this area, if I can put it in those terms. We have seen, through legislation, the setting up of the Office of the Ombudsman and the Freedom of Information Act and other Acts of that nature to protect individuals from abuse of government power. We certainly do not find any comprehensive legislative program adopted in this country to protect our basic human rights. The conclusion that we reached-we believe unemotionally and logically-was that protections for basic human rights are not clearly enumerated or embodied within the Constitution of Australia, its legislation or the common law.

Rather than enact our own individual national set of basic human rights in this country we have become part of the international regime for the protection of human rights. I applaud that approach. In other words, we recognise that these rights are a basic entitlement of man. We claim that they arise from the dignity and individuality of man and therefore should be respected, are basic rights to which individuals throughout the world community should be entitled, and are not rights which simply are developed from time to time by a state for that state's interests. The function of nation states within the world community-logically one could say this follows-is to protect those rights in such ways as is necessary within their own domestic structures. Australia has embraced the international regime for the protection of human rights, I am pleased to say, both in fact and in practice. I make reference to what I believe is an excellent background information paper prepared last year by the Parliamentary Library which looked at the history of this subject. At the bottom of page 12 of this paper it is stated:

Since 1945, over 40 international conventions on human rights have been adopted, covering slavery, forced labour and traffic in persons; marriage and family life; the protection of labour in industry, agriculture and shipping; freedom of the Press; the protection of prisoners and civilians in armed conflict. Most of these conventions have either renewed or elaborated in older conventions but the significant new conventions were the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.

In fact, I know that some people who have written on the subject now claim that over 60 different conventions cover various aspects of internationally accepted basic human rights. As I say, the Australian way basically has been to adopt those conventions through the ratification procedure and by putting them into practice. If we compare our action with that of the United States, for example, we will see that it has not been prepared to become party to, say, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights because it has argued that its domestic Bill of Rights efficiently serves that purpose. If we look at some other countries that have become parties to the covenants we see that regrettably, as some of my colleagues have said, some countries, particularly some of the Eastern bloc countries, have become parties in fact but certainly have not complied in practice with either the spirit or the detail of those conventions. It has been something of pride that in Australia not only have we been prepared to become a party to this international recognition and regime but also have practised the principles.

I do not claim, naturally enough, that the international covenants are perfect or that they are the product of any perfect being. They have the marks and failings of politics and compromise. However, I think on a dispassionate reading of the documents they are not a bad set of basic principles to adhere to. Given that we are a party to that international regime, and that that is the way that we have chosen in the past to go about protecting such rights, the question has become and becomes in this debate one of how best to meet our responsibility thereunder.

Apart from introducing specific pieces of legislation to deal with specific enforcements-I mentioned a couple a while ago, and I add the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, which is principally under another covenant-the approach of the former Liberal-National Party Government was to enact the Human Rights Commission Act. The logic, the rationale, behind that piece of legislation was that it would be concerned with achieving compliance with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights through the education of governments, the community and the Parliament and, at the breach level, through a process of conciliation; in other words, the approach was to set up a structure which emphasised policy development, legislative review and conciliation in the case of complaints.

Much has been written and said about the Human Rights Commission but, on a reasonably balanced appraisal, one would say that it has done its work quite well. With regard to its complaint-hearing procedures, it has stated, and I have no reason to doubt it, that to December 1985 it dealt with 9,882 complaints, and it seems to have been able to dispose of most of them using the conciliation procedure. The performance of the Commission in its promotion and community education has been reasonable. In its role of reporting to the Parliament and educating and advising the Parliament in these matters it has produced 16-odd reports, most of which I have read and most of which I think are good and helpful documents.

On balance, I think that the Commission has done pretty much the job that the former Liberal-National Party Government expected of it, and it has played its part in contributing to Australia's method of dealing with and protecting basic human rights. The Commission obviously operates in a delicate area and it is obviously important that it must be particularly careful, unbiased and balanced in the way in which it deals with those very delicate matters. I therefore have to say on the other side of the coin that there are matters being dealt with by the Commission that do cause me concern. One subject that has been mentioned today in the Senate is a paper prepared on teaching for human rights by Ralph Pettman. I shall quote briefly what it says in relation to the family. The paper states:

In Australia-a liberal, capitalist, multicultural democracy, with social welfare proclivities, a highly stratified class structure, a value system that is secular, racist, sexist, and materialistic-the family reflects and promotes this fact.

I do not think that is the case. I do not think that statement can stand on any balanced appraisal. I would be concerned if a statement in those terms were available in our schools. I turn to what the paper says about something which is reasonably dear to me, and that is capitalism. Looking around the world, I can see how many people have benefited materially and otherwise from capitalist societies. The paper states:

There has been mass assassination, too, by more covert and indirect means. The construction of a capitalist world economy, predicated upon dishonesty and greed, has slaughtered uncounted millions the world over through the exploitation and the mis-development of global resources. The United States and the other erstwhile `free market' democracies have much to answer for in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —What of the authoritarian states?

—I find no mention of authoritarian societies, and that concerns me. Nobody says that the capitalist system is perfect. That is why it has masses of legislation to guide and direct it. That paper is not the balanced sort of material that the Human Rights Commission should be putting out. When it puts out rubbish of that nature, it does itself a disservice and it makes it hard for people such as me who are prepared to give it credit for all the good work it does. I think that most Australians would hold the same view. On balance, I am prepared to say that I believe that it has been a worthwhile body, making a worthwhile contribution. Certainly, as a legislator, I have found its reports of help.

SPEECH.PARA: Comparing the approach of the Liberal and National parties of the past with what is being proposed by the Labor Government today, the Labor Party has a different approach. Since 1969, it has had as part of its platform the introduction of a Bill of Rights. It introduced a Federal Bill of Rights in late 1973. That Bill was to be binding on the Federal Government, States, local officials and State parliaments. It provided individual remedies, and the Human Rights Commission was to take action on behalf of aggrieved persons. That Bill lapsed when Parliament was prorogued in February 1974 and it was not reintroduced. The Labor Party, on returning to office, reaffirmed its commitment to the introduction of a Bill of Rights. We now have this Bill before us.

What is the scheme that is proposed in this Bill? What does it seek to do in the area of the protection of human rights? I plagiarise the explanatory memorandum in saying that the Bill is an attempt to operate at two levels. With regard to the first level, the explanatory memorandum states:

The Bill of Rights is to operate as a guide to the judicial interpretation of the Commonwealth and Territory (other than Northern Territory) laws, so that as far as possible laws are construed in such a way as not to conflict with the Bill of Rights:
The second point is:

The Bill of Rights is itself to have the force of law so that when any future Commonwealth or Territory (other than Northern Territory) law (and, after 5 years, any earlier Commonwealth or Territory law) conflicts with the Bill of Rights, the Bill of Rights will prevail and the inconsistent law will be inoperative (or repealed).

I do not think that this is the best way to achieve the goal of enhancing or further entrenching the protection of human rights in this country. The Bill restates certain of the terms of the Covenant in equally broad and vague language, with expressions of sentiment which, by virtue of this Bill, will become part of the domestic law of this country and require interpretation, but expressions often by their nature not capable of precise interpretation. So the responsibility of interpretation would pass to the judiciary. I have no wish to encourage members of the judiciary in this country to impose their own values and policies on government. Policy-oriented judicial activism might be, by the United States Bill of Rights, part of the United States political process but it is not ours.

I suggest that it would be better to look to introducing detailed legislation in this country to implement effectively such of the provisions of the Covenant as are necessary to be implemented from time to time. We have the Racial Discrimination Act, the Sex Discrimination Act, and so forth. We should have detailed pieces of legislation which are capable of much more precise interpretation and which therefore do not give to the judiciary the responsibility, in effect, of becoming legislators. That preference that our side of politics has advocated places a high responsibility on Parliament and on the legislative process. I appreciate that it might be argued that from time to time Parliament has not only legislated to protect human rights but also encroached upon them. At least in the legislative process we, unlike the judiciary, are subject to the ultimate judgment of the people. If the people are unhappy with the legislative direction of a government, they can vote that government out. I refer again to the Senate Committee report to quote the words of Dr Ken Wiltshire which are reported at point 2.83. He said:

On balance my preference is always for Parliaments. I believe in a true democracy parliament ought to be our first avenue of redress of grievances. That is an entrenched belief of mine. However, government being as large as it is and it is one of the highest incidences of government in the Western world, bureaucracy being as large as it is-one in three employees in Australia works for a bureaucracy of some kind-and society being as complex as it is, I wonder if we do not have an unfair expectation of Parliament serving as a control and scrutiny device . . . I think the logistics of our government today make it very difficult for Parliament to serve the same role as it used to serve in the Victorian era when the Westminster model was refined, when government was small, government was weak and government intruded very little into people's lives.

That tends to indicate that whereas legislation in the Parliament is the correct avenue to move along, the Parliament requires the assistance of other mechanisms. That is why I see so much value in an effective and balanced Human Rights Commission; a Human Rights Commission that has the capacity to assist the Parliament in its investigations, in its reports to the Parliament and in the other ways which I detailed a little while ago. Furthermore, this approach, the Opposition's approach, overcomes the problem that most rights and freedoms cannot exist in absolute and unqualified terms. Most will have to be qualified so as to protect other individuals' rights and freedoms, and even so as to protect some general public interests. I think that is conceded, but again we find in this Bill the same general terms that cannot effectively do that. Therefore, I advocate more specific legislation to enhance and protect particular freedoms, as has been the practice in the past.

As I have indicated, I support what I call this traditional approach of the Opposition. I applaud the work that was done by the previous Liberal-National Party Government and Senator Durack, who has been playing a significant part in this debate. I suggest that perhaps we could have been a little more game in the past. I know that not all of my colleagues would agree with this view. But in this area of fundamental human rights, I have no problem with the Commonwealth Parliament, a party to the individual conventions, binding the States in relation to basic human rights. Of course, the Parliament is obliged to do so under the Covenant to which it is a party. Point 4.34 of the Committee's report referred to submissions by Mr J. Herlihy and Mr W. B. Lane, who argued:

The level of protection of fundamental rights in Australia should not be determined on a State to State basis. All Australian citizens, regardless of which State they reside in are equally entitled to the same measure of protection.

That seems to me to be a reasonable statement in the circumstances of talking about fundamental, basic human rights, not matters that are of a State interest. That is the sentiment I adopted in regard to another matter I referred to earlier tonight, the Tasmanian dams case. If we are talking about natural heritage of world significance, part of the world heritage, I do not think State by State legislation is the correct way in which to proceed. The Australian Parliament, the national Parliament, should have matured to the extent that it can deal with these matters. Again, I would be more game on the question of international adjudication. I support the position that was put to the Committee by the United Nations Association, to which I referred the Senate, at point 6.4 of the report:

A major argument on behalf of the Association was that by submitting itself to the possibility of individual petition, Australia would put itself in a better position to put pressure on other nations to observe international human rights standards.

That is the view I hold. I think we should not be so concerned with what I have heard, that nations who are less democratic would be in some way passing judgment. If we are sufficiently confident of the standards we have in the area of human rights in this country, why be frightened of international adjudication? Why not be prepared to set the standard and therefore be in a better position to demand others to comply with a similar standard?

In summary, I submit to the Senate that the practice and process that have been adopted in the past-that we are part of an international regime of protection of human rights-are the best way for us to proceed and continue to proceed. I would support and encourage that action. I would support the enactment of specific detailed legislation when it is necessary to implement covenants within the domestic law of this country. I therefore leave the prime responsibility for that purpose with the people's representatives, the legislature. I would have the Human Rights Commission able and willing to assist the Parliament in its task of legislating and to guide and educate the public in the importance of meeting the international standard that governments and the legislature have accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 and associated legislation. I first acknowledge the vast numbers of representations I have received by petition, visit, phone and certainly by mail. Thousands of interested, ordinary people who have been concerned about the issue have been in contact with me. They are not people who have been manipulated. They are not people who have been coerced, lied to, threatened or whatever else has been alleged today. These people, if the Government and the Australian Democrats had just stopped to listen, are telling them that they do not want a Bill of Rights, that they did not ask for a Bill of Rights, that the Bill was not part of the election undertakings of the Government and that the Bill before us will never provide us with any rights that we do not currently have. I will not quote Sir Harry Gibbs as I have heard him quoted many times. But I would refer to his comment, and I am sure every senator is well aware of the significance of it.

SPEECH.PARA: We are signatories to an International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. So what? What has that Covenant done for the people of the signatory countries which have human rights problems? On the day on which the Covenant was opened for signature in New York, on 19 December 1966, it had six first-day signatories: Costa Rica, Cyprus, Honduras, Israel, Jamaica and the Philippines. I think it is fair to ask: How helpful has this declaration been to them? Let us look at the others: Afghanistan, Argentina, Chile, Kampuchea, Iran, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I wonder how much benefit those countries have derived from being signatories and how much benefit there has been for the people of those signatory countries. I do not think we want to share in the sort of human rights that goes with being a member of one of those countries.

This Bill is another way in which the Government wishes to bypass the Constitution. I respect our Constitution. It is a fine Constitution and I will certainly fight changes that are proposed for change's sake or any efforts that are made to weaken the Constitution that was set up by a bunch of brilliant people and who, fortunately for us, had a lot more brains than those who would try to change it now. The aim of this legislation is to use some obscure international piece of paper which has already proved to be useless and worthless for the purpose for which allegedly it exists. We are obviously under a manoeuvre to become more internationalised as we go on. If those who wished to promote this Bill had their way they would have us singing the Internationale as part of it.

It may be of interest to honourable senators in the chamber to know that in the World Human Rights Guide by Charles Humana published in 1983, Australia with no Bill was rated at 93 per cent, whereas countries such as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics with a Bill was rated at 27 per cent on a world average of 64 per cent. I am not quite sure what we are trying to achieve and at what cost this would be obtained. I also wonder what good a Bill of Rights was to Anatoly Shcharansky. After spending 12 years in a Russian prison I really do not think he is thrilled with the possibilities of having a Bill of Rights in his country. Many of the communications that I have received have come from people who are heavily motivated and have a strong religious faith, people concerned about the wellbeing of others and people whose beliefs are to help one another. It is the political aspect that could wreck their humanitarian beliefs. Many of these people come from community groups.

We have received letters from organisations such as the Country Women's Association, various service organisations and clubs, local councils and even the Defence of Government Schools. These are organisations with no apparent political links but which are wise enough not to trust something like this which the Government is not prepared to raise as an election issue or by way of referendum. They object to the desire and intention to jam the Bill through in this manner. If it were fair and above board, why would the Government not take the trouble to explain it, as was the case with the previous referenda, the various employment schemes or whatever? But there has been no effort by the Government to give the people who have been pouring in all these inquiries any information at all. Why not leave it on the table for two or three months if it is quite okay?

The Government admits to nothing that makes this job urgent. Why disturb the ordinary people by making it look as if it is shonky. I think even Senator Gareth Evans would understand that the perception is important and he has previously fallen foul of these perceptions. I would have thought that he would have learned something from that. However, if all these letters and communications were doubtful in the minds of some of the government speakers, what about the comments that have been made by the media? TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the proposed Alice Springs to Darwin railway line, which again came under attack in this chamber only last week. Senator Walsh unleashed yet another diatribe against political commentator Katharine West because she had the audacity to support the Northern Territory Government's proposal for a privately built and owned railway. I take this opportunity to clarify the situation and to bring the Senate up to date with some facts about the project-that is, to complete the spanning of the continent by railway from north to south. I believe that the Senate could do with some factual information for a change, instead of Senator Walsh's unsubstantiated invective.

SPEECH.PARA: The final report of the Canadian Pacific Consulting Services-CPCS-on the economic viability of the extension of standard gauge rail services from Alice Springs to Darwin was tabled in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly last November and references have been made to it since then. The Northern Territory Chief Minister, in tabling the report, made the point, quite rightly, that the Canadian Pacific Consulting Services report is a vindication of the Northern Territory position on the railway. It demonstrates that the findings of the Hill report-Mr Hill is in charge of the New South Wales Railways-on which the Federal Government based its decision not to proceed with the railway, are insupportable. The reputation of Canadian Pacific Consulting Services-that is, the Canadian Pacific Railway-is beyond dispute. It is a major North American company of world-wide reputation. It carries 85 million tonnes of traffic per annum. Its expertise is unquestionable and, most importantly, it makes a profit. By contrast, the State Rail Authority of New South Wales, of which Mr Hill is Chairman, loses $800m per annum and relies on Commonwealth funds for its survival.

The conclusion of the Canadian Pacific report is that in strictly economic terms a railway extension is viable for a broad range of traffic forecasts. In 1985 dollars, using a 7 per cent discount rate over the 50 years economic life of the project, the financial projections show that the railway could provide a real return of between $54m and $264m to this nation-a handy dividend. By contrast, the Hill report claims that over a 40-year period the same Alice Springs to Darwin railway would show losses exceeding $340m in present value to the nation, regardless of the traffic volume.

The difference between the Canadian Pacific figures and the Hill report figures in cost saving terms are as follows: Between $97m and $177m, depending on the traffic volumes, will be saved by other State and Federal railways and road authorities because of the completion of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. These savings will be generated by the additional railway traffic on the Australian National and State government railway systems and reduction in road maintenance costs since road freight traffic will be transferred to rail. Also, $109m to $141m would be saved by modifying the track design which, while it would reduce the standard of the line, would not have adverse safety implications.

Reducing the construction schedule to about four years would also reduce the costs. In addition, $40m would be saved by eliminating passenger services from the evaluation of the railway's economics. Further, $30m to $40m road maintenance savings over and above those identified by David Hill would be obtained by the Territory and State governments by diverting road freight to rail. Between $13m and $32m can be recovered by disposing of the track-laying equipment and welding plant at the end of the construction period. Also $8m to $11m would be saved in labour costs by using two-man crews rather than three-man crews. Mr Hill adopted a three-man crew as a cost base but by the time the railway is completed crews in Australia, one would expect, will be reduced to two men.

These assessments are based largely on Alice Springs to Darwin northbound traffic. However, when one looks at the potential for the substantial southbound freight volumes which will be generated by the development of Darwin as a major port of entry for imports into Australia, the viability of the project will be enhanced even further. I am not going into that tonight. However, the possible development of the Darwin port for international freight is an exciting one.

This is a project of immense national significance and will do more than any other project to aid the development of Australia's north. It will open up opportunities in trade, shipping and industry and improve the viability of mines, agricultural and pastoral enterprises and create thousands of jobs directly and indirectly not only in the Territory but also in South Australia, New South Wales, Victoria and other States. The project also has substantial defence implications as the report of Dr Desmond Ball of the Australian National University's Strategic and Defence Study Centre in Canberra has argued most forcefully. Dr Ball has concluded that the existence of the railway would provide a powerful deterrent to the development of any significant military threat to Australia.

In summing up, I would like to respond to the allegations of Senator Walsh that the Federal Government will be expected to heavily subsidise the line. He evidently just cannot get off that track. As I have said, the project is of national significance and it should have bipartisan support from State governments and Federal governments because, as much as the Northern Territory itself, they will be principal beneficiaries of this project. Defence benefits, savings in fuel costs, savings in road maintenance, greater intrastate rail freight volumes and greater economic prosperity are all benefits which will not be confined to the Northern Territory alone. For those reasons the Territory Government is quite properly seeking to persuade the Federal Government to contribute to this project. It could be encouraged to do so through capital depreciation on taxation-this is not new-as has happened in respect of other national projects over the year.

Senator Walsh has dismissed the project out of hand but that is not unusual-he has done that before in relation to the Amadeus to Darwin pipeline, the construction of which is now well under way. In the Senate he referred to that project as pie in the sky. If he bothered to acquaint himself with the developments of the pipeline, and the phenomenal rate at which it is proceeding, he would have to eat his words. I believe that he will be eating his words before too long on the railway project as well.

It is time Senator Walsh and his colleagues stopped pouring out their invective just long enough to take a close look at what is happening in the north. What is happening in the north is to the benefit of the whole nation. Perhaps then, they would realise the great opportunities which Australia is losing by failing to develop this very important area.
