TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to report to the Senate that I attended the 7 February election in the Philippines as a member of an international observer mission. The mission was put together by the international institutes of both the Democratic and Republican parties of the United States. It comprised 42 representatives from 19 different countries and was jointly led by former President Pastrana, the leader of the Conservative Party of Columbia and Vice-Chairman of the International Democratic Union, and John Hume, the leader of the Social Democratic and Labour Party of Northern Ireland and a member of the British and European parliaments. The mission was accredited by the Commission on Elections-COMELEC-and received the support of both President Marcos and Mrs Aquino. An initial delegation, in testing the feasibility of the mission, concluded its positive recommendation by stating:

SPEECH.PARA: It is our belief that such a delegation can contribute to the conduct of a free and fair election, will be instrumental in determining international opinion about such an election, and will serve to underscore the vital role a credible electoral process can play in bringing about political stability in the Philippines.

The mission was preceded by officials who monitored such matters as the adequacy of the campaign period, restrictions on campaigning, political arrests, intimidation and improper campaign practices. The officials also monitored the role of the media, including access provided by COMELEC, whether the media was permitted to purchase time, the coverage of the campaign and censorship. At the level of administration of the election officials monitored COMELEC and in particular whether its local election officials acted in a non-partisan manner, voter registration, fraud prevention and the plans for the counting of ballots.

Upon arrival in Manila delegates were briefed on the above matters. Delegates were also briefed and had the opportunity to question officials of COMELEC, officials of NAMFREL, the National Citizens Movement for a Free Election, the UNEDA and JBL parties, academics and other experts. After two days of such briefings the mission was dispersed in nine smaller groups throughout the country to areas which had shown problems in the past. On the Thursday afternoon before the poll the sub-groups familiarised themselves with the major counting stations in their region and had discussions with local COMELEC officials and NAMFREL volunteers.

On election day from the opening of the polls at 7 a.m. until the closing at 3 p.m. sub-groups visited precincts and witnessed the poll, speaking to officials, other observers and voters and observing the general conduct of the poll. Upon the closure of the poll at 3 p.m. sub-groups witnessed counting at polling booth level and then followed ballot boxes to provincial and regional headquarters for subsequent voting collation. On the following day sub-groups returned to Manila for debriefing and preparation of an initial statement. That initial statement was issued on the night of Sunday, 11 February. I seek leave to have that statement incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
STATEMENT BY CO-LEADERS INTERNATIONAL OBSERVER DELEGATION

We have had the opportunity to observe an historic election in a country which each of our delegates holds in the highest esteem. We have come here as friends of democracy and of the Filipino people, and have been reaffirmed in our purpose. We share the belief that the electoral process is sacred in a democracy and the vote of the individual must be protected from those who would seek to either deny, or alter it.

We are grateful for the invitation to observe this election which was extended by both major parties. We have been moved by our experience and by the deep dedication of the vast majority of the Filipino people to the principles of democracy, and the sanctity of the electoral process. Wherever we went in the Philippines, people came up to our delegation members to thank us for coming. Some expressed surprise that we would travel so far to offer our moral support to their efforts to keep the electoral process free and honest. All of us were deeply heartened by these expressions of gratitude.

Over the past week our delegates from 19 nations and a wide range of political and ideological viewpoints have observed the electoral process in 15 provinces of the Philippines. These areas were selected on the basis of past history of election irregularities and with an eye toward maintaining political balance. We have been careful to remain impartial, and to distinguish personal observation from hearsay and fact from rumour. We have also been able to reach a consensus among each of our teams in evaluating the election in these provincial areas. We have come here today as we said we would to offer our observations, not our final assessment.

We have begun with the premise that an election is the mechanism by which citizens individually and collectively express the will of a nation. We recognise that irregularities occur to some extent in all democratic nations. The question that must be addressed by all who cherish democracy is whether malpractice occurs to such an extent as to invalidate an election result. This judgment can only be made after careful analysis of the election returns against documented reports of malpractice. We are obviously not prepared now to make that critical judgment.

Our teams have reported on areas of the country where the balloting and counting have gone smoothly and without incident. Members of the delegation have compared these areas favourably with elections held in other parts of the world.

However, in others areas, we have observed practices which compare far less favourably. Occurrences of vote buying, intimidation and lack of respect for electoral procedures were present, and were observed by members of our delegation. Attempting to ascertain the impact of these activities which are illegal under Filipino law must await the final result of the election.

A critical aspect of any election is the dissemination of the results, and the credibility attached to those results. Forty-eight hours after the vote we note that there are a number of competing counts which are damaging to the credibility of the process. One of the problems in this regard has been the failure of the COMELEC-NAMFREL ``PARTNERS'' agreement which was originally drafted to provide reliable and credible results. Our observations suggest that the resolution of the information problem is critical in ensuring national confidence in the results of this election. Regarding the official count and canvas, certain delays are occuring. Some of these have been caused by legal challenges to election returns wherein discrepancies have been found. Other delays are taking place which seem to have no basis in law. We will continue to study this problem, and to look for patterns to see whether these delays result in a shift of votes.

The activities of NAMFREL have been the focus of much attention and commentary by the government and the media. Our observations have been that the vast majority of NAMFREL volunteers in the regions we have covered have acted in a non-partisan, professional manner. Many have risked a great deal to preserve the integrity of the electoral process.

The electoral anomalies which we have witnessed are serious and could well have an impact upon the final result. These anomalies fall under two categories: those which can be termed ``irregularities'' and which may be the result of problems of election administration; and those abuses which are clearly intended to affect the outcome of the election.

Under the category of irregularities, we begin by taking note of the fact that this was a snap election and there was not much time to prepare guidelines and training programs for teachers and others who served as members of the Board of Canvas. Our teams reported instances of improperly locked and sealed-or unlocked and unsealed ballot boxes and election returns. Instances of ineffective application of indelible ink and other weaknesses in the enforcement of safeguards designed to prevent double-voting were observed and reported by our teams. Of great concern are reports that thousands of voters-particularly in the Manila area-were not able to vote because their names were not on the registration list.

In the category of abuse designed to affect the outcome, we saw many instances of vote-buying, attempts at intimidation, snatching of ballot boxes, and tampered election returns. In some areas NAMFREL, the accredited arm of COMELEC, was excluded from polling stations in violation of a range of previous agreements reached regarding access of the citizen's arm. There were also some limited areas in which the system of safeguards seemed to break down completely, and those who held responsibility for adjudicating complaints were either unavailable, or unresponsive.

We cannot determine at this point whether the extent of this activity will affect the overall results of the election, but the potential exists, and we would be remiss if we did not publicly acknowledge this fact. We will keep a team of technical experts in Manila to continue to collect information, analyze results, and observe the activities of those institutions which are designed to provide redress under the law.

We close today by underscoring our support for the democratic aspirations of the people of this great nation. The ultimate judgment as to the validity of this election-and hence its ability to facilitate reconciliation and stability-rests with the Filipino people. We stand with them in their fervent hope that the final result will reflect their will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Delegates returned to their home country shortly thereafter, leaving a secretariat to compare the observations of the international mission with those of NAMFREL, the United States presidential observer group and various other international and local observer teams. Upon completion of that work it is the intention of the mission to produce and publish a final report.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the observer mission observed widespread fraud and abuse of the electoral process. Practically every form of abuse imaginable occurred-from violent intimidation through to the snatching of ballot papers and simple vote buying. It is, however, a long step from the observations of abuse to asserting that such abuses were so numerical that they could have affected the total result. We would not want to make that assertion without being very confident of its accuracy. As a deterrent to abuse, our mission together with the hundreds of thousands of NAMFREL volunteers and other observers seems to have failed. I say that simply because some of the worst violations occurred in Makarti, the central business district of Manila, where those perpetrating acts of violence and abuse knew they would be observed, not only by such groups as ours, but also by the international media. Such blatant abuse regrettably paints a dim picture. As an encouragement and support for the hundreds of thousands of Filipinos who did work for free and fair elections and put themselves at risk to that end, the mission was obviously successful. Everywhere we went there were expressions of appreciation from NAMFREL volunteers, the church, some unions which were involved in the observing process and other community groups.

In presenting to the world a fair and objective picture of the elections we remain to be judged. We have, however, been at pains to avoid sensationalism, realising that to many outside the Philippines the election was a novelty but to many millions of Filipinos it was seen as critically important to their future. I wish to express regret that the Australian Government was not prepared to contribute to an observer mission or positively respond to the bipartisan request from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence of this Parliament to send an observer mission or even to encourage its own Caucus members to attend. Caucus members were in fact actively discouraged by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) with such nonsense as they would not be allowed within 50 metres of polling booths. I was welcomed and invited into 70-odd polling booths I visited on election day.

The Philippines faces major problems and there is obvious need for urgent reform in areas of the economy, social structures and the military. Regrettably, such reforms will not take place without stable government. On this occasion many hundreds of thousands of Filipinos believed they could contribute to what would be a turning point in Filipino history, that of a free and fair election, when a democratic government could come to power at the popular will of the people and proceed to such reforms. Both sides promised this to the Filipino people. It was an opportunity for Australia to be present and support that process, showing its concern not only for Filipinos but also for stability within the region and the Western security network of which the Philippines plays a vital part. Unfortunately, the Labor Government missed that opportunity.

To speak in very general terms, Australia is not highly regarded in the Philippines. We are not well known; in fact Australians are probably best known for their apparent involvement in Manila's vice industry. Our relations are strained, with the Philippines Government not even being prepared to engage in joint training exercises with the Royal Australian Air Force. A lot of bridge building is necessary. Australia could have started by showing a modest presence and support for an open and free election. My concern now is that the Labor Government will voice its moral indignation at the poll abuses by further cutting back its aid to the Philippines. That will not hurt the strong and wealthy, but it will hurt the poor, who can ill-afford to be further deserted by those of us who can help in their currently very difficult circumstances. I would urge the Hawke Government to think long and hard about the consequences of such a step. Help and support for the mass of Filipinos, not desertion, are needed at this time.

I say no more than that at this stage, but it is a matter obviously which we will be debating on future occasions in this Parliament. The question of the condition of the Philippines and Australia's relationship with that country will be a very delicate and difficult issue to resolve in the months ahead. I thank Senators Kilgariff, Reid and Boswell for their contributions to the debate, in each case on fairly familiar topics. I will ensure that the relevant Ministers have their attention drawn to the remarks made by those honourable senators tonight.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
